title: Intern
description:
Job title: Intern

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under close to general supervision, to perform a variety of administrative support duties and/or technical and sub-professional duties for a department head or other manager in a learning environment; and to perform related duties as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS 

This is a temporary part-time, entry level, classification. Incumbents assigned to the Intern classification perform increasingly responsible duties as on-the-job experience increases. Intern positions may be assigned to any City department or function including City Manager's, City Clerk/Communications, Community Development, Community Safety and Finance.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

Receives close to general supervision from department supervisory or management staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job. 

1. Performs tasks specific to a particular departmental and/or function (e.g. City Clerk, Community Enhancement & Safety, Community Development, Finance, Talent Attraction & Development, and Public Information/ Communications).

2. Prepares reports, memos, and correspondence as required.

3. Conducts research and surveys on specific topics in the resolution of administrative, personnel or operational concerns or problems.

4. Collects, summarizes, and analyzes information and statistics on existing programs and services.

5. Participates in organizational and procedural studies and the preparation of reports and manuals.

6. Participates in the conduct and implementation of programs and systems.

7. Assists in drafting various communications including press releases and newsletters. 8. Answers phone calls from citizens and provides accurate information and excellent customer service.

8. Operates office equipment.

9. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

10. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

No prior experience required. However, some experience (paid or unpaid) related to the area assigned is highly desirable. Two (2) years of college course work at an accredited college or university and current enrollment as a college student, OR graduation from a four (4) year accredited college or university with major course work in Public or Business Administration, or an area related to the Intern position to be assigned.

License/Certificate: 

Possession of an appropriate, valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

Modern office procedures, methods and equipment; English usage, spelling, grammar and punctuation; selected technical aspects as they relate to area assigned; effective methods or making oral and written reports; techniques of research and analysis; computer applications as they related to area assigned.




Ability to:

Communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; understand and carry out oral and written instructions; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships; provide excellent customer service; adhere to City safety standards; operate a personal computer and applicable software including word processing, spreadsheet, database, presentation and publication programs at an intermediate level; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; drive and operate a motor vehicle; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; meet deadlines and be flexible with changing priorities; interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required in order to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and related matters. These hours may include, but are not limited to: weekends, evenings and holidays. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City may be required.




DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale Employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Management Assistant
description:
Job title: Management Assistant

Job Summary

DEFINITION 

 

Under general supervision, to perform a variety of entry level specialized, administrative, and analytical generalist duties in support of an assigned department; to assist with the implementation of departmental, operational, and City-wide programs and policies; and to perform other related duties as required.   

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS 

 

This is the entry level class within the Management series. This class is typically used as an entry level professional class in which an incumbent develops and evolves into full journey level work. Incumbents may initially have limited or no directly related work experience. This class is distinguished from the Management Analyst by the performance of the more routine tasks, while the Analyst level performs more complex duties.    An incumbent in this class is expected to carry out general administrative assignments and works closely with management personnel on all matters which involve policy decisions, interpretation, and complex organizational matters. Initiative is required in conducting thorough research, and in making appropriate and sound recommendations to upper management.    

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

 

Receives general supervision from the Director, Manager, or assigned designee. May exercise lead supervision over clerical staff and interns, as assigned.  

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.  Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.   




1. Assists and participates in the development and implementation of goals, objectives, and priorities; conducts studies and surveys and performs data analyses to evaluate the effectiveness of current programs; makes recommendations on process or program enhancements and service areas; compiles and interprets qualitative, statistical, and financial data; reviews findings and assists in the preparation of staff reports.  




2. Meets and corresponds with various citizens, professionals, business, non-profit, and other groups to answer questions and secure their help in carrying out various programs. 




3. Coordinates various community special events and assists with special projects and programs as assigned. 




4. Assists with the preparation and submission of grants applications and funding requests. 




5. Represents the Economic Development Division at various Community meetings as required. 




6. Conducts surveys and performs research and statistical analyses on administrative, fiscal, personnel, and operational problems or issues; monitors legislation and proposed legislation.  




7. Assists in conducting assigned administrative, fiscal, or operational project activities, preparing and maintaining records, performing research and analysis as required; prepares and may present reports of findings and recommendations on programs, operating and organizational procedures, and cost comparisons. 




8. Performs a variety of duties related to special assignments and projects; leads or participates in committee activities, contributing views and interests of the City and/or department in the execution of responsibilities; may represent the City in relations with the community, local, federal, and state agencies, and professional organizations; makes presentations relating to areas of assignment and attends/participates in community events. 




9. Reviews, analyzes, and develops recommendations regarding state and federal legislation; monitors and ensures timely compliance with regulatory matters and reporting requirements. 




10. Collects, organizes, analyzes, and interprets routine data relating to operations, including policies, functions, organizational structure, forms and procedures, work output, space and physical planning, types, and effectiveness of equipment; prepares organization and workflow charts; designs and controls the utilization of forms; prepares procedures manuals. 




11. Assists in the preparation of City Council reports and resolutions, financial reports, requests for proposals, statistical tables, charts, and graphs. 




12. Coordinates projects, programs, and studies with other City departments, public agencies, and contractors; serves as liaison to the public in the execution of responsibilities. 




13. Coordinates with federal, state, and local agencies on the funding of City projects, which includes grant writing and monitoring of grant administrative programs to ensure contract compliance. 




14. Interacts with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner.




15. Utilizes various computer applications and software packages; enters and maintains data; generates reports from a database or network system; creates documents using word processing software. 




16. Keeps abreast of new laws and regulations affecting area of responsibility. 




17. Analyzes unusual situations and resolves them through application of management principles and practices, and in conjunction with upper management; recommends effective courses of action. 




18. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner. 




19. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.  




20. Performs other duties as assigned.  

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES 

 

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:  

 

Qualifications: 

 

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in Political Science, Business Administration, Public Administration, or a related field. One year of office administrative experience or internship involving support of a functional area.    

 

License/Certificate:   

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES 

 

Knowledge of: 

 

Concepts, theories, principles, methods and practices of organizational and municipal government administration; cost accounting procedures, practices; research and statistical methods; state, federal and local laws and regulations; report preparation and presentation methods; principles and techniques of project management; short and long range organizational planning; grant writing and application procedures; legal, ethical, and professional rules of conduct for public sector employees; computer software applications used to create spreadsheets and databases to analyze data; safe work methods and safety regulations. 

 

Ability to: 

 

Organize work based on established priorities; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound recommendations in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files and records; initiate and compose correspondence as required related to assigned work; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; exercise discretion when dealing with the public and employees on sensitive or confidential matters; understand and follow written and oral instructions; gather pertinent facts, making thorough analyses, and arriving at sound conclusions; report information in clear, complete, and logical form; work independently or as part of a team to organize and complete detailed assignments with minimal direction; participate in conducting routine organizational and procedural studies and prepare comprehensive reports; recommend and implement goals and objectives for providing effective services; properly interpret and make decisions in accordance with laws, regulations, and policies; plan and present clear, concise, and effective presentations to executive management and the public using non-technical language; organize and maintain accurate records of activities and projects; prepare and administer an operating budget; participate in directing various work activities consistent with goals and priorities; assist in evaluating programs and services from an operational and productivity standpoint; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work, including the City Manager, management, staff, other government officials, community groups, and the general public; apply safe work practices; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; operate a computer using word processing, database and spreadsheet software at an advanced level.  

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 

 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.   

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required. 

 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

 

Physical Demands: 

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

 

Mental Demands: 

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work. 

 

 

WORKING CONDITIONS 

 

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the incumbent. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City may be required. 

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER 

 

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Human Resources & Risk Manager
description:
Job title: Human Resources & Risk Manager

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under general direction, to plan, coordinate, recommend and implement the activities and operations of the City’s human capital program with an emphasis on talent acquisition and employee retention in order to develop a strong and effective workforce to serve the residents and businesses of the City of Eastvale;  to develop an “employer of choice” team-centered, collaborative work environment that promotes innovation and creativity; to recommend and implement programs and policies in support of employee engagement, employee and team development, employee wellness, employee recognition, and employee work/life balance; to manage and coordinate all traditional human resources functions; to lead, manage, and implement various special projects and programs for the City across multiple City departments and functions involving the City’s human capital; and to perform related duties as required. 

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives general direction from the City Manager, or the City Manager’s designee; may exercise general supervision over professional, para-professional, technical and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

1. Leads and manages the development, implementation, and nurturing of a team-centered, collaborative culture and work environment; conducts research related to best practices; seeks opportunities to invest in people in order to deliver a high level of employee satisfaction and customer service. 

2. Recommends and implements special programs to support employee engagement, employee wellness, employee recognition, rewards programs, and employee work/life balance; coordinates various annual employee events/activities to foster a best practices work environment consistent with an “employer of choice.”

3. Coordinates City-wide training; assesses training needs for all City staff; works closely with supervisors and managers to identify individual job enrichment and employee development opportunities for succession planning, and towards the achievement of employee self-actualization.

4. Serves as the City’s “Talent and Acquisition Manager” leading the City’s marketing and recruitment efforts; posts and manages open recruitments; determines advertising and outreach strategies; uses social media to support the recruiting process.

5. Serves as the face of the City for external career fairs to attract candidates; participates in community outreach activities related to recruiting and to maintain visibility.

6. Maintains the City’s recruitment webpage so that it is visually appealing, current, and relevant to prospective applicants; develops and maintains effective City branding, which emphasizes the City of Eastvale’s culture of innovation and creativity, as a clear “employer of choice” with best practice approaches to the work environment for optimal employer/employee relations. 

7. Manages the City’s applicant tracking system; screens candidates and evaluates candidate qualifications; recommends the most highly qualified candidates for further review; coordinates a structured and unbiased selection process to include tests, practical exercises, and interviews in order to further evaluate candidates.   

8. Conducts reference checks, background checks; coordinates post-offer physical exams; prepares conditional and final offer letters; conducts on-boarding sessions and new employee orientation sessions.   

9. Participates in the development and implementation of goals, objectives, policies, and priorities for assigned programs; recommends, develops, and administers policies and procedures.

10. Plans, coordinates, administers, and manages traditional human resources programs and services for the City and its human capital including benefits administration, classification and compensation, plan administration, workers’ compensation, training, safety, risk management and related functions. 

11. Facilitates the resolution of sensitive and controversial issues in the course of managing the responsibility for all human resources services and activities, nurtures continuous positive working relationship with employees, supervisors, managers, and department heads.  

12. Monitors and evaluates the efficiency and effectiveness of service delivery policies, practices, methods, and procedures; makes recommendations for improvement.

13. Plans, directs, coordinates, and reviews the work plan for human resources, assigns work activities, projects, and programs; reviews and evaluates work products, methods, and procedures; meets with staff to identify and resolve problems.

14. Administers and maintains the City’s classification and compensation plan; conducts job analysis studies, salary and benefit surveys; makes recommendations and implements appropriate solutions.

15. Administers the City’s workers’ compensation program; receives and processes claims; serves as the liaison with injured workers, City staff, attorneys, medical providers, and investigators in the management of injured worker claims; and works closely with injured employees, managers and supervisors regarding return to work issues. 

16. Assists in the overall administration of health benefits program including conducting open enrollment for health benefits and coordinating information with the City’s benefits administrator; reviews the City’s benefit package annually for cost effectiveness and makes recommendations for changes and/or enhancements. 

17. Administers leave management programs for the City including various protected state and federal leave of absence laws; provides required notices, monitors time off, and conducts interactive processes in accordance with the Americans’ with Disabilities Act (ADA), as required.  

18. Selects, trains, motivates, and evaluates staff; provides and/or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies; implements discipline and termination procedures; conducts exit interviews.

19. Participates in the development and administration of the annual budget; participates in the forecast of funds needed for staffing, equipment, materials, and supplies; monitors and approves expenditures; implements adjustments.

20. Serves as the liaison for human resources services internally, and with outside agencies; assists with disciplinary issues and provides guidance on handling employee issues; negotiates and resolves sensitive and controversial issues; receives and assists in the investigation and resolution of complaints.   

21. Prepares and presents staff reports to City Council; prepares necessary correspondence.

23. Coordinates with the City Attorney as needed related to legal issues.

24. Serves as records manager in the maintenance of official employee personnel files and confidential employee records.

25. Conducts a variety of organizational studies, investigations, and operational studies; recommends modifications to personnel administration programs, policies, and procedures as appropriate.

26. Coordinates the City’s risk management activities with the carrier, and in consultation with the City Attorney and City Manager as required.  

27. Develops, coordinates, and administers an effective safety program and maintains required records.

28. Attends and participates in professional and community meetings as necessary; stays current on issues relative to the field of human resources, talent acquisition and retention, and municipal operations in general. 

29. Participates in cross-training and provides back up to other staff; assists other office personnel in performing related administrative support functions.

30. Establishes positive working relationships with City staff and the public.

31. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe and efficient manner.

32. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

 

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

 

Qualifications:




Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in public administration, business administration, human resources, or a closely related field. A minimum of five years of progressively responsible experience in municipal or public administration, human resources, benefits administration, or risk management with three years of supervisory, management, and/or administrative experience.  

 

License/Certificate:  

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

 

Possession of a professional Human Resources certification is highly desirable and/or completion of college coursework in Human Resources or Organizational Development.  

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

 

Knowledge of:




Operations, services, and activities of a municipal human resources program in a public agency setting including job analysis, classification, compensation, benefits administration, workers’ compensation, safety, employee relations, employee development, and training; methods and techniques of talent acquisition including recruitment, outreach, marketing, and branding  strategies; methods and techniques of screening and selection practices, test construction, and interviewing; management practices related to employee onboarding and orientation;  modern trends and best practices related to employers of choice; concepts and methods of employee engagement, employee recognition, employee development, employee wellness and employee work life balance programs; legal issues in the field of human resources management; basic principles and practices of budget administration, contract administration and evaluation; principles and methods of employee supervision including work planning, assignment, training, review and evaluation of staff; methods and techniques of research and analysis of personnel administrative and statistical data; principles and procedures of record keeping; principles and practices of customer service; modern office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and related software applications such as word processing, spread sheets and databases; the organization and operations of the City and of outside agencies in order to perform necessary assigned responsibilities; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes, and regulations; English usage, spelling, grammar and punctuation; business letter writing and report preparation; safe work methods and safety regulations.

 

Ability to:




Plan and administer an effective and compliant human resources program; perform professional level managerial responsibilities in the administration of the City’s personnel functions; make independent decisions; establish goals and objectives; design effective talent acquisition  programs to obtain highly qualified candidates; develop valid and effective selection procedures; onboard and orient new employees; research, conceive, and initiate best practices programs as an “employer of choice” for employee retention; implement progressive employee development, employee recognition, employee wellness and employee work-life balance programs; research, collect, compile, and analyze information and data; make complete and accurate analyses, reports, and recommendations in a variety of personnel areas; prepare clear, concise, oral and written reports both narrative and statistical; work tactfully with and gain confidence and cooperation of other internal personnel, the public, and outside agencies and organizations; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; understand, interpret, and apply general and specific administrative and human resources policies and procedures as well as applicable federal, state, and local policies, laws, and regulations; formulate and conduct presentations to employees, supervisors, and division managers; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; operate office equipment including computers and supporting software applications; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely, and appropriately to inquiries from the public, City staff, or other agencies on sensitive issues in area of responsibility; exercise good judgment and maintain confidentiality in maintaining critical sensitive information, records, and reports; utilize public relations techniques in responding to inquiries and complaints; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.

 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  Travel by vehicle may be required while conducting City business.  

 

Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Human Resources/Risk Manager.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally, the environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER




In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Construction Inspector
description:
Job title: Construction Inspector

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, performs quality assurance inspections on a variety of civil engineering and public works projects. Performs construction, installation, repair, and maintenance of the infrastructure of the City’s potable water system, reclaimed water system, and streets. Coordinates construction activities with contractors and the project team, attends various meetings to provide status updates, identifies problem areas, and recommends resolutions.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is a journey level position within the Public Works department. Performs construction inspections of the workmanship and materials in a variety of public works or utility construction projects. Distinguished from Senior Construction Inspector in its performance of more routine inspection activities and tasks. Ensures compliance with plans, specifications, and departmental regulations.  




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Public Works Director/City Engineer or designee. Provides broad support and insight to lower level technical staff and related personnel.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  



Performs inspections on all Capital Improvement, Land Development, and other permitted projects; provides general project updates and regularly communicates and coordinates project status with developers, contractors, and utility owners.
Reviews plans and specifications of assigned projects with construction supervisors; interprets and applies construction knowledge to various plans, drawings, and blueprints; indicates location of various appurtenances on plans.
Inspects materials, equipment, and tools for identification to ensure compliance with specifications; monitors safety hazards and ensures proper construction procedures.
Reads and interprets engineering plans, specifications and details, utility maps, barricade manuals, and related engineering plans and drawings for constructability and to ensure compliance with project plans and specifications; advises contractors or developers of changes necessary for compliance.
Inspects, checks, and evaluates adjacent properties for damage from construction activity; confers, engages, and communicates with property owners regarding project schedule, hazards, and inconvenience.
Coordinates and collaborates work with other city departments and utilities to ensure cohesion, transparency, and efficiency; helps locate other utility structures ahead of work sites; schedules service interruptions to ensure the least interferences and least inconvenience to properties and property owners.
Prepares, creates, and drafts as built plans for completed projects; monitors compliance with air and water quality regulations.
Verifies progress payment requests and computes final quantities item-by-item from the contract bid schedule on City contract jobs, special improvement districts, and on a private development involving City cost sharing in order to determine the amount of money to be paid by contractor.
Supports communication between the City and outside contractors on large or specialized construction projects including treatment plants, pump stations, lift stations, well sites, and specialized street maintenance projects.
Participates in training and professional development.
Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

High School Diploma, GED supplemented by specialized training in building and construction. Two (2) years of increasingly responsible experience in inspection of industrial, commercial, residential construction.




License/Certificate: 

Possession of at least one Building Inspector Certificate from the ICC.

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of: 

Modern principles, procedures, practices and standards of municipal civil engineering; land development, surveying methods and techniques; municipal engineering laws, ordinances, codes, specifications and plans; engineering project inspection methods; water and wastewater systems/plants; modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding engineering; principles and practices of contract administration; traffic engineering fundamentals and use of standard equipment used in the engineering profession; communications techniques; cost estimation practices; engineering principles and practices as applied to public works, including planning and development, design, and construction; methods and techniques utilized in the preparation of public works project designs and related plans, specifications, and cost estimates; related federal and state laws, ordinances and regulations; standard office procedures, practices and equipment; modern office equipment, including a computer and applicable software; methods and techniques for record keeping and report preparation and writing; proper English, spelling and grammar; occupational hazards and standard safety practices




Ability to: 

Operate computer terminal and use computer-aided design, mapping, spreadsheet and word processing programs; review and prepare engineering plans, specifications and design requirements; analyze and interpret legal contracts and work agreements; prepare and evaluate engineering data; organize and prioritize tasks to meet deadlines; prepare clear and concise reports, drawings, maps, notes, correspondence and other written materials; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships with staff, management, public and private representatives, contractors, architects, developers, and others in the course of work; perform professional engineering work, including project design; direct the work of others involved in related activity; interpret and apply related laws, ordinances, and regulations; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; prepare and maintain records and reports; meet the public in situations requiring diplomacy and tact; deal constructively with conflict and develop effective resolutions; communicate effectively both orally and in writing; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is frequently climbing, balancing, reaching, sitting, standing, stooping, kneeling, crouching, walking, talking, seeing, hearing, smelling, and utilizing manual dexterity. Occasional lifting and carrying up to 20 pounds. Work is typically performed in both standard office and outdoor environments, with potential exposure to adverse weather conditions. Work is occasionally performed in high and precarious places and near moving mechanical parts. Occasional exposure to the risk of electric shock, fumes, airborne particles, infectious diseases, and criminal suspects. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee may be required to deal constructively with conflict and in developing effective resolutions. The employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

Work periodically in an office environment and frequently in an inspection site environment with exposure to dust, noise, fumes, and inclement weather. Frequent standing and sitting for extended periods; walking on even, uneven, and slippery surfaces; climbing, stooping, squatting, crouching, kneeling, bending, leaning, turning, twisting, reaching, grasping, pushing, and pulling. Lifting, carrying, and pushing objects weighing up to 20 pounds.  Inspect in confined areas.  Near and far vision required for performing inspections. Drive motorized vehicles and work around moving traffic. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

title: Planning Technician
description:
Job title: Planning Technician

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, the Planning Technician is the primary operator of the Planning Division public counter responsible for: providing exceptional customer service; answering questions from the public; intake and review of plans and applications for completeness; a variety of tasks in gathering, analyzing and summarizing data required by professional planning staff; and performing other related duties as assigned.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the paraprofessional class in the Planning series. Incumbents in this class are initially considered to be in a training status and work assignments are generally limited in scope. As experience is gained, incumbents are expected to perform more complex tasks and assignments of limited to moderate difficulty within the design and framework established by higher level management staff. As experience is acquired, the employee performs with increasing independence. This Planning Technician is distinguished from the Assistant Planner in that an incumbent is expected to perform assigned duties under direct supervision as they learn their positions.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives close to general supervision from the Planning Manager or designee.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job
Assist in the analysis and interpretation of social, economic, population, and land use data and trends; assist in the preparation of written reports on various planning and environmental matters.
Compiles basic information and makes recommendations on special studies of a limited scope.
Researches and drafts ordinances for review with supervisor.
Reviews basic -zoning, variances, conditional use permits, design review, and other similar planning related applications; assists with preparing legal notices to public hearings; assists with preparing reports pertaining to advisability and permissibility of the requests; confers with property owners and petitioners regarding effects and implications of zoning and development actions.
Reviews basic building plans and other development related applications, for conformance with appropriate regulations and conditions of approval for a specific case.
Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.
Deals directly with the public at the counter and over the phone, responding to inquiries and answering routine questions concerning zoning, land use, the general plan and current projects.
Receives plans at the counter for plan check, and verifies accuracy and completeness of material submitted; issues various permits; records, logs, routes and tracks various plans and permits being processed.
Prepares, maintains and/or updates zoning and general plan maps, base maps and others required by special circumstances; prepares according to specified scales using a variety of drafting equipment and graphic arts tools and techniques to prepare maps, charts and graphs.
Compiles and maintains records and reports on statistical information for various planning permits and related documents; compiles and prepares reports on land zone throughout the City; operates a computer terminal to enter and retrieve information.
May perform field inspections to verify address and individual property holding; tabulates and maps results; identifies parcel numbers, addresses and property owners for notification.
Provides preliminary review of plans and processes planning applications.
Reviews business registration applications for compliance with zoning ordinances and performs necessary follow-up.
Prepares zoning compliance letters for financial institutions and real estate agencies.
May perform field inspections to verify site conditions with respect to routine plan checks or zoning compliance letters.
Investigates and processes permit requests for fences, patios and other tenant improvements; investigates and processes requests for residential and business signs.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Required qualifications: Meeting the minimum required qualifications can be achieved by any of the following options:

Option #1: Graduation from high school or equivalent, and three years of planning or front counter technician experience that provides the basic knowledge and ability to perform the required duties.

Option #2: Graduation with an associates degree, and two years of planning or front counter technician experience that provides the basic knowledge and ability to perform the required duties.

Option #3: Graduation with a bachelor's degree

Desired qualifications: Bachelor's degree in Urban and Regional Planning, Planning Administration, Environmental Planning, Landscape Architecture, Public Administration, or other related discipline; with some municipal planning experience.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Planning principles and practices, mapping methods, practices and techniques; implementation of zoning and other municipal ordinances; methods used in developing information for General Plan modifications; land use, physical design, environmental, and/or social concepts to the planning process; mathematic concepts; terminology, symbols, methods, used on zoning and General Plan maps; applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations. Current literature, information sources, and research techniques in the field of urban planning. Personal computer operation and relevant software applications. general office procedures. Skill in the use of a personal computer, drafting tools and the operation of a variety of office equipment

Ability to:

Ability to prepare and interpret maps/plans; calculate and convert map/plans scales; gather and compile data; keep accurate records; perform routine assignments under supervision; understand and apply federal, state and local laws, regulations, policies, procedures and standards pertaining to the planning process; interpret maps, site and building plans and specifications, graphs and statistical data; prepare clear and concise reports, correspondence and other written materials; keep accurate records; exercise sound judgment within established guidelines and supervisory direction; analyze, organize and systematically compile technical and statistical information, and to prepare routine reports; work effectively in a high volume, fast paced environment; provide superior customer service; operate a personal computer and applicable software programs; follow written and oral directions; promote and observe safety principles and work in a safe manner; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City personnel and the public; operate an office computer and a variety of word processing and software applications.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment and occasionally works in a construction site and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, and special City events. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. Employees may occasionally work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or electrical hazards.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Purchasing Manager
description:
Job title: Purchasing Manager

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, manages, oversees, supervises, and monitors procurement activities and operations for the City and its departments. Manages staff, interprets and applies local, state, and federal statutes, ensures compliance with purchasing guidelines, and manages projects that are highly complex and risk adverse for the City. 




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Finance Director/City Treasurer or designee. Provides close to general supervision over professional, para-professional, technical, and accounting clerical staff as assigned.  

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS


1. Manages, monitors, and oversees the daily functions, operations, and activities of the Purchasing Division and provide all procurement and related services for internal customers; protects and guards the City’s interests through transparent purchasing, procurement, and risk analysis; develops policies, procedures, and standards for procurement activities.

2. Plans, manages, and oversees the operations of the Warehouse function; evaluates and maintains adequate stock levels and proper inventory control practices. 

3. Oversees and manages daily purchase orders ensuring compliance with contract requirements, approval authority, and budgetary control; verifies supplies are purchased through the appropriate contracts and negotiates contracts for departments as needed.

4. Directs complex formal and informal solicitations, including but not limited to Request for Proposal (RFP), Request for Qualifications and Quotations (RFQ), Notice Inviting Bids (NIB), and Public Works bidding for locally funded projects using generally accepted best practices; compiles timelines, legal bid specifications, and other requirements.

5. Manages, oversees, supports, and facilitates hiring, interviewing, training, motivating, and evaluating assigned purchasing and warehouse personnel; works with employees to correct deficiencies; recommends and implements discipline and termination procedures.

6. Creates, oversees, and manages the approval process for written, long and short form contracts based on procurement best practices; reviews contractual documents for completeness, accuracy, and compliance with policies and procedures, presents documents to legal and executive management for approval and authorization; researches, analyzes, and implements codes, policies, and procedures: ensures best value and appropriate apportionment of risk.

7. Communicates, collaborates, and strategizes with project managers to negotiate contract scope, pricing, terms and conditions, and performance standards; evaluates solicitations of services.

8. Reviews and issues decisions regarding sole-source requests, vendor protests, and non-compliance issues; investigates and resolves any disputes and/or complaints; identifies and implements process improvement methods concerning procurement and supply problems; ensures all deliberation and outcomes of internal and external customers are fair, reasonable, and within the law.

9. Answers and responds to procurement related questions from residents so that the residents of the City are served accurate and useful information; develops and creates presentations and outreach and provide department metrics to enhance services.

10. Conducts market research to identify market trends, emerging technologies, and superior suppliers; communicates with departments to identify needs.

11. Manages and creates training to improve procurement knowledge; develops and implements procurement information sessions for suppliers and other outreach activities to increase supplier participation in solicitations.

12. Performs related duties as assigned.  

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES




Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in Purchasing, Finance, Business Administration, Public Administration or closely related field, and five (5) years of progressively responsible professional purchasing and procurement experience, including municipal or local government related.  Two (2) years of supervisory experience preferred. 




License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:

Thorough knowledge of current purchasing and procurement principles and practices; contract management, negotiation, and support; Governmental Accounting and Purchasing standards and other pertinent federal, state, and local laws; purchasing and financial management software systems and ability to utilize various software programs to analyze and maintain large amounts of data. 




Ability to:

Negotiate purchasing contracts and facilitate procurement activities; maintain efficient and effective purchasing systems and procedures; accurately account for City funds; establish and maintain effective working relationships with employees, City officials, vendors and the public; operate listed tools and equipment; accurately record and maintain records; read, interpret and understand rules, regulations and ordinances; work independently; analyze and review organizational and management problems and recommend and implement effective courses of action; draft and edit reports and various documents; learn, interpret and apply City policies, procedures, rules and regulations; elicit cooperation of others; properly interpret and make decisions in accordance with laws, rules, and policies and to assimilate and understand information consistent with essential job duties; think clearly and work well under normal and high pressure situations; make sound judgments in a manner consistent with essential job duties.




Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS




Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  




Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS




The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, and special City events.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Senior Accountant
description:
Job title: Senior Accountant

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under general direction, to perform advanced and complex professional accounting functions involved in compiling, preparing and monitoring a wide variety of accounting activities; to supervise and review the work of professional employees involved in a variety of accounting, financial and accounts payable functions of the City; and, to perform duties relative to the assigned area of responsibility and related duties as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS




This is the advanced journey level class within the Accountant series. This class is distinguished from the Accountant by the performance of advanced journey level duties, by the difficulty and complexity of work performed, and the responsibility for the oversight and supervision of staff, as assigned.  This class is further distinguished from the lower level Accountant by the responsibility for complex accounting involving a thorough knowledge of public agency accounting procedures, the ability to exercise sound independent judgment within established guidelines, ensuring day-to-day accounting and fiscal activities are in conformance with accepted standards, and appropriate laws and regulations. Discretion is required in applying general goal and policy statements, and in resolving organizational and service delivery problems. Latitude is necessary in administering a complex and sensitive area of responsibility.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives general direction from the Finance Director/City Treasurer or designee; exercises close to general supervision over other accounting staff as assigned. 

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.  Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Recommends and assists in the implementation of departmental goals and objectives; implements approved policies and procedures; participates in the development of accounting systems, control systems, and reporting procedures.




2. Organizes, develops, updates and monitors information from a variety of databases, word processing, and spreadsheet software applications to prepare information related to departmental and division reports.




3. Assists management staff in establishing and directing City-wide policies and procedures related to financial transactions and financial reporting to ensure effective internal controls.




4. Prepares and analyzes complex financial reports and statements; notifies departments when there are discrepancies; monitors cash balances in all funds; recommends adjustments as appropriate.




5. Performs bank account reconciliations, verifying accuracy of recorded transactions; prepares related work sheets, cash balances, proofs, and other schedules; supervises or prepares daily cash flow analysis.




6. Supervises and reviews the work of subordinates in making entries, reconciliations, and performing other fiscal recordkeeping work.




7. Makes complex or difficult adjusting entries affecting several sub-systems of an accounting system; assists in closing the City’s financial records at the end of the accounting period; prepares a variety of related reports.




8. Acts as a liaison to other City personnel, auditors, other agencies, and the public regarding accounting activity; coordinates the preparation of external audit materials and assists auditors in the review of financial operations; responds to and resolves questions and requests for information from the auditor.  




9. Analyzes and tracks budgetary expenditures and prepares accounting summaries for use in accounting reports, financial summaries, or reimbursement actions.




10. Participates in the administration of the City’s business registration and rental registration programs. 




11. Enters data and proofreads a wide variety of reports, letters, memoranda, correspondence, and statistical charts; independently composes correspondence related to assigned area of responsibility.




12. Utilizes various computer applications and software packages; enters and maintains data; generates reports from a database or network system; creates documents using word processing software.




13. Recommends and assists in the implementation of goals and objectives; implements approved policies and procedures; participates in the development of accounting systems, control systems, and reporting procedures.




14. Participates in the selection of subordinate staff; provides or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies.




15. Reviews staff reports; ensures compliance with approved City budget; evaluates financial impact.




16. Prepares purchase orders and check requests; receives invoices, checks for accuracy and processes for payment.




17. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.




18. Provides back-up support to other staff as required.




19. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

 

Qualifications:




Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in Finance, Business Administration, Public Administration, Accounting, or a closely related field, and four to five years of increasingly responsible professional level accounting work, including one year of supervisory experience.   Governmental accounting experience is highly desirable. 

 

License/Certificate

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:




Advanced principles and practices of accounting and auditing, including governmental accounting and budgeting; pertinent Federal, State, and local laws, codes and regulations related to accounting and budgeting practices; advanced research methods involving the use of department data processing systems/applications related to accounting and budgeting procedures and practices; departmental administrative policies; advanced office practices and procedures; principles and practices of sound business communications; correct English usage, including spelling, grammar and punctuation; word processing and spreadsheet software at an advanced level; record keeping, filing, and accounting procedures; and report preparation and presentation methods; safe work methods and safety regulations.

 

Ability to:




Prepare and present detailed reports; analyze and interpret data; interpret, understand, explain, and apply related laws, regulations, policies, and procedures; supervise and coordinate the work of subordinate staff as assigned; operate a computer using a variety of software programs at an advanced level; organize, set priorities and exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound decisions in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files; compose routine correspondence from brief instructions; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; understand and follow written and oral instructions; prepare clear, accurate and concise records and reports; use tact and discretion in dealing with sensitive situations, concerned people and customers; and establish and maintain effective working relationships with the City Manager, City Council, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safety operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS




Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business. 




Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the incumbent.  These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City may be required.
