title: Senior Accounting Technician
description:
Job title: Senior Accounting Technician

Job Summary

DEFINITION 

Under general supervision of the Finance Director, to perform a variety of highly responsible and advanced/lead level accounting related functions in billing, cashiering, accounts payable, accounts receivable, purchasing, permits, registrations, payroll and related functions; to receive and process payments, and verify account and application information; to explain procedures, issue receipts for registrations and permits, and handle delinquent accounts by telephone and in-person; to perform specialized clerical work in connection with the preparation, validation, examination, coding, and reconciliation of fiscal, financial, payroll and statistical records; and to perform other related duties as required.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS 

The Senior Accounting Technician is the advanced/lead level class within the Accounting Technician series and is responsible for performing a full range of accounting and financial transaction related duties, including Payroll. Incumbents within this classification are expected to demonstrate a complete understanding of all applicable policies, procedures and work methods associated with assigned duties. Employees in this class may often have contact with other City employees, businesses, and the public. This classification is distinguished from the lower level classification of Accounting Technician in that incumbents are expected to perform assigned duties with minimal supervision and at an independent level.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

Receives general supervision from the Finance Director, City Manager, or City Manager designee.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Verifies warrants, deposit slips, computer source documents, and other records for arithmetical accuracy, consistency, and budget classifications requiring application of established coding and record keeping practices.

2. Assembles, sorts, tabulates, codes, and files fiscal and statistical data; makes arithmetical calculations and verifies totals and extensions; performs data entry or maintains manual records to post, adjust, and balance accounts; allocates funds to correct accounts according to established procedure; balances and reconciles accounts.

3. Collects and accounts for money; issues vouchers and receipts; prepares deposits as assigned; generates computer or manual warrants as assigned, in accordance with established procedures; receives payments; validates receipts for all City departments.

4. Prepares and otherwise processes various bills and invoices; generates billing for accounts; prepares entries, tabulations, standard forms, and routine documents according to specific instructions; maintains related files; operates data terminals, calculators, and other standard office equipment as required.

5. Researches problem accounts; reviews and processes claims for overpayment; handles customer questions and concerns about accounts and payment procedures; contacts delinquent accounts.

6. Responds to inquiries in person or by phone, providing explanation of established procedures and work unit policies; issues routine correspondence to vendors, businesses, or the public according to established procedure, including routine collection correspondence.

7. As required, contacts financial institutions, vendors, businesses, the public, or other agencies to verify or obtain routine information regarding City financial activity; and assist others involved in related activity.

8. Verifies time records against consultant invoices and checks appropriate amounts against approved contracts; processes consultant invoices for accounts payable payments.

9. Monitors individual developer accounts for deposit thresholds and processes appropriate account billing requests for low thresholds and delinquent accounts; places delinquent accounts on hold status until payment received; coordinates billings with accounts receivable staff; posts invoice payments to appropriate developer accounts and releases hold status.

10. Maintains payroll information by collecting, calculating, and entering data; updates payroll records by entering changes in exemptions, insurance coverage, and savings deductions; resolves payroll discrepancies by collecting and analyzing information; provides payroll information by answering questions and requests; maintains payroll operations by following policies and procedures; reports needed changes.

11. Assists in the administration of the City's business registration and rental registration programs.

12. Assists in audit preparation and site visits.

13. Prepares account reconciliations for annual audit for payroll and other accounts as required.

14. Uses spreadsheet software to keep financial records and to process documents involved in financial transactions; processes invoices for payment.

15. Prepares checks for authorized signatures and distribution and/or mailing.

16. Assists in preparing a variety of bi-weekly, monthly, quarterly and year-end reports; assembles, prepares and enters into computer a variety of data.

17. Creates correspondence.

18. Keeps abreast of new laws and regulations effecting area of responsibility.

19. Conducts cross-training with other clerical functions to cover the duties of other office staff during absences, as needed.

20. Assume responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

21. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from high school or satisfactory equivalent, supplemented by college level coursework in accounting or related field, and three years of general or accounting experience, including some statistical or financial record keeping. Municipal accounting experience preferred.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

General fiscal and financial record keeping practices; procedures, methods, and office equipment used in statistical record keeping; principles, methods and practices of payroll, accounts receivable, accounts payable, and customer account record keeping work; customer service practices and business communications techniques; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Perform difficult clerical, financial record keeping; make arithmetic calculations quickly and with accuracy; operate a computer using word processing and spreadsheet software; type accurately at a speed necessary to meet the requirements of the position; organize, set priorities and exercise sound judgment within areas of responsibility; work independently; handle a high volume of customer questions and concerns regarding billing, in person and by telephone; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; understand and follow written and oral instructions; prepare clear, accurate and concise financial records and reports; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City Manager, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safety operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS 

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required in order to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and other related matters. These hours may include, but are not limited to: weekends, evenings and holidays. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale Employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Community Services & Recreation Leader I
description:
Job title: Community Services & Recreation Leader I

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under close to general supervision, to perform a variety of administrative support duties and/or technical and sub-professional tasks in assisting the Community Services Division’s activities and events; and to perform related duties as required.

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is a temporary part-time, entry level, classification. Incumbents assigned to the Community Services Leader classification perform increasingly responsible duties as on-the-job experience increases. The Community Services Leader differs from the Community Services Coordinator in that the Community Services Leader exercises limited levels of independent judgement and performs more routine tasks where the Community Services Coordinator exercises moderate levels of independent judgement and performs complex tasks.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives close to general supervision from the Community Services Manager or designee as assigned.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.




1. Promote and help enforce established policies and procedures for special events and programs.  




2. Help identify special event and program needs; help prepare and schedule special event and program activities; determine, gather, and prepare materials and equipment. 




3. Conduct inventory and maintain and care for supplies and equipment.




4. Prepare facilities for special events and program operations.  Perform facility clean-up after special events or program closing. 




5. Inspect event facilities and program areas for safety hazards.  Assists in minor maintenance assignments, as required, and report maintenance and safety hazards. 




6. Help maintain participant attendance reports and other special event or program records. 




7. Provide routine/procedural information to the public; direct people to the appropriate event or program location; assist other employees in the conduct of event or program activities.




8. Assists with desk reception, telephone support and related customer service activities. Accept registrations and collect fees as required.  Enter and retrieve registration data on computer. 




9. Interact with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner. 




10. Maintain prompt and regular attendance.




11. Operates office equipment. 




12. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.




13. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

 

Qualifications:

 

Equivalent to the completion of the twelfth grade is required with two (2) years of college course work at an accredited college being preferred. One (1) year of recreation programming or facility maintenance experience is preferred.

 

License/Certificate:

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

 

Possession of a Standard First Aid Certificate issued by the American Red Cross.

 

Possession of a CPR Certification.

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

 

Knowledge of:




Basic principles of employee and volunteer supervision and training; principles, practices, methods, techniques, procedures, and service delivery needs related to the program area to which assigned; procedures for planning, implementing and maintaining a variety of recreation and leisure activities through community participation; recreational, cultural, age-specific, and social needs of the community; variety of games, sports, and other recreational activities appropriate to various ages of participants; applicable Federal, State and local laws, regulations, codes and guidelines related to the program area and facilities to which assigned; principles and practices of program administration, including budgeting, purchasing and basic supervision; event site management and oversight; safety principles and practices, including basic first aid; business arithmetic and basic statistical techniques; basic principles of record keeping and cash handling; modern office practices, methods and computer equipment; computer applications related to the work; English usage, grammar, spelling, vocabulary, and punctuation; techniques for providing a high level of customer service to public and City staff, in person and over the telephone. 




Ability to:




Plan, coordinate, review and evaluate a community event, as well as volunteers and staff; maintain events equipment in a clean, safe and secure manner; provide excellent customer service; respond to medical emergencies and injuries in a calm and effective manner, including providing basic first aid and/or adult and child cardiopulmonary resuscitation; understand and carry out both oral and written instructions in an independent and timely manner; organize own work, set priorities and meet critical time deadlines; operate modern office equipment including computer equipment and specialized software applications programs; use English effectively to communicate in person, over the telephone and in writing; use tact, initiative, prudence and independent judgment within general policy, procedural and legal guidelines; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of the work; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle where required in the course of performing work duties. 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS



Ability to work a part-time, varying, and flexible schedule to include weekdays, weekends, evenings, holidays, and occasional special events (hours/days will be adjusted as needed). 

 

Ability to travel between various locations during their scheduled work shift. 

 

Ability to drive vehicles used to transport materials, tools, and equipment.


PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally needs to push, pull, drag, lift, lean, stoop, twist, bend, and/or carry equipment/supplies weighing up to 50 lbs., in the performance of job duties. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

 

Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS

 

The employee typically works in an office and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs, including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the City’s Community Services Leader. These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events. 

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER




In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Management Analyst
description:
Job title: Management Analyst

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, performs specialized, administrative, and analytical tasks in support of the Community Development Department. Assists with the implementation of departmental, operational, and City-wide programs and policies and manages economic development outreach, support, and marketing.   




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the entry/journey level class within the Management Analyst series. This class is typically used as an entry level professional class in which an incumbent develops and evolves into full journey level work. Incumbents may initially have limited or no directly related work experience. This class is distinguished from the Senior Management Analyst by the performance of the more routine tasks, while the senior level performs more complex duties.     An incumbent in this class is expected to carry out general administrative assignments and works closely with management personnel on all matters which involve policy decisions, interpretation, and complex organizational matters. Initiative is required in conducting thorough research, and in making appropriate and sound recommendations to upper management.   




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the Director or assigned designee. May exercise lead supervision over clerical staff and interns, as assigned.  

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Assists in conducting assigned administrative, fiscal, or operational project activities, preparing and maintaining records, performing research, and analysis as required; prepares and may present reports of findings and recommendations on programs, operating and organizational procedures, and cost comparisons.




2. Performs a variety of duties related to special assignments and projects; leads or participates in committee activities, contributing views and interests of the City and/or department in the execution of responsibilities; may represent the City in relations with the community, local, federal, and state agencies, and professional organizations; makes presentations relating to areas of assignment and attends/participates in community events.




3. Reviews, analyzes, and develops recommendations regarding state and federal legislation; monitors and ensures timely compliance with regulatory matters and reporting requirements; supports communication efforts and communicates with congressional staff for updates and scheduling.




4. Connects with businesses to promote Eastvale and future Downtown Project; participates in monthly business walks with Economic Development Staff; conducts meetings with potential new businesses and tracks new businesses coming to the City as well as citywide vacancies.




5. Manages the CDBG program for the City; tracks progress of active City projects and ensures that correct procedures are followed and executed efficiently; manages the City's annual CDBG application cycle by creating and distributing public notices, accepting applications, and reviewing applications for compliance. 




6. Compiles all data regarding the City's CDBG program and regularly presents information to City Council with a recommendation. Completes annual training course with the County of Riverside on CDBG compliance and procedures.




7. Collects, organizes, analyzes, and interprets routine data relating to operations, including policies, functions, organizational structure, forms and procedures, work output, space and physical planning, types, and effectiveness of equipment; prepares organization and workflow charts; designs and controls the utilization of forms; prepares procedures manuals.




8. Participates in budget preparation, analysis, and administration; reviews departmental budget requests; investigates proposals for new programs, services, equipment, and personnel; conducts routine financial studies and prepares revenue estimates and forecasts; coordinates and processes department invoices.




9. Coordinates with federal, state, and local agencies on the funding of City projects, which includes grant writing and monitoring of grant administrative programs to ensure contract compliance; researches potential grant opportunities and manages awarded grants.




10. Designs, implements, and supports the development of marketing tools, collateral, and displays for department and various programs.




11. Responds to concerns, complaints, and other areas of improvement. Requests additional information as needed. 




12. Provides back up support to other office staff as required. 




13. Performs other duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a associates degree or equivalent in Political Science, Business Administration, Public Administration, or a related field.  Two (2) years of responsible complex office administrative experience involving support of a functional area or equivalent.    

License/Certificate

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:

Concepts, theories, principles, methods and practices of organizational and municipal government administration; cost accounting procedures, practices, and their relationship to budgeting; research and statistical methods; state, federal and local laws and regulations; report preparation and presentation methods; principles and techniques of project management; short and long range organizational planning; grant writing and application procedures; legal, ethical, and professional rules of conduct for public sector employees; computer software applications used to create spreadsheets and databases to analyze data; safe work methods and safety regulations.




Ability to:

Organize work based on established priorities; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound recommendations in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files and records; initiate and compose correspondence as required related to assigned work; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; exercise discretion when dealing with the public and employees on sensitive or confidential matters; understand and follow written and oral instructions; gather pertinent facts, making thorough analyses, and arriving at sound conclusions; report information in clear, complete, and logical form; work independently or as part of a team to organize and complete detailed assignments with minimal direction; participate in conducting routine organizational and procedural studies and prepare comprehensive reports; recommend and implement goals and objectives for providing effective services; properly interpret and make decisions in accordance with laws, regulations, and policies; plan and present clear, concise, and effective presentations to executive management and the public using non-technical language; organize and maintain accurate records of activities and projects; prepare and administer an operating budget; participate in directing various work activities consistent with goals and priorities; assist in evaluating programs and services from an operational and productivity standpoint; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work, including the City Manager, management, staff, other government officials, community groups, and the general public; apply safe work practices; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; operate a computer using word processing, database and spreadsheet software at an advanced level. 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business. 




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the incumbent. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.   The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City may be required.




DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Payroll Coordinator
description:
Job title: Payroll Coordinator

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, performs a wide range of standard, routine, and general financial duties in the maintenance and processing of the City's full-cycle payroll; responsible for accurate and timely timekeeping and payroll distribution activities in accordance with statutory and regulatory requirements and sound financial accounting principles and practices; review and processing of payroll records and documents in a centralized payroll system; and related work as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is a journey level classification, incumbents within this class are responsible for performing technical duties of payroll functions and are expected to demonstrate a complete understanding of all applicable policies, procedures, statutory and legal requirements, and work methods associated with assigned duties.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the Deputy Talent and Special Project Director or designee. May exercise lead supervision over clerical staff and interns, as assigned. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job. 




Participates in the duties relating to the administration of the Talent Attraction & Development and Risk Management functions.
Performs confidential administrative duties; recommends improvements in workflow, procedures, and use of technology and forms.


Processes various department payroll files; investigates and resolves any areas of discrepancy; processes garnishment requests, employment verifications, and other correspondence.
Oversees the collection of new hire paperwork, approval of time and attendance data, processes payroll data, processes tax and other deductions, distributes paystubs, produces reports, provides audit support, and ensures regulatory compliance with federal, state, and local laws.


Processes and calculates payroll, overtime, personnel actions, benefits, retirement plan deductions, tax reporting, leave of absences, leave accruals, payroll deductions, employment verification and other related information.
Analyze complex financial data and prepare, reconcile, and audit payroll and payroll related processing such as benefit vendor payments, quarterly tax filings, W-2 forms and statements, and end of the year reports; ensure CalPERS pension plan reports and payments are accurate, filed, and paid timely; respond to retirement inquiries and discrepancy notices.


Ensure electronic bank and other financial institution automated transmissions are accurate and completed within established deadlines; ; maintains employee confidentiality and ensures all information is entered accurately.
Reviews personnel action forms for accuracy and completeness, makes adjusting calculations based on claims or inaccuracies, and verifies payroll worksheets submitted by employees.


Gathers, compiles, and verifies information on employee files ensuring accurate payroll accounting and management; reviews timecards and gathers information from all timekeeping systems; calculates retroactive pay and confirms all withholdings; Identify payroll requirements when new pay policies, pay systems, and/or benefits are implemented; participate in development, coordination, and implementation of payroll system enhancements as necessary; coordinate maintenance and documentation of personnel and payroll systems.
Communicates, engages, and collaborates with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner to clarify discrepancies, confirm accuracy of timecards submitted, and correct any errors; serves as main point of contact for all payroll and benefit related inquiries and requests; ensures city employees are properly trained on current and new procedures on a regular, on-going basis


Collects employee tax information, deductions, and benefits; ensures all appropriate withholdings and benefits are documented and accurately applied.
Assists with the administration of the City's benefit programs including annual coordination of open enrollment for employees; participates in the coordination of employee benefits/wellness fair and related programs; processes insurance premiums; resolves billing issues.


Receives and responds to telephone calls; responds to complaints, inquiries, and requests for information on policies, procedures, systems, and forms.
Understands, interprets, and applies pertinent policies, procedures, laws, and regulations, stays abreast of changes in laws and regulations within area of responsibility.


Prepares memos, letters, and reports from general instruction or self-initiated; performs data entry into various logs and spreadsheets. Review documents for accuracy, completion, and conformance to established procedures.
Assembles information from a variety of sources; makes routine to complex arithmetic calculations; assists in maintaining data files in spreadsheet and database formats utilizing intermediate to advanced level skills; participates in the maintenance of department records.


Maintains confidentiality of sensitive personnel matters. 
Cross-trains and provides administrative and technical support assistance in other functional areas as required based on workload and for coverage during staff absences.
Establishes positive working relationships with City staff and the public.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.


Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. ?A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with an associates degree or equivalent in business/public administration, accounting, finance or a closely related field and two years of increasingly responsible experience performing payroll or accounting duties. Experience in municipal payroll operations including working with CalPERS is desirable. A Certified Payroll Professional (CPP)  designation is required, incumbent must obtain within (1) year of employment. 

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class C California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Basic principles and practices of payroll administration and personnel processes including record keeping, terminology, and efficiency; compliance, security, and privacy protocols; principles and practices of financial record keeping; benefits, classification & compensation, and employee relations knowledge; advance knowledge of the City's personnel rules; federal and state regulations including but not limited to California Labor Code, Public Employees Retirement Law, and Fair Labor Standards Act; reporting requirements of various state and federal agencies; business letter writing and basic report preparation techniques; principles and procedures of filing and record keeping; statistical and record keeping methods; operations, procedures, policies, and precedents of the City; records management methods and practices; personal computer operation and related software applications including word processing, spreadsheet, database, and presentation software at an intermediate to advanced level of proficiency; customer service and customer relations practices and principles; English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; principles and practices of sound business communications; safe work methods and safety regulations.




Ability to:

Make sound judgement and exhibit strong decision-making and problem-solving skills. Display exceptional interpersonal communication with particular attention to confidentiality. Maintain strong attention to detail. Handle multiple tasks and meet deadlines. Perform a variety of advanced, moderately complex, confidential, and payroll related administrative support work with speed and accuracy; perform responsible administrative work involving the use of independent judgment and personal initiative; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; independently prepare correspondence and memoranda; operate a variety of office equipment including computers and applicable software at an intermediate to advanced level; conduct research and develop findings, conclusions and recommendations; perform assigned duties within established guidelines; establish and maintain effective working relationships with all levels of ? management, employees, the public and others encountered in the course of work; understand and follow oral and written directions; work effectively with a small group or individually; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and other related matters. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events.

title: Community Safety Director
description:
Job title: Community Safety Director

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under direction, the Community Safety Director plans, manages, and oversees the activities and operations of the Community Enhancement & Safety Division (Code Enforcement) and the Building & Safety Division; coordinates assigned activities with other departments, outside agencies and the public; oversees the citywide vehicle and equipment maintenance program; establishes and maintains effective contact with community leaders, developers and groups; and serves as a member of the executive management team. This position provides highly responsible and complex administrative support to the City Manager in areas of expertise, and performs related work as required.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives direction from the City Manager or designee.   Provides general direction over the Community Enhancement and Safety Division and the Building & Safety Division. Exercises direct and indirect supervision over professional, para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Recommend and implement the revision of policies, procedures, and other information pertaining to the administration of City and department business; conduct research, perform complex analysis and review for conformance with City code and other legal requirements. 




2. Implement directives from the City Manager and collaborate to resolve issues.




3. Invest in staff development to enhance their strengths to align with the City’s purpose and values.




4. Direct the preparation of the Community Safety Department Budget; compile materials in preparation of City Manager review; maintain and monitor appropriate budget controls; and ensure compliance with budget parameters and City financial policies. 




5. Receive, investigate, and respond to difficult and sensitive problems and complaints in a professional manner; take necessary corrective action. 




6. Assess and monitor workloads, service delivery methods, administrative and support systems, and internal reporting relationships; identify opportunities for improvement in efficiency and effectiveness.




7. Attends City Council meetings and takes necessary action regarding Council agenda items and City Council Strategic Plan goals. 




8. Prepares comprehensive written reports for department, City Council, or commission action; makes oral presentations to same; prepares annual reports required for State or Federal agencies or other interested parties.




9. Participates in selection, training, counseling, motivating, and maintaining harmony among staff; works with employees on performance issues and staff training; interviews applicants and recommends and approves hiring, termination, discipline, pay or other employee status changes in accordance with established procedures.




10. Contributes to the overall quality of the department's service by developing, reviewing, and implementing policies and procedures to meet legal requirements and City needs; continuously monitors and evaluates the efficiency and effectiveness of service delivery methods and procedures; assesses and monitors the distribution of work, support systems, and internal reporting relationships; identifies opportunities for improvement; directs the implementation of change.




11. Directs, coordinates, and reviews amendments to the building code, and municipal code; provides general plan and code interpretation as needed; provides analysis of recommendations for, and implementation of voter initiatives.




12. Oversees the development of requests for proposals for professional services, including the advertising and bid processes; evaluates proposals and recommends project award; coordinates with legal counsel to determine City needs and requirements for contractual services; negotiates contracts and agreements; administers same after award.




13. Conducts a variety of departmental, organizational, and operational studies and investigations; recommends modifications to programs, policies, and procedures, as appropriate.




14. Participates in and makes presentations to the City Council and a variety of boards and commissions; attends and participates in professional group meetings; stays abreast of new trends and innovations in the field of development services and other services as they relate to the area of assignment.




15. Maintains and directs the maintenance of working and official departmental files.




16. Monitors changes in laws, regulations, and technology that may affect City or departmental operations; implements policy and procedural changes, as required.




17. Prepares, reviews, and presents staff reports, various management and information updates, and reports on special projects as assigned by the City Manager.




18. Responds to difficult and sensitive public inquiries and complaints and assists with resolutions and alternative recommendations. 




19. Plan, manage, and oversee day to day operations of the facilities maintenance program. 




20. Supervises the operation, maintenance, and repair of City facilities, vehicles, and equipment. 




21. Analyzes and develops fleet quality control strategies and management programs to establish continuous fleet management improvement opportunities, standard maintenance and repair methods and time elements, predictive maintenance, life-cycle costing, and vehicle repair/replacement models. 




22. Provides analytical services and develops fleet management programs to enhance fleet performance and capabilities. 




23. Prepares specifications and makes recommendations on the purchase, sale, and disposal of new and used vehicles and equipment.

 

KEY INITIATIVES:




24. Participate in the research, strategic analysis, design, and “groundwork” processes that will lead to the establishment of Eastvale’s Police Station.




25. Participate in the research, strategic analysis, design, and “groundwork” processes that will lead to the establishment of Eastvale’s 3rd Fire Station.




26. Manage and direct the plan check and inspection and permitting of private land development projects in collaboration with the Building Official and Community Development Director.




27. Manage and direct the Community Enhancement & Safety team and projects. 




28. Manage and execute the Community Emergency Response Team (CERT) activities throughout the year. 




29. Participate in the activities of and perform as the City’s liaison to the Neighborhood Watch program. 




30. Establish and manage the Safety Awareness Campaign.




31. Facilitate and participate in the National Night Out program. 




32. Collaborate with RSO and CALFIRE on educational outreach and awareness campaigns to enhance community safety.




33. Establish and manage the Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design (CPTED).




34. Facilitate and manage the RSO/CalFire Explorer Program and other volunteer programs.




35. Establish and manage the See Something, Say Something Program. 




36. Enhance, review, and maintain E-Citizen, the City’s online application reporting system for residents. 




37. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES 

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications: 

Graduation with a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university with major course work in Construction Technology, Architecture, Civil Engineering, Public Administration, or a closely related field. Eight (8) or more years of increasingly responsible experience in managing and coordinating Building & Safety and Community Enhancement & Safety programs or projects, including five (5) years of experience in a supervisory or managerial capacity. A master's degree in Public or Business Administration, or a related field is highly desirable.   

License/Certificate:   

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES 

Knowledge of: 

Administrative principles and practices, including goal setting, program development, implementation, and evaluation and project management. Principles and practices of employee supervision including work planning, assignment, review and evaluation and the training of staff in work procedures. Principles, practices, methods, theories and trends in volunteerism and volunteer management. Administration of police, fire, emergency medical, Community Enhancement & Safety (Code Enforcement), Building & Safety, customer service, and public information programs.  Organizational and management practices as applied to the analysis and evaluation of programs, policies, and operational needs.  Law enforcement theory, principles, and practices and their application to a wide variety of services and programs. Knowledge of public and private project financing methods. Principles and practices of disaster preparedness, response, and recovery. General Operational characteristics of police and fire apparatus and equipment. General knowledge of principles of structural design, engineering mathematics, and architectural plan review and inspection.   General knowledge of hazardous materials mitigation management. Principles and practices of vehicle and equipment maintenance and repair; theories, principles, techniques and equipment used in vehicle and equipment maintenance and repair. Methods and techniques of public relations. Knowledge of principles, practices and procedures of public administration, management, and supervision. Knowledge of laws, regulations, and ordinances affecting departmental operations. Knowledge of state and federal regulations and guidelines for grant application and administration. Knowledge of functions and operation of a public agency.  Pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes, and regulations. Principles and practices of municipal organization, administration, and personnel management. Principles and practices of municipal budget preparation and administration.  

Ability to:

Manage and direct a comprehensive public safety program including law enforcement, crime prevention, fire suppression, fire prevention, emergency medical services, disaster preparedness, code enforcement, and associated programs, services, and operations.  Effectively work with the City Manager, Mayor, City Council, department heads, citizens, and other persons on the telephone and in person; ability to work amicably as a team to accomplish individual and group assignments and goals.  Provide leadership that includes building strong work relationships, empowering and mentoring staff, contributing to the City’s culture of ethics and integrity, and embracing and fostering the City’s Mission, Purpose, and Values Statements. Develop and administer department goals, objectives, and procedures. Analyze problems, identify alternative solutions, resolve project challenges of proposed actions, and implement recommendations in support of goals. Communicate timely, clearly, and concisely, both orally and in writing; prepare clear and concise reports. Interpret and apply related Federal, State, and local policies, laws, and regulations. Identify and strategically respond to community and City Council issues, concerns, and needs. Administer large and complex budgets. Select, supervise, train, and evaluate staff.  

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required. 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.   

Mental Demands: While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work. 

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Community Safety Director.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Lead Building Inspector
description:
Job title: Lead Building Inspector

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, to perform advanced level inspection of field work for compliance of applicable codes and materials used in a variety of residential, commercial, and industrial projects to enforce the regulations regarding building, electrical, mechanical, and plumbing construction; and to perform other related work as required.  

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the advanced level classification within the Building Inspector series. This classification is distinguished from the Building Inspector I/II by the performance of advanced level duties and by the difficulty and complexity of work performed, and the responsibility for the oversight and supervision of staff, as assigned. Incumbents within this classification are fully responsible for the operating procedures and policies of the work unit.  




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

Receives general supervision from the Building Official, or designee.  May exercise general supervision over para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS




Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Inspect structural, plumbing, mechanical, and electrical installations in residential, commercial, and industrial construction for compliance with the appropriate codes, and other applicable regulations and approved plans and specifications. 




2. Conduct periodic inspections of construction work requiring permits to enforce building, zoning, mechanical, plumbing, electrical, energy, green building, fire, housing, accessibility, and related codes and regulations for a wide variety of construction types.




3. Inspect installation of electrical panels, fixtures, outlets, controls, motors, and HVAC equipment; perform electrical surveys of buildings, equipment, and load and provide information pertinent to findings.




4. Inspect swimming pools including structural and electrical installations.




5. Perform more complex field inspection assignments and support other inspector's assignments as needed.




6. Investigate property ownership in cases involving unsafe and illegal conditions.




7. Interpret and apply pertinent Federal, State, and local laws, codes, and regulations.




8. Prepare various inspection and activity reports as required; maintain files and reports regarding inspection and plan check activities and findings.




9. Inspect work sites to ensure that contractors and workers have appropriate licenses and that the proper permits have been obtained for the work being performed.




10. Notify contractors of changes in codes and ordinances. Prepare written reports, issue notices to correct code violations, and issue "stop work" notices.




11. Conducts fire investigations to determine the extent of fire damage and level of hazard to potential occupants in commercial and residential occupancies and determine if habitable.




12. Respond to building related emergencies during business hours and after hours to assess damage for occupancy purposes.




13. Investigate complaints and make inspections of existing buildings to determine if hazardous or illegal conditions exist relating to the structures and their use.




14. Advises on and interprets codes to property owners, contractors, architects, engineers and others; coordinates progress with other City functions and outside agencies.




15. Advises property owners, contractors, architects, engineers, and others on matters relevant to construction methods, materials, types of construction and occupancies.




16. Conducts studies and investigations of complex building operations such as converting the use of a building, condemning a building, or assessing damage to buildings.




17. Delegate daily called inspections; discuss job progress with inspectors and ensure that inspections are performed to City standards.




18. Participate in training of Building division staff on city policies and work procedures and participate in public education activities, seminars, and events.




19. Supervise, train, and evaluate assigned staff.




20. Interacts with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner.




21. Conducts various cross-training with other team members to provide coverage during absences.




22. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.




23. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.




24. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

 

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:




Equivalent to completion of the twelfth grade supplemented by specialized training in building and construction. Three years of increasingly responsible experience in inspection of industrial, commercial, residential construction including at least one year of supervisory experience.  

 

License/Certificate:  

 

Possession of at least one Building Inspector Certificate and two other trade-related Inspector certifications from the International Code Council (ICC), or possession of an Inspector's Certificate as a Combination Inspector from the International Code Council (ICC) is required. CASp Certification is desirable. 

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES                                                       

 

Knowledge of:

 

Knowledge of building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, construction, fire safety, and related codes and regulations adopted by the City, including the International Residential Codes & International Building Codes; methods, materials, techniques and practices employed in plan review and permit processing; organization and functions of the various trades, agencies and organizations involved in the construction process; methods, practices, materials, and safety hazards associated with construction, remodeling, and repair of building structures; possible defects and faults in construction and of standard testing devices and methods as well as corrective measures. Applicable local, state, and federal building regulatory codes and standards; federal and state requirements related to accessibility under the Americans with Disabilities Act. Principles and practices of examining and interpreting advanced construction design plans, specifications, working plans, and methods and practices of conducting building inspections; pertinent rules, related federal and state laws, policies, and codes including the California Building, Plumbing, Mechanical, and Electrical codes; full range of construction terminology, materials and methods used at all stages of construction; advanced mathematical calculations used in plumbing, electrical, mechanical and building trades; safe work methods and safety regulations; principles and practices of customer service and conflict resolution techniques; computer equipment and software applications related to assignment; building tools and materials; methods of building construction; methods and practices of supervisory techniques; methods and techniques of general office procedure; English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation.

 

Ability to:

 

Understand and interpret building and construction plans and specifications; enforce ordinances and regulations firmly, tactfully, and impartially. Apply advanced technical knowledge and follow proper inspection techniques to examine work and materials; interpret, explain and apply applicable laws, codes and regulations pertaining to municipal construction; inspect and analyze standard building construction and identify violations; manage time effectively with high volume while maintaining quality of each inspection; research, interpret and apply advanced technical building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical codes; seek outside technical resources as needed; maintain accurate records, checklists and logs; prepare correspondence and issue notices; stay abreast of changes in building and related codes; drive City vehicles observing legal and defensive driving practices; use initiative and sound independent judgment within established guidelines; deal with irate customers in an effective manner; keep work related records using a computer; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work; and work with various cultural and ethnic groups in a tactful and effective manner.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is frequently climbing, balancing, reaching, sitting, standing, stooping, kneeling, crouching, walking, talking, seeing, hearing, smelling, and utilizing manual dexterity. Occasional lifting and carrying up to 20 pounds. Work is typically performed in both standard office and outdoor environments, with potential exposure to adverse weather conditions. Work is occasionally performed in high and precarious places and near moving mechanical parts. Occasional exposure to the risk of electric shock, fumes, airborne particles, infectious diseases, and criminal suspects. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  




Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee may be required to deal constructively with conflict and in developing effective resolutions. The employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work

 

WORKING CONDITIONS

 

Work periodically in an office environment and frequently in an inspection site environment with exposure to dust, noise, fumes, and inclement weather. Frequent standing and sitting for extended periods; walking on even, uneven, and slippery surfaces; climbing, stooping, squatting, crouching, kneeling, bending, leaning, turning, twisting, reaching, grasping, pushing, and pulling. Lifting, carrying, and pushing objects weighing up to 20 pounds.   Inspect in confined areas.  Near and far vision required for performing inspections. Drive motorized vehicles and work around moving traffic.  

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

 

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Principal Accountant
description:
Job title: Principal Accountant

Job Summary

DEFINITION




Under limited direction, performs all accounting functions supporting the financial functions of the City and its departments.  Oversees work of professional employees involved in a variety of accounting, financial, and accounts payable functions of the City ensuring transparency and accountability.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS




This is the professional class within the Accountant series. This class performs broad accounting functions serving the City as a whole, supporting fiscal responsibility and ensuring accountability. Distinguished from the Senior Accountant by the performance of advanced professional financial functions and supports department leadership and accounting staff. Effectively applies independent judgement in resolving organizational and service delivery problems. Provides policy development and implementation for financial functions.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives general direction from the Finance Director/City Treasurer or designee; exercises close to general supervision over other accounting staff as assigned. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 




Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Develops and recommends departmental goals and objectives; implements approved policies and procedures; participates in the development and implementation of accounting systems, control systems, and reporting procedures.

2. Prepares and analyzes complex financial reports and statements; notifies departments when there are discrepancies; oversees cash balances in all funds and recommends adjustments as appropriate.

3. Performs broad account reconciliations across departments, verifies accuracy of recorded transactions; analyzes daily cash flow.

4. Provides insight, supervision, and support over the work of subordinates making entries, reconciliations, and performing other fiscal recordkeeping work; approves and oversees final accounting and ensures accuracy.

5. Makes complex or difficult adjusting entries affecting several sub-systems of an accounting system; reviews the closing of the City’s financial records at the end of the accounting period; prepares a variety of related reports.

6. Acts as a liaison to other City personnel, auditors, other agencies, and the public regarding accounting activity; participates and provides professional accounting for auditing; responds to and resolves questions and requests for information from the auditor.  

7. Monitors, analyzes, and tracks budgetary expenditures and prepares accounting summaries for use in accounting reports, financial summaries, or reimbursement actions; ensures compliance with approved City budget; forecast budget requirement and evaluates financial impact.

8. Develops, monitors, and maintains records on City assets, construction in progress and infrastructure; records asset additions and deletions, determines asset value, calculates asset records and depreciation schedules, and prepares expenditures analyses on ongoing Capital Improvement Projects.

9. Utilizes various computer applications and software packages; enters and maintains data; generates reports from a database or network system; creates documents using word processing software.

10. Participates in the selection of subordinate staff; provides or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies.

11. Approves purchase orders and check requests; receives invoices, checks for accuracy and processes for payment.

12. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES




Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent in Finance, Business Administration, Public Administration, Accounting, or a closely related field, and five (5) years of increasingly responsible professional level accounting work, including two (2) year of supervisory experience.  Governmental accounting experience is highly desirable. 




License/Certificate

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




Certified Professional Accountant.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:

Advanced principles and practices of accounting and auditing, including governmental accounting and budgeting; pertinent Federal, State, and local laws, codes and regulations related to accounting and budgeting practices; advanced research methods involving the use of department data processing systems/applications related to accounting and budgeting procedures and practices; departmental administrative policies; advanced office practices and procedures; principles and practices of sound business communications; correct English usage, including spelling, grammar and punctuation; word processing and spreadsheet software at an advanced level; record keeping, filing, and accounting procedures; and report preparation and presentation methods; safe work methods and safety regulations.




Ability to:

Prepare and present detailed reports; analyze and interpret data; interpret, understand, explain, and apply related laws, regulations, policies, and procedures; supervise and coordinate the work of subordinate staff as assigned; operate a computer using a variety of software programs at an advanced level; organize, set priorities and exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound decisions in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files; compose routine correspondence from brief instructions; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; understand and follow written and oral instructions; prepare clear, accurate and concise records and reports; use tact and discretion in dealing with sensitive situations, concerned people and customers; and establish and maintain effective working relationships with the City Manager, City Council, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safety operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS




Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  




Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS




The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business. 




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the incumbent.   These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  A generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City may be required.
