title: Assistant City Clerk
description:
Job title: Assistant City Clerk

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, assists the City Clerk/Communications Director (or City Manager) in managing the operations of the City Clerk's Office; organizes and supervises the work of staff; develops, coordinates and administers the City's records management program; serves as acting City Clerk/Communication Director in the City Clerk/Communication Director's absence; and performs related duties as required.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Assistant City Clerk reports directly to the City Clerk/Communications Director (or City Manager, in the absence of a City Clerk/Communications Director), who directs and oversees department goals, programs, and budgeting, as well as Council and departmental relations, legislative initiatives, and compliance with City codes, and elections and compliance matters. The Assistant City Clerk is distinguished from other staff positions in the City Clerk's Office given its broader administrative and supervisory responsibilities, and more specialized knowledge of Fair Political Practices Compliance standards, records management practices and elections procedures.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the City Clerk/Communications Director or City Manager; may supervise other technical and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job. 
Acts on behalf of the City Clerk/Communications Director and manages the operations of the City Clerk's Office in the absence of the City Clerk/Communications Director.
Assists in establishing and implementing departmental goals, programs, policies, and administrative procedures; makes recommendations for budget allocations.
Selects, trains, organizes, supervises, and evaluates the work of assigned departmental staff; checks and proofreads work to ensure compliance with legal and work standards.
Assists in the preparation, administration, and monitoring of assigned department budget; compiles annual department budget requests; monitors approved department budget accounts.
Administers the compilation of the City Council/Commission agendas on behalf of the City Clerk/Communications Director through the City's agenda management software; examines agenda submittals to ensure compliance with Brown Act and suggests revisions; ensures agenda packets are distributed to the City Council, City Attorney, Commissioners, Committee members, City Manager, Directors, City departments and general public in a complete and timely manner.
Compiles original documents, transmittal letters, affidavits and exhibits from City Council Meeting agenda items; prepares meeting minutes; processes actions resulting from meetings.
Oversees and participates in the drafting of ordinances and resolutions; ensures proper distribution and recording of ordinances, resolutions, agreements, and deeds.
Assists the City Clerk/Communications Director in election related matters; assists in the preparation of the candidate's manual; examines and verifies nomination papers from candidates; ensures the proper filing of forms required by candidates.
Develops and maintains up-to-date procedures for filing Statement of Economic Interest and campaign financing statements and reporting; manages the City's Netfile database of Form 700 filers; notifies affected parties of FPPC requirements and deadlines; answers questions regarding filing issues from City management, candidates, the media and the public; indexes, reviews, and verifies filing to ensure they are complete and in compliance with specified requirements.
Researches Government Code and monitors document handling practices by Recorder's Office for compliance with state requirements governing documents that are to be provided to requesting parties without an imposed processing fee.
Records documents with the County Recorder in conjunction with the Public Works Division; oversees the release of bonds and evaluates information for completeness and accuracy.
Assists with the supervision of the City's record archiving, retention, and destruction program; receives, assigns, and processes public records requests.
Receives subpoenas, summons, claims and requests for records; tracks disposition and ensures timely resolution; serves as Custodian of Records.
Researches and prepares reports for review by the City Clerk/Communications Director and City Council action; conducts analyses, completes surveys, composes correspondence, and prepares and maintains administrative procedures, committee rosters, logs, and listings.
Accepts bids and requests for proposals and administers bidding processes.
Keyboards and proofreads a wide variety of reports, letters, memoranda, correspondence and statistical charts from rough draft, verbal instruction, or transcribing machine; independently composes correspondence related to assigned area of responsibility.
Serves on various committees and attends meetings as assigned.
Utilizes various City Clerk related computer applications such as Laserfiche, Peak Agenda Management, Granicus Live Manager, Netfile, and software packages; enters and maintains data; generates reports from a database or network system; creates documents using word processing software.
Prepares and revises various operating procedures, rules and regulations as directed; develops and revises office forms and report format.
Prepares purchase orders and check requests; receives invoices, checks for accuracy and processes for payment.
Acts as a certified Notary Public for City business matters.
Assists in managing the City's Passport Services Program and acts as a Passport Acceptance Agent.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:

Equivalent to a Bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university with major course work in Business Administration, Public Administration, or a related field; and a minimum of three years of responsible public agency administrative experience that involves maintaining complex files and records, and providing varied and complex technical assistance regarding policies, procedures and regulations to staff and the public, and the taking and editing minutes of public meetings is required, within a City Clerk's office.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

Possession of, or ability to obtain, a valid certificate as a Notary Public issued by the State of California.

Possession of a certification as a Certified Municipal Clerk or Master Municipal Clerk designation, or attainment within 18 months of appointment.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Knowledge of operations, services and activities of a municipality including the policies, procedures and related to the functions and statutory obligations of the City Clerk's Office, including requirements governing the actions of an elected City Council; organization, functions, procedures and rules of the Council and Council Committees; Fair Political Practices Commission (FPPC) Act and compliance standards; Brown Act and rules and procedures governing the notice and conduct of public hearings; Public Records Act and requirements related to release of public information; Maddy Act compliance related to election practices, terms and obligations; City Municipal Code and matters which come before the Council and its Committees; supervisory principles and techniques; basic principles and practices of budget preparation and administration; standard office administrative practices and procedures; records management software programs; proper English grammar, punctuation, spelling and usage; operation of a personal computer and other standard office equipment; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Perform responsible and difficult administrative and secretarial support duties involving the use of independent judgment and personal initiative; interpret, and apply administrative and departmental policies and procedures; provide information and organize material in compliance with applicable laws and regulations; effectively represent the City to outside individuals and agencies to accomplish the goals and objectives of the City Clerk's department; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely and appropriately to inquiries from the public or other agencies on issues in area of responsibility; keyboard at a speed necessary for successful job completion; maintain confidentiality of information and exercise tact and diplomacy in interpersonal dealings which are difficult, highly sensitive and confidential; work independently in the absence of supervision; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; operate a computer using word processing and spreadsheet software; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; and establish and maintain effective working relationships with the City Manager, City officials, Board and Commission members, contractors, consultants, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus; travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Assistant City Clerk. These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

title: Assistant Finance Director
description:
Job title: Assistant Finance Director

Job Summary

DEFINITION 

Under direction, to perform a variety of responsible and professional accounting and fiscal activities in order to maintain the integrity of the City's finances; to advise the Finance Director and City Manager related to current and projected budget status; and to perform related duties as required.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

Receives direction from the Finance Director; may supervise other technical and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Acts as primary support to the Finance Director and City Manager in the administration of the City's financial policies and procedures.

2. Maintains the integrity of all City revenues including periodic reviews of revenues, as well as direct contact with other City departments and government agencies.

3. Administers or assists in the administration of capital assets projects.

4. Assists in the administration of Finance Department personnel matters.

5. Prepares fiscal estimates and reports.

6. Ensures compliance with the City's accounting procedures, including audits and follow up to ensure proper compliance City-wide.

7. Establishes collection procedures to ensure full and current collections.

8. Administers the City's business registration and rental registration programs.

9. Oversees the administration of payroll.

10. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

11. Performs related duties as assigned

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in Finance, Accounting or a closely related field. A minimum of five years of progressively responsible experience in governmental finance, accounting, grants administration, and auditing functions in a public agency, at the level of a Senior Accountant or above. A Master's degree is highly desirable.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

Knowledge of operations, services and activities of a municipality including the policies and procedures related to governmental accounting and finance; general laws and administrative policies governing municipal financial practices and procedures; applicable ordinances and regulations governing financial operations of the City; business letter writing and basic report preparation techniques; modern office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and related software applications such as word processing, spread sheets and databases; office management principles, methods and procedures, including principles and procedures of financial record keeping; the organization and operations of the City and of outside agencies in order to perform necessary assigned responsibilities; advanced principles and practices of budget preparation and administration; advanced principles and practices of auditing; English usage, spelling, grammar and punctuation; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Perform responsible and difficult administrative and financial management and recordkeeping involving the use of independent judgment and personal initiative; develop and apply administrative and departmental policies and procedures; provide information and organize material in compliance with applicable laws and regulations; effectively represent the City to outside individuals and agencies to accomplish the goals and objectives of the Finance department; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely and appropriately to inquiries from the public or other agencies on issues in area of responsibility; maintain confidentiality of information and exercise tact and diplomacy in interpersonal dealings which are difficult, highly sensitive and confidential; work independently in the absence of supervision; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; operate a computer using word processing, spreadsheet, and financial software at a high level of competency and proficiency; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City Manager, City officials, Board and Commission members, contractors, consultants, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Possession of a designation as a Certified Public Accountant is highly desirable.

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS 

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required in order to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Senior Administrative Analyst. These hours may include, but are not limited to: weekends, evenings and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale Employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Human Resources & Risk Management Analyst
description:
Job title: Human Resources & Risk Management Analyst

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under general supervision, to perform professional human resources work in a variety of program areas including recruitment and selection; classification, compensation, and benefits; training; labor relations; risk management; safety; and special programs; to assist with the implementation of departmental, operational, and City-wide programs and policies; and to perform related work as assigned.  

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS




The Human Resources/ Risk Management Analyst is a professional level classification, it is the entry/journey level class within the Human Resources/ Risk Management Analyst series and is typically used as an entry level professional class in which an incumbent develops and evolves into full journey level work. An incumbent in this class is expected to carry out complex projects requiring independent analysis and makes recommendations related to matters of significance to the organization and within the City’s Human Resources and Risk Management functions; works closely with management personnel on all matters which involve policy decisions, interpretation, and complex organizational matters. This class is distinguished from the Human Resources Specialist by the increased difficulty and complexity of work assignments, and for performing work involving research, analysis, and the preparation of sound recommendations. It is distinguished from the Human Resources/ Risk Management Manager by the latter’s greater responsibility for a major functional area and for the completion of highly complex assignments.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives general supervision from the Human Resources/Risk Manager, and/or designee; may exercise general supervision over para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

1. Assists in establishing and implementing departmental goals, programs, policies, and administrative procedures; makes recommendations for budget allocations.

2. Selects, trains, organizes, supervises, and evaluates the work of assigned departmental staff; checks and proofreads work to ensure compliance with legal and work standards.

3. Assists in the preparation, administration, and monitoring of assigned budget; compiles annual budget requests; monitors approved budget accounts.

4. Prepares purchase orders and check requests; receives invoices, checks for accuracy and processes for payment.

5. Plans and implements employee recruitment and selection for assigned job classes to attract top talent. Develops all related announcement materials. Screens applications for qualifications. Ensures that all phases of recruitment and selection comply with applicable federal, state, and local laws, regulations, and guidelines.

6. Supervises and participates in the administration of examinations, scoring of examinations, and the establishment of eligibility lists.

7. Conducts reference checks, background checks; coordinates post-offer physical exams; prepares conditional and final offer letters; conducts on-boarding sessions and new employee orientation sessions.   

8. Conducts and implements classification, reclassification, and organizational studies; researches, analyzes, audits, and participates in the maintenance of the City’s classification plans; conducts job classification analysis; prepares or revises class specifications; recommends salary range placements and adjustments; develops classification recommendations and reports.

9. Meets with agency and departmental representatives to review personnel needs and concerns; discusses position requirements and employee development goals.

10. Assists in the administration of the City’s employee benefits program; including analyzing a variety of benefits programs and making recommendations for improvements; develops and implements new benefits programs; answers inquiries relating to various City benefits.

11. Coordinates new hire benefits information; reviews, verifies, prepares, processes, and ensures timely submission of health enrollment forms, medical and dental forms, disability claims, and other related forms and documents.

12. Administers leave management programs for the City including various protected state and federal leave of absence laws; provides required notices, monitors time off, and conducts interactive processes in accordance with the Americans’ with Disabilities Act (ADA), as required.  Ensures City-wide consistency of application; prepares, reviews, approves, and monitors requests for leave.

13. Coordinates the annual benefit open enrollment process.

14. Coordinates Citywide training programs with consultants and/or in-house instructors; prepares and/or delivers orientation programs, training programs, and other related workshops; tracks training programs and activities.

15. Develops, coordinates, and administers an effective safety program and maintains required records.

16. Administers the City’s workers’ compensation program; receives and processes claims; serves as the liaison with injured workers, City staff, attorneys, medical providers, and investigators in the management of injured worker claims; and works closely with injured employees, managers and supervisors regarding return to work issues. 

17. Meets with employees and employee groups to discuss grievances, complaints, and problems, and resolves them in cooperation with line management and employee groups consistent with City policy.

18. Assists with employee relations issues; provides information and assistance to departmental personnel regarding employee evaluations, disciplinary actions, and other employee relations issues; attends and participates in pre-disciplinary meetings; prepares disciplinary documents.

19. Determines and assists in the development of appropriate written, oral, and/or performance evaluation programs.

20. Conducts investigations of grievances, discrimination complaints, and misconduct/performance issues; makes recommendations for appropriate action; prepares required documentation and responses.

21. Works with departments to resolve human resource problems, analyze staffing needs, interpret human resources policies and procedures; recommends effective courses of action.

22. Administers HRIS systems; writes queries and prepares reports; analyzes current processes and recommends improvements.

23. Maintains payroll information by collecting, calculating, and entering data; updates payroll records by entering changes in exemptions, insurance coverage, and savings deductions; resolves payroll discrepancies by collecting and analyzing information; provides payroll information by answering questions and requests; maintains payroll operations by following policies and procedures; reports needed changes.

24. Assists in developing human resources’ policies and procedures; interprets and explains policies and procedures to applicants, employees, and departmental staff.

25. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

26. Participates in cross-training and provides back up to other staff; assists other office personnel in performing related administrative support functions.

27. Establishes positive working relationships with City staff and the public.

28. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.

29. Performs other duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES 

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:  

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in business administration, public administration, human resources, risk management, or a closely related field.  Three years of increasingly responsible experience in human resources, employee benefits, or risk management.  A master’s degree or graduate level course work in a closely related field is highly desirable. 

License/Certificate Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES 

Knowledge of:

Principles and practices of human resources administration including recruitment, testing and selection, classification and job analysis, compensation and benefits analysis and administration, employee and labor relations principles, and payroll administration; principles and practices of human resources information systems; concepts, theories, principles, methods and practices of organizational and municipal government administration; cost accounting procedures, practices, and their relationship to budgeting; research and statistical methods; state, federal and local laws and regulations; report preparation and presentation methods; principles and techniques of project management; legal, ethical, and professional rules of conduct for public sector employees; computer software applications used to create spreadsheets and databases to analyze data; safe work methods and safety regulations; supervisory principles and practices.  

Ability to:

Analyze and evaluate human resources program needs and requirements; organize, set priorities and exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound decisions in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files and records; initiate and compose correspondence as required related to assigned work; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; exercise discretion when dealing with the public and employees on sensitive or confidential matters; understand and follow written and oral instructions; gather pertinent facts, make thorough analyses, and arrive at sound conclusions; report information in clear, complete, and logical form; work independently or as part of a team to organize and complete detailed assignments with minimal direction; conduct organizational and procedural studies and prepare comprehensive reports; recommend and implement goals and objectives for providing effective services; properly interpret and make decisions in accordance with laws, regulations, and policies; organize and maintain accurate records of activities and projects; direct various work activities consistent with goals and priorities; evaluate programs and services from an operational and productivity standpoint; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work, apply safe work practices; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; operate a computer using word processing, database and spreadsheet software at an advanced level. 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required. 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work. 

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Human Resources/Risk Management Analyst. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. Generally, the environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Streets Maintenance Worker
description:
Job title: Streets Maintenance Worker

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under direct supervision, performs skilled work in the construction, maintenance, and repair of streets, curbs, gutters, storm drains, streetlights, and related public works infrastructure; operates a variety of light and medium-duty motorized maintenance and construction equipment; and performs related duties as assigned.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the entry level classification within the Street Maintenance Worker series. This classification is distinguished from the Senior Street Maintenance Worker by the latter’s performance of the more complex maintenance and skilled work.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives direction from the Public Works Superintendent or designee.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Performs construction and maintenance work on city owned properties including streets, sidewalks, storm water and drainage systems, street sweeping, graffiti abatement, and traffic signage and striping, traffic control systems, traffic signal systems, fiber systems, electrical systems, and other related duties.

2. Breaks and removes pavements; digs, shovels, hauls, and loads soils, sand, gravel, cement, asphalt mixes and other materials, tools, and equipment; cleans up work sites upon completion of job.

3. Operates air compressor and pneumatic air tools, including breaking guns and concrete saws; uses hand tools including shovels, picks, brooms, wheelbarrows, rakes and rollers, and a variety of small hand tools for a variety of trades.

4. Drives vehicles to work sites and sets up and removes barricades to protect crews from street traffic including lane closures and DUI checkpoints; directs traffic in roadways to protect crews.

5. Removes and installs street lighting poles and fixtures; removes and/or paints over graffiti on private and public property; assists in the fabrication, assembly, and installation of traffic signs.

6. Performs storm drain maintenance, removes, and replaces drains; cleans and removes debris from drains.

7. Organizes and maintains assigned equipment and tools; inspects, cleans and performs preventative maintenance to ensure operability and reliability of equipment and tools.

8. Reviews equipment and materials required for daily maintenance and work projects; initiates request for or purchases approved materials and supplies.

9. Prepares and/or maintains activity records, logs, work orders, material requests, reports and/or technical documentation for equipment or building systems.

10. Assist with recommending equipment, materials, staffing, safety needs, devices, and/or equipment for assigned operation, maintenance, and improvement projects.

11. Identify potential hazards and safety issues related to city facilities and landscape areas.

12. Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.

13. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

14. Provides back-up support to other maintenance staff as required.

15. Performs other public works related duties as assigned

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:
Equivalent to a High School Diploma or GED and two years of street maintenance or construction experience.

License/Certificate:
Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.
Possession of, or ability to obtain, a valid Class A or B California Driver's License may be required, after appointment, depending on assignment.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:
Safety equipment and work practices related to the work, including excavation, trenching/shoring, and confined space entry; proper operation and maintenance of hand and power tools, vehicles and light and heavy equipment; basic methods, materials, tools and equipment used in the construction, installation, maintenance and repair of streets, water, sewer and storm drainage lines, mains and services; basic methods for removal, replacement, and application of road surfacing materials; basic methods of locating underground utility services and related notification requirements; basic principles and practices of water/wastewater systems and equipment; basic principles and practices of carpentry work; basic knowledge of plumbing and construction techniques; basic knowledge of work zone safety such as OSHA, Heat Awareness, First Aid, and CPR; basic mathematical computations; techniques for dealing effectively with those contacted in the course of work, both in person and on the telephone.

Ability to:
Perform construction, maintenance and repair work on streets, water distribution and wastewater collection systems, infrastructure and equipment; operate and maintain tools, vehicles, and equipment used in the construction, maintenance, repair, installation and monitoring of City streets and utilities systems and infrastructure; set up and operate traffic area construction zones, including cones, barricades and flagging; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; read, understand and interpret written instructions; follow oral and written instructions; physically perform frequent, heavy manual labor using safe work practices; operate computer devices using standard and customized software applications appropriate to assigned tasks; maintain effective and cooperative working relationships with City staff, departments, outside agencies, commercial vendors, and the general public.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

May be required to be on-call and to work various shifts or emergencies on evenings, weekends, and holidays.
Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.
Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:
While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, climb, stoop, kneel, bend, lean, turn, twist, reach, grasp, push, and pull on even, uneven and slippery surfaces and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office and field equipment; and reach with hands and arms. Lift, carry, and push objects weighing up to 100 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:
While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

Work is performed in confined spaces and outdoor construction and maintenance environment with moderate to high noise levels, hot and cold temperatures, inclement weather conditions, road hazards, loud noise levels, vibration, confining workspace, chemicals, mechanical and/or electrical hazards, and hazardous physical substances and fumes. Employees use power and noise producing equipment, and often work with constant interruptions. Employees may interact with upset staff and/or public and private representatives in interpreting and enforcing departmental policies and procedures.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Code Enforcement Manager
description:
Job title: Code Enforcement Manager

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under direction of the Community Safety Director or designee, to lead and manage; supervise, assign, review, and participate in the operations and activities of the City’s Code Enforcement Team, Neighborhood Watch Program, Community Emergency Response Team (CERT) and Emergency Services programs with a growth mindset including implementing City activities and events related to setting and maintaining effective contact with community leaders and groups; provides supervision and sustainability for community programs; facilitates community meetings; community connector; community relations; community liaison; community ambassador; ensures compliance with applicable ordinances, codes, and regulations related to zoning, land use, building codes, health and safety, and other matters of public concern; administers the Citywide vehicle and equipment maintenance program to ensure work quality adherence to established policies and procedures; to perform the more technical and complex tasks relative to assigned area of responsibility; and to perform other related duties as required.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives direction from the Community Safety Director or designee.  Provides general direction over the Code Enforcement team, Emergency Services team and Neighborhood Watch team.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.  Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Plans and directs the City-wide Neighborhood Watch and Services Program, assumes responsibility in the development and management of the program, and in identifying community resources. 

2. Empowers and engages Neighborhood Watch Program block captains via regular contact, influence, motivation and inspiration.

3. Develops and sustains public and private partnerships within the community; participates in the evaluation and maintains effectiveness in serving the public; monitors program compliance. Connects with community leaders, organizations, non-profits and faith based community as an ambassador and champion of the City. 

4. Establishes relationships and works effectively with organized community groups and agencies for the promotion and coordination of programs; serves as the City’s representative with Police personnel, School District officials; Parks and Recreation officials, and Solid Waste franchise representatives; attends meetings and provides staff support to the community and the City Council including the preparation and presentation of staff reports. 

5. Plans, directs, coordinates and reviews the work plan for community enhancement staff; assigns work activities, projects and programs; reviews and evaluates work products, methods and procedures; meets with staff to identify and resolve problems with a balance of both efficiency and effectiveness. 

6. Reviews and edits work of staff, including letters, reports, logs, evaluations, and other written correspondence. 

7. Oversees and provides direction in the management and enforcement of all Community Enhancement programs. 

8. Selects, trains, motivates, inspires, influences and evaluates Community Enhancement & Safety personnel; provides or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies; implements discipline and termination procedures.

9. Prepares and manages the Community Enhancement & Safety program budget, including forecasting funds needed for staffing, equipment, materials, and supplies; monitors and approves expenditures, and implements adjustments. 

10. Serves as the City’s facilitator to interpret municipal code violations with representation from legal, Police, and Planning; determine public nuisances, and issue civil fines when administrative remedies are employed to gain code and permit compliance.

11. Manages the development of goals and objectives for programs; recommends and administers policies and procedures. 

12. Formulates discretionary judgments and determinations for complex and/or disputed cases.

13. Identifies opportunities for improving service delivery methods and procedures; recommends, within departmental policy, appropriate services and staffing levels. 

14. Responds to and handles difficult compliance cases regarding municipal code provisions and explains City regulations to City officials and the public relating to building, zoning, land use, planning and related issues.

15. Serves as a liaison for the Community Enhancement & Safety Team with other divisions, departments, and outside agencies.

16. Conducts a variety of organizational studies, investigations, and operational studies as necessary.

17. Serves as staff on a variety of boards, commissions and committees; prepares and presents staff reports and other necessary correspondence; responds to council, staff, media and the public as appropriate. 

18. Attends and participates in professional group meetings; stays abreast of relevant issues and changes to codes, ordinances, laws and regulations.

19. Plan, manage, and oversee day to day operations of the facilities maintenance program. 

20. Supervises the operation, maintenance, and repair of City facilities, vehicles, and equipment. 

21. Analyzes and develops fleet quality control strategies and management programs to establish continuous fleet management improvement opportunities, standard maintenance and repair methods and time elements, predictive maintenance, life-cycle costing, and vehicle repair/replacement models. 

22. Provides analytical services and develops fleet management programs to enhance fleet performance and capabilities. 

23. Prepares specifications and makes recommendations on the purchase, sale, and disposal of new and used vehicles and equipment.

24. Responds to and resolves difficult and sensitive citizen inquiries and complaints.

25. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

26. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.

27. Oversees and participates in assigned special projects.

28. Performs other related duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:

A minimum of five years of increasingly responsible community engagement, community ambassador, community champion, community liaison, community enhancement and safety, environmental planning, and municipal code compliance experience including a minimum of two years of administrative and supervisory responsibility, and the equivalent to graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree (120 semester units) in a related field. Two additional years of qualifying experience may substitute for two years of the required education. A master's degree in Public Administration, Leadership or a related field is desirable.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Operational characteristics, services and activities of a code enforcement program; principles and practices of code enforcement including identification and investigation techniques; methods and techniques of code enforcement; Legal aspects of code administration; principles of municipal budget preparation and administration; methods and techniques of research, business letter writing and report preparation; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications; principles of management, training and performance evaluation; pertinent federal, state and local laws, codes and regulations;

principles and practices of vehicle and equipment maintenance and repair; theories, principles, techniques and equipment used in vehicle and equipment maintenance and repair. 



Ability to:

Oversee and participate in the management of a comprehensive municipal code and permit compliance program; supervise, direct and coordinate the work of lower level staff; select, supervise, train and evaluate staff; oversee and participate in the management of a comprehensive municipal code and permit compliance program; participate in the management of a comprehensive enforcement program; participate in the development and administration of section goals, objectives and procedures; interpret and explain City code enforcement policies and procedures; operate code enforcement equipment including City vehicle; operate office equipment including computers and supporting software applications; conduct site inspections for code violations; prepare clear and concise reports; manage sensitive and confidential issues; prioritize tasks and meet deadlines; respond to requests and inquiries from the general public and resolve code related issues; analyze problems, identify alternative solutions, project consequences of proposed actions and implement recommendations in support of goals, research, analyze and evaluate new service delivery methods and techniques; interpret and apply federal, state and local policies, laws and regulations; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work.

Special Requirements

Possession of a P.C. 832 Peace Officer's Standard and Training (POST) Certificate is required at the time of employment.

Possession of any combination of certifications are highly desirable including those from the California Association of Code Enforcement (CACEO), International Code Council (ICC), Association of Code Enforcement (AACE) or certification as a Zoning Enforcement Officer, and/or Property Maintenance and Housing Inspector.

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee may be required to deal constructively with conflict and in developing effective resolutions. The employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Community Enhancement & Safety Manager. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER
