Oversees Requests for Qualifications (RFQ) and Requests for Proposals (RFP) for the solicitation, evaluation and selection of engineering consultants; negotiates fees and determines the scope of work for complex engineering services contracts; prepares, reviews and analyzes bid documents; award construction contracts; schedules and attends pre-construction meetings; oversees and supervises staff in the administration and management of professional engineering contracts. 
Attends public hearings, committee meetings, and workshops and acts as a liaison between staff, developers, contractors, consultants, and the public in matters involving engineering, planning, construction, cost updates, reimbursement agreements, and capital improvements design.
Monitors and keeps informed of current trends in the field of municipal engineering including legislation, court rulings and professional practices and techniques; evaluates their impact and makes recommendations to the City Engineer regarding policy and procedural modifications accordingly.
Manages the preparation of a variety of studies and reports relating to current and long-range City capital improvement needs and fixed assets; plans and directs project management activities for a variety of capital improvement and maintenance projects, including the preparation of plans, specifications, designs; estimates, and schedules; establishes conditions of approval; coordinates inspections and project monitoring programs.
Gives presentations to the City Council, boards, commissions, civic groups, and the public as needed and assigned.
Represents the City, Community Development Department, and/or Engineering Division while providing support to a variety of City commissions, neighboring jurisdictions, boards and committees, and various City Council sub-committees.
 Assists in development of the Division's annual budget and work programs; allocates staff and resources among work program priorities.
Reviews and approves subdivision maps, grading and erosion control plans, and developer public improvement plans; issues encroachment permits for construction work within the City's public right-of-way; administers the National Flood Insurance program, and Local Improvement, Community Facilities and Landscape Maintenance Districts; maintains utility plans showing water, sewer, recycled water, and storm drain facilities, provides public access for all City drawings, deeds, maps assessment district diagrams, aerial photos, and utility drawings, and performs Geographical Information Systems (GIS) mapping updates and maintenance. 
Perform civil engineering design on land development projects including site design, site grading, earthwork balance, drainage, utilities, sanitary collection and water distribution systems, storm water management, erosion, and sediment control designs/plans. 
Plan for and review construction inspection activities for commercial and residential development and public facilities.  
Oversee the development, processing and review of final maps and pertinent infrastructure improvement plans; recommend plans for approval signatures to the City Council; review construction cost estimates for the development of fees and bond amounts.  
Review and approve construction permit applications submitted by developers or contractors; review and approve major design and/or construction changes.  
Inspect the more complex development projects; ensure quality control and compliance with applicable codes and regulations; prepare detailed reports on inspection and construction activities.  
Attend and participate in construction and design meetings; confer with developers, contractors, surveyors, and other engineers; provide information regarding City development standards and ordinances. 
Oversees the management of Land Development specialized programs and functions, and persons/consultants performing services and functions. 
Reviews, interprets, and recommends appropriate compliance programs related to NPDES regulations. 
Establishes performance requirements and personnel development targets; monitors and evaluates the quantity and quality of staff performance. Supervises subordinate supervisors and staff; provides training and instruction; takes disciplinary action to address performance deficiencies in accordance with the City's Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual; and conducts annual progress reviews.  
Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.
Invests in reporting staff to develop their strengths and align with the City's purpose and values. 
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner. 
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Performs other related duties as assigned.



Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree in Civil Engineering and registration in California as a Professional Engineer; and four or more years of responsible professional civil engineering experience, including experience with public works projects and three years of supervisory experience; or an equivalent combination of training and experience. A master's degree in a field related to Civil Engineering is desirable. 

License/Certificate:   Possession of a valid Class C California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record. Registration as a Professional Civil Engineer (P.E.) with the California State Board of Registration for Civil and Professional Engineers required. Active membership and/or participation in professional organization such as American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Public Works Association (APWA), Professional Traffic Operations Engineer (PTOE) and/or related groups is highly desirable.    

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES 

Knowledge of:

Modern principles, procedures, practices and standards of municipal civil engineering; land development, surveying methods and techniques; municipal engineering laws, ordinances, codes, specifications and plans; engineering project inspection methods; water and wastewater systems/plants; Subdivision Map Act, California Environmental Quality Act, and Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors Act; Public Contract Code, Government Code, Vehicle Code, Public Utilities Code, Streets and Highways Code; approaches and problem-solving techniques used in construction engineering and inspection and compliance processes; modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding engineering; principles and practices of contract administration; traffic engineering fundamentals and use of standard equipment used in the engineering profession; basic principles of mathematics; control surveys for horizontal and vertical datums necessary for use by private engineers; principles and practices of management, organization, budget practices, administrative procedures and fiscal management; methods and techniques of supervision, training and motivation; methods and techniques of scheduling work assignments; standard office procedures; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes, and regulations; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications such as word processing, spreadsheets, and databases; proper English, spelling and grammar; methods and techniques for report preparation and writing; occupational hazards and standard safety practices.

Ability to:

Manage, oversee, review, and perform complex engineering computations; check, design and supervise the preparation of engineering plans and studies; plan, organize, direct and evaluate the effectiveness of assigned program activities; exercise supervisory control over complex professional and technical tasks; perform the full range of professional civil engineering tasks; prepare and administer a budget; safely and effectively operate engineering tools and equipment; interpret, explain and apply applicable laws, codes and regulations pertaining to municipal public works design and construction; analyze and evaluate design drawings and specifications; prepare and manage project budgets; negotiate with citizens, property owners, contractors and other agencies; oversee the maintenance of detailed project management records and documentation; make adjustments to standard operating procedures to improve effectiveness and comply with regulatory changes as appropriate; read, interpret and record data accurately; organize, prioritize and follow-up on work assignments; work independently and as part of a team; make sound decisions within established guidelines; analyze complex issues, develop, and implement an appropriate response; follow written and oral directions; promote and observe safety principles and work in a safe manner; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective and collaborative working relationships with City personnel and the public; operate an office computer and a variety of word processing and software applications; safely and effectively operate surveying instruments. Skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.




Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.   Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work. 

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment and occasionally works in a construction site and field environment. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Employees may occasionally work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or electrical hazards. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, City Commission meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Senior Engineer. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Senior Code Enforcement Officer
description:
Job title: Senior Code Enforcement Officer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under direction, performs complex inspection and investigations and the more complex office and field duties associated with the interpretation, application and enforcement of municipal and other related codes dealing with zoning, land use, building, housing, dangerous buildings, inoperable vehicles, noise, litter, sanitation, weeds and other public nuisance code provisions. 




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Senior Code Enforcement Officer is the advanced level classification in the Code Enforcement job series. It differs from the Code Enforcement Officer position in that the incumbent performs more complex and challenging enforcement activities. Incumbent does not directly supervise but may provide lead level support and direction to lower-level staff and ensures all activities are completed within established policy and protocol.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Code Enforcement Manager, or designee. Supports, oversees, and organizes Code Enforcement and clerical personnel as assigned.  

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Serves as a lead to Code Enforcement staff; assigns, monitors, and oversees work, providing direction, monitoring the quality of case management files, and performing code compliance activities.

2. Conducts and performs inspections and re-inspections of single-family rental properties; conducts site visits, inspects properties, inputs results of inspections into applicable databases, generates notice letters to owners regarding violations, and verifies completion and abatement of violations.

3. Performs proactive and complaint-generated inspections of various neighborhoods and commercial locations, enforcing and ensuring compliance with applicable State laws, City and County land use, zoning, signs, nuisance abatement, parking violations, housing, dangerous building abatement, and other applicable issues; secures vacant structures and provides temporary repair work on downed fences.

4. Performs a variety of administrative activities in support of departmental operations; reviews and responds to a variety of correspondence and responds to requests for information from resident, internal departments, and external agencies; documents case responses in applicable database, assists in the review of notices, interprets ordinances, and prepares case file information for presentation to applicable Boards or Commissions.

5. Participates in a variety of meetings, committees, task forces, and other related groups to receive and obtain information involving Code Enforcement.

6. Presents evidence and testimony in Municipal Court related to motion dockets or trials; prepares citations and submits fine recommendations.

7. Participates in vendor selection and management activities; solicits short-term bids from vendors, defines specifications, recommends vendor selection, oversees the work of on-site contractors, provides technical expertise and guidance to contractors, and ensures contract terms are met by monitoring and evaluating contractor performance. 

8. Takes photographs and necessary measurements and gathers all pertinent facts from the parties involved; issues notices of violation and, when necessary, citations.

9. Confers with related agencies and City departments on disposition of complaints and code violations; prepares detailed and specialized reports and correspondence related to code enforcement inspections, violations, and other activities.

10. Provides the public with information regarding land use, zoning, building, and housing codes and regulations.

11. Assists with street sweeping citation enforcement, as required.

12. Provides excellent customer service with a pleasant and calm demeanor, and effectively handles confrontation with the public in occasional high stress situations.

13. Performs other related duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:

High School Diploma or equivalent and three (3) years of increasingly responsible experience performing code compliance/enforcement work.  Associates degree in a related field is highly desirable. The completion of up to one (1) year of college (30 semester units) in a related field from an accredited college or university may substitute for up to one year of experience. 


License/Certificate:



Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




Criminal background checks are conducted post-offer and in compliance with the Fair Chance Act. 


KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:



Principles of lead supervision and training; operations, services, and activities of a municipal code compliance program; principles, practices, and methods used in the enforcement of a variety of codes; pertinent codes, ordinances, laws, and regulations pertaining to zoning, nuisance abatement, health and safety, and related areas; procedures involved in the enforcement of codes and regulations including methods and techniques of conducting and documenting field investigations; City services and organizational structure as they relate to code compliance; legal actions applicable to code enforcement compliance; effective public relations practices; principles and procedures of record keeping; methods and techniques of business correspondence and technical report preparation; modern office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and supporting word processing and spreadsheet applications; occupational hazards and standard safety procedures.



Ability to:

Independently perform a full range of municipal code enforcement and compliance duties; interpret and apply applicable codes, ordinances, and regulations related to zoning, nuisance abatement, and health and safety issues; inspect and identify violations of applicable codes and ordinances; enforce pertinent codes, ordinances, laws, and regulations with impartiality and efficiency; read and interpret legal documents and descriptions; respond to inquiries, complaints, and requests for service in a fair, tactful, and firm manner; investigate complaints and mediate resolutions in a timely and tactful manner; prepare accurate and detailed documentation of investigation findings; maintain complex logs, records, and files; research, compile, and collect data; prepare clear and concise technical reports; work independently in the absence of supervision; exercise sound and independent judgment; follow written and oral instructions; operate office equipment including computers and supporting word processing, spreadsheet, and database applications; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work.

Special Requirements

Possession of a P.C. 832 Peace Officer’s Standard and Training (POST) Certificate is required at the time of hire or within 6 months of employment.

Possession of a Certified Code Enforcement Officer (CCEO) designation from the California Association of Code Enforcement Officers (CACEO) is required at the time of hire or within 1 year of employment if the incumbent possesses an equivalent certification.  

Possession of any combination of certifications are highly desirable including those from the California Association of Code Enforcement (CACEO), International Code Council (ICC), Association of Code Enforcement (AACE) or certification as a Zoning Enforcement Officer, and/or Property Maintenance and Housing Inspector.  

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required. 




Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.


PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS



The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.



Physical Demands:



While performing the essential duties of this position, the employee may be required to engage in various physical activities, including climbing, balancing, reaching, sitting, standing, stooping, kneeling, crouching, walking, talking, seeing, hearing, and utilizing manual dexterity. Occasional lifting and carrying of up to 20 pounds may be required. Work is performed in both standard office settings and outdoor environments, which may involve exposure to adverse weather conditions. There may be occasional work at heights or near moving mechanical parts. The position also involves occasional exposure to the risk of electric shock, fumes, airborne particles, infectious diseases, and contact with criminal suspects. Specific vision abilities that may be required include close vision and the ability to adjust focus, with reasonable accommodations available for individuals with disabilities.



Mental Demands:



The employee may need to handle conflict constructively and develop effective resolutions. Strong oral and written communication skills may be required, as well as the ability to exercise sound judgment in situations without specific guidelines. The employee may also need to prioritize tasks, manage multiple assignments and projects concurrently, meet deadlines in a dynamic environment with interruptions, and interact professionally with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and other stakeholders encountered in the course of work.



WORKING CONDITIONS



Work is done in a standard office environment and in the field with exposure to various weather conditions, such as extreme heat, cold, and rain; hazardous conditions including unstable structures, unsafe neighborhoods, or exposure to chemicals, standing water, infectious disease, odors, and other conditions. Employees may interact with upset residents, and public and private representatives.



DISASTER SERVICE WORKER



In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Landscape & Facilities Maintenance Worker
description:
Job title: Landscape & Facilities Maintenance Worker

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under direct supervision, performs a range of maintenance and general construction work for City facilities, public spaces, landscape areas, and special projects; operates and maintains a variety of power equipment and hand tools; may operate light to heavy duty equipment; and performs other related work as necessary.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the entry level classification within the Landscape & Facilities Maintenance series. This classification is distinguished from the Landscape and Facilities Superintendent by the performance of the more routine, less complex maintenance and skilled work.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives direction from the Maintenance and Operations Manager or designee. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Performs skilled maintenance and repair work in assigned trade areas of City facilities and landscape spaces.




2. Plans, prioritizes, and schedules activities to complete repairs and maintenance work in an efficient and timely manner.




3. Selects proper tools and equipment for assignment; monitors work site safety; performs work following established safety policies and procedures and applicable codes and regulations.




4. Performs maintenance inspections; troubleshoots equipment, maintenance and/or system issues; identifies repair needs; reviews repair versus replacement costs and makes recommendations; performs required repairs or works with outside contractors for project completion.




5. Prepare various inspection reports as required; maintain files, reports, and logs regarding inspection; record amounts of materials used, and work performed.




6. Performs maintenance inspections; troubleshoots equipment, maintenance and/or system issues; identifies repair needs; reviews repair versus replacement costs and makes recommendations; performs required repairs or works with outside contractors for project completion.




7. Organizes and maintains assigned equipment and tools; inspects, cleans and performs preventative maintenance to ensure operability and reliability of equipment and tools. 




8. Reviews equipment and materials required for daily maintenance and work projects; initiates request for or purchases approved materials and supplies.




9. Prepares and/or maintains activity records, logs, work orders, material requests, reports and/or technical documentation for equipment or building systems.




10. Coordinates building maintenance services, preventative maintenance and repair activities with other City departments and outside agencies.




11. Determines and recommends equipment, materials, staffing, safety needs, devices, and/or equipment for assigned operation, maintenance, and improvement projects. 




12. Identify potential hazards and safety issues related to city facilities and landscape areas.




13. Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.




14. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.




15. Provides back-up support to other Public Works maintenance staff as required. 




16. Performs related duties as assigned.  

Special Requirements

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Equivalent to a High School Diploma or GED and two years of maintenance experience related to assignment.  




License/Certificate:  

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:

Operational characteristics, services, and activities of landscape and facilities maintenance, construction, installation and repair programs; organization and management practices as applied to the evaluation of maintenance operations programs, policies and operation needs; modern and complex principles and practices of municipal maintenance operations; services program development and administration; principles and practices of public works maintenance operations and facilities; and their application to a wide variety of operational programs; hazardous material containment and disposal principles and practices; specification writing principles and practices; preparation and evaluation of "Requests for Proposal" for services; principles and practices of contract administration; principles of municipal budget preparation and control; principles of supervision, training, and performance evaluation; principles and procedures of record keeping; principles of business letter writing and report preparation; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications such as word processing, spreadsheets, and databases; pertinent federal, state and local laws, codes, and regulations. Customer service and customer relations practices and principles. English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; principles and practices of sound business communications; safe work methods and safety regulations. 




Ability to: 

Display interpersonal communication; analyze situations accurately and adopt an effective course of action as necessary; perform responsible administrative work; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; research, design, prepare, and evaluate plans, and specifications for accuracy and conformance with accepted standards, compliance with appropriate laws, codes, regulations, and community needs; examine plans, specifications, designs, cost estimates, and legal descriptions for a variety of landscape, irrigation, and City facility projects; understand, and successfully communicate both orally and in writing, pertinent department policies and procedures; and legal guidelines; establish, maintain, and foster positive and harmonious working relationships with those contacted in the course of work. 

Other Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS




May be required to be on-call and to work various shifts or emergencies on evenings, weekends, and holidays.




Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. 




Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, climb, stoop, kneel, bend, lean, turn, twist, reach, grasp, push, and pull on even, uneven and slippery surfaces and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office and field equipment; and reach with hands and arms. Lift, carry, and push objects weighing up to 50 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

Work is performed in an outdoor construction and maintenance environment with moderate to high noise levels, hot and cold temperatures, inclement weather conditions, road hazards, loud noise levels, vibration, confining workspace, chemicals, mechanical and/or electrical hazards, and hazardous physical substances and fumes. Employees use power and noise producing equipment, and often work with constant interruptions. Employees may interact with upset staff and/or public and private representatives in interpreting and enforcing departmental policies and procedures.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Code Enforcement Officer
description:
Job title: Code Enforcement Officer

Job Summary

DEFINITION
Under general supervision, performs field inspections and investigations related to property maintenance violations, zoning, and housing code violations. Performs research and writes reports regarding zoning and municipal code violations, and facilitates special projects and assignments. 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS
The Code Enforcement Officer is the journey level classification in the Code Enforcement job series. It differs from the Senior Code Enforcement Officer position in that the incumbent performs less complex and more routine code enforcement activities. Incumbent demonstrates knowledge and experience in the performance of established procedures and protocols for code violation investigations and enforcement activities.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED
Receives general supervision from the Code Enforcement Manager or designee. This position exercises no supervision. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 
Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Ensures compliance with State laws, City and County land use, housing, zoning, abatement, and nuisance codes and ordinances.

2. Responds to complaints and performs proactive patrols.

3. Prepares case files, documentation, and issues notices and citations.

4. Maintains accurate records and tracks enforcement efforts..

5. Prepares documentation for legal actions and testifies in court..

6. Schedules and conducts property inspections and seeks voluntary compliance. 

7. Coordinates with other departments and agencies. 

8.Provides the public with information regarding applicable codes and ordinances. 

9. Assists with street sweeping and parking enforcement.

10. Assists with writing warrants and abatements.

11. Provides excellent customer service and handles conflict with professionalism.    

12. Performs other related duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES
Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:
High School Diploma and two (2) years of experience as a Code Enforcement Officer or two (2) years of experience performing inspections, investigations, abatements, land use, zoning, building, public safety, related code enforcement or administration of justice work.  The completion of up to one year of college (30 semester units) in a related field from an accredited college or university may substitute for up to one year of experience. 

License/Certificate:
Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.
Criminal background checks are conducted post-offer and in compliance with the Fair Chance Act. 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES
Knowledge of:
State and local laws and ordinances related to land use and zoning. Investigation techniques and enforcement practices.  Case documentation and reporting. Office software and enforcement-related technology.   Safety procedures and public relations practices.

Ability to:
Interpret and apply codes and regulations. Conduct investigations and prepare reports. Testify in legal proceedings.  Communicate clearly and effectively.  Provide high-level customer service. Work independently and manage priorities

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Possession of a P.C. 832 Peace Officer’s Standard and Training (POST) Certificate is required at the time of employment or must be obtained within six (6) months of employment. 

Possession of a Certified Code Enforcement Officer (CCEO) Designation is required at the time of hire, but incumbent may be provided with one (1) year to obtain the designation if they have an equivalent (non-CACEO) designation.  

Possession of relevant certifications from CACEO, ICC, AACE, or equivalent is highly desirable.
Ability to work evenings, weekends, and holidays, as needed. 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this job with or without reasonable accommodation.

Physical Demands:
Frequent walking, climbing, balancing, sitting, standing, bending, kneeling, and entering/exiting vehicles. Occasional lifting and carrying of objects up to 25 pounds. Visual and auditory acuity for inspections and communication. Manual dexterity for computer and enforcement equipment use.

Mental Demands:
Ability to manage multiple tasks, respond to public inquiries, and resolve complaints. Must maintain attention to detail and follow established procedures. 

Ability to exercise judgment, prioritize work, and handle interactions with the public in potentially stressful situations. 

WORKING CONDITIONS

Work is performed in a combination of indoor office settings and outdoor field environments, including exposure to varying weather conditions such as heat, cold, rain, and wind. Field work may involve exposure to noise, dust, traffic, animals, and potentially unpleasant property conditions. The employee may drive a city vehicle throughout the community to assist with inspections and parking enforcement activities. Office work includes using a computer, phone, and standard office equipment to support case documentation and research. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Communications Officer
description:
Job title: Communications Officer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, to direct, plan, organize, and implement a comprehensive public communications program for the City including the coordination of all City media and community information activities; to incorporate of the City's Mission, Vision, and Purpose, and Strength Based leadership principles and philosophies into the City's public communication strategies; and to perform other related work as required.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the journey level professional classification in the Communications series. The Communications Officer oversees a broad range of responsibilities for public relations and communication related to City services and activities. Incumbents serve as a centralized source of public and community information for dissemination to employees, businesses, community groups, the public, and the media. The Communications Officer position requires the ability to perform complex assignments with moderate levels of independent judgement. This position differs from the Public Information Officer by the latter's increased level of complexity and independent judgment required.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the City Clerk/Communication Director, or designee. May provide general supervision over para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS?

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

Oversees and participates in the full range of public relations and communication activities; determines need for informational and promotional materials and the most effective way to disseminate information to target audiences.
Represents the City at assigned meetings, functions, or events as assigned while fostering positive relationships with partner agencies, community groups, non-profit organizations, and the community.
Maintains regular media contacts and keeps them informed of issues and events of importance to the City.
Manages all City community media relations; implements and updates a strategic communication plan to effectively support the City's image.
Oversees and participates in the work of staff involved in community relations and outreach.
Researches, prepares, edits, and disseminates public information, news releases, promotional flyers, newsletters, brochures, and press kits.
Advises and trains City Council Members and City management on appropriate and effective ways to convey City messages and provides information on programs and activities.
Coordinates and assists with the preparation and response to correspondence received by the City Council.
Designs, writes, prepares layout, and takes photographs for the City newsletter.
Assists with City events such as the State of the City, Team Building events, End of Year Recognition Dinner and Awards, photo opportunities, and groundbreaking ceremonies.
Coordinates electronic information needs; oversees content, design, accuracy, timeliness and layout of the City's website.
Creatively designs, writes, and prepares layout for the City newsletter, marketing materials, and City website.
Develops and directs convenient, accessible, and cost-effective information services and resources to meet the changing needs of the community.
Sets and maintains customer service standards; solicits and responds to customer concerns; responds to and resolves difficult and sensitive citizen inquiries and complaints; follows-up with department staff to ensure prompt resolution.
Develops, recommends, and administers policies and procedures.
Stays abreast of new trends and innovations in the field of community relations, including operations and technology; evaluates the impact of new developments and recommends improvements to existing programs and procedures.
Reviews and prepares public presentations at City Council and other public meetings.
Interact with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner
Perform all duties within the context of the City's Mission Statement and Organizational Values.
Conducts various cross-training with other team members to provide coverage during absences.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and education that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities is qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be;

QUALIFICATIONS:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with the equivalent to a bachelor's degree with major coursework in public administration, business administration, journalism, communications, marketing, or public relations or a related field; a minimum of three (3) years of progressively responsible experience involving public information, community outreach, social media marketing, and public relations experience, preferably in the public sector; one year in a supervisory capacity; a master's degree in public administration, business administration, journalism, communications, marketing, or public relations or a related field is highly desirable.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS & ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Techniques and methods used in the development and evaluation of communications; principles and practices of research, journalism, graphic design, layout and production; fundamentals of photography, video-photography and cable-casting; personal computer operation; software applications including graphics and desktop publishing systems; interviewing techniques, communications, media services and resources; organization, services and functions of municipal government; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes and regulations; principles of supervision, training and performance evaluation; and local government process, management and governance; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Develop, organize, and coordinate a communications program; communicate effectively, both orally and in writing; gather and verify news information through interview, observation and research; analyze administrative problems, evaluate alternatives and make creative recommendations; advise on most effective techniques of information dissemination; exercise judgment in release of information; give information rapidly, accurately and tactfully; prepare press releases, news articles, presentations, reports and other written materials in a timely manner; prepare and present a variety of communications materials; write and edit newsletters and news releases; prepare flyers and reports; prepare and give presentations; edit materials for proper punctuation and grammar; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City officials, employees, the public and news media; act as a spokesperson for the City during interviews and other public speaking engagements; effectively represent the City in meetings with other governmental agencies, citizens, contractors, vendors, various businesses, as well as professional, regulatory, and legislative organizations; coordinate activities with other divisions and City departments; operate a personal computer and applicable software including graphics and desktop publishing systems; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle where required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required. Possess a valid Class C California Driver License and a satisfactory driving record. Bilingual ability is highly desirable. Graphic Design experience is highly desirable. Photography and videography experience are highly desirable.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item(s) above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the City's Communications Specialist. These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. ?Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Assistant Human Resources & Risk Management Director
description:
Job title: Assistant Human Resources & Risk Management Director

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under direction of the City Manager, to direct a comprehensive City-wide human resources program, including recruitment, selection, employment, classification, compensation, employee relations, performance appraisal, benefits administration, payroll, risk management and related internal services; provides expert professional assistance and guidance to City management on human resources and risk management; champion a team-centered, collaborative work environment that promotes the City values of kindness, grit and solutions-driven results; to recommend and implement programs and policies in support of employee engagement, employee and team development, employee wellness, employee recognition, and employee work/life balance; ensure that the City and personnel are in full compliance with applicable laws, mandates, codes and regulations; to lead, manage, and implement various special projects and programs for the City across multiple City departments and functions involving the City’s human capital; and to perform related duties as required. 

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives direction from the City Manager, or designee; exercises general supervision over professional, para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

1. Manages and evaluates the work of the Human Resources/ Risk Management Division staff, participates in establishing operational plans and initiatives to meet division goals and objectives; implements division plans, work programs, processes, procedures and policies required to achieve overall division performance results; coordinates and integrates division functions and responsibilities to achieve optimal efficiency and effectiveness; participates in developing and monitoring performance against the annual departmental budget.

2. Champion the development, implementation, and nurturing of a team-centered, collaborative culture and work environment promoting our city values of kindness, grit and solutions-driven results; conducts research related to best practices; seeks opportunities to invest in people in order to deliver a high level of employee satisfaction and customer service. 

3. Provides day-to-day leadership and works with staff to ensure a high performing, collaborative work environment which supports achieving City objectives; provides leadership and participates in programs and activities that promote a positive employee relations environment.

4. In collaboration with other members of the executive team, participates in the development and implementation of the City’s strategic and business plans, goals and objectives; leads and directs division staff in the development and application of new processes and technologies to achieve higher efficiency, productivity and customer service in division work processes. 

5. Develops, implements and administers comprehensive human resources management programs, policies and procedures and guidelines across all City departments, consistent with state and federal requirements and sound professional principles and practices; confers with and coordinates the implementation of programs, policies and practices with City departments; provides expert advice to executives, managers and supervisors on a wide range of human resources management issues and practices; provides internal consulting on a variety of complex, sensitive and confidential organizational and human resources issues; manages, directs and participates in the development of City-wide human resources policies and procedures.

6. Serves as the liaison for human resources services internally, and with outside agencies; advises executives, department heads and other managers and supervisors on employee relations matters, including grievance and disciplinary procedures and actions; represents the City in grievance and disciplinary actions. 

7. Directs recruitment, testing and selection activities for positions; directs the development and maintenance of comprehensive classification and compensation plans; approves completed classification and job evaluation studies; directs administration of City performance management practices and programs; directs the maintenance of central personnel records. 

8. Proposes and directs administration of a broad program of health and welfare benefits; recommends benefits program design changes; negotiates benefit plan provisions and rates. 

9. Directs the investigation and resolution of complaints; represents the City in dealing with state and federal compliance agencies and in hearings and litigation on employment matters; works with and assists City attorneys and outside labor counsel in developing and presenting the City's position for hearings and litigation. 

10. Directs the development and delivery of training for managers and supervisors on human resources legal and procedural requirements; interprets City policies and procedures and precedents for managers and employees. 

11. Directs City-wide training; assesses training needs for all City staff; works closely with supervisors and managers to identify individual job enrichment and employee development opportunities for succession planning, and towards the achievement of employee self-actualization.

12. Monitors developments in areas of responsibility; analyzes proposed state and federal law, regulations and court decisions for their impact on City practices and operations; recommends and implements policy and procedure changes consistent with requirements; directs and conducts research and analysis of human resources and employee relations needs, recommends appropriate actions and implements plans, organizes, and manages the financial management component of payroll processing; monitors and oversees activities and operations of payroll to ensure full compliance with applicable laws, codes and regulations. Ensures that City policies, practices and procedures are carried out within a framework based on sound financial management principles.

13. Recommends and implements special programs to support employee engagement, employee wellness, employee recognition, rewards programs, and employee work/life balance; coordinates various annual employee events/activities to foster a best practices work environment. 

14. Oversees the City’s recruitment and selection process; screens candidates and evaluates candidate qualifications; recommends the most highly qualified candidates for further review; coordinates a structured and unbiased selection process to include tests, practical exercises, and interviews in order to further evaluate candidates.

15. Plans, coordinates, administers, and manages traditional human resources programs and services for the City and its human capital including benefits administration, classification and compensation, plan administration, workers’ compensation, training, safety, risk management and related functions. 

16. Facilitates the resolution of sensitive and controversial issues in the course of managing the responsibility for all human resources services and activities, nurtures continuous positive working relationship with employees, supervisors, managers, and department heads.

17. Monitors and evaluates the efficiency and effectiveness of service delivery policies, practices, methods, and procedures; makes recommendations for improvement.

18. Oversees the administration and maintenance of the City’s classification and compensation plan; conducts job analysis studies, salary and benefit surveys; makes recommendations and implements appropriate solutions.

19. Oversees the administration and maintenance of the City’s workers’ compensation program; receives and processes claims; serves as the liaison with injured workers, City staff, attorneys, medical providers, and investigators in the management of injured worker claims; and works closely with injured employees, managers and supervisors regarding return to work issues. 

20. Oversees the overall administration of health benefits program including conducting open enrollment for health benefits and coordinating information with the City’s benefits administrator; reviews the City’s benefit package annually for cost effectiveness and makes recommendations for changes and/or enhancements. 

21. Oversees the administration of the leave management programs for the City including various protected state and federal leave of absence laws; provides required notices, monitors time off, and conducts interactive processes in accordance with the Americans’ with Disabilities Act (ADA), as required.  

22. Participates in the development and administration of the annual budget; participates in the forecast of funds needed for staffing, equipment, materials, and supplies; monitors and approves expenditures; implements adjustments.

23. Prepares and presents staff reports to City Council; prepares necessary correspondence.

24. Coordinates with the City Attorney as needed related to legal issues.

25. Serves as records manager in the maintenance of official employee personnel files and confidential employee records.

26. Directs and conducts a variety of organizational studies, investigations, and operational studies; recommends modifications to personnel administration programs, policies, and procedures as appropriate.

27. Coordinates the City’s risk management activities with the carrier, and in consultation with the City Attorney and City Manager as required.

28. Oversees the development and administration of an effective safety program and maintains required records.

29. Attends and participates in professional and community meetings as necessary; stays current on issues relative to the field of human resources, talent acquisition and retention, and municipal operations in general.

30. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe and efficient manner.

31. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

 

Qualifications:




Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in public administration, business administration, human resources, or a closely related field.  A minimum of seven years of progressively responsible experience in municipal or public administration, human resources, benefits administration, or risk management with three years of supervisory, management, and/or administrative experience.   

 

License/Certificate:  

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

 

Possession of a professional Human Resources certification is highly desirable and/or completion of college coursework in Human Resources or Organizational Development.   

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:




Operations, services, and activities of a municipal human resources program in a public agency setting including job analysis, classification, compensation, benefits administration, workers’ compensation, safety, employee relations, employee development, and training; methods and techniques of talent acquisition including recruitment, outreach, marketing, and branding  strategies; methods and techniques of screening and selection practices, test construction, and interviewing; management practices related to employee onboarding and orientation;  modern trends and best practices related to employers of choice; concepts and methods of employee engagement, employee recognition, employee development, employee wellness and employee work life balance programs; legal issues in the field of human resources management; basic principles and practices of budget administration, contract administration and evaluation; principles and methods of employee supervision including work planning, assignment, training, review and evaluation of staff; methods and techniques of research and analysis of personnel administrative and statistical data; principles and procedures of record keeping; principles and practices of customer service; modern office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and related software applications such as word processing, spread sheets and databases; the organization and operations of the City and of outside agencies in order to perform necessary assigned responsibilities; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes, and regulations; English usage, spelling, grammar and punctuation; business letter writing and report preparation; safe work methods and safety regulations.

 

Ability to:

Plan and administer an effective and compliant human resources program; perform professional level managerial responsibilities in the administration of the City’s personnel functions; make independent decisions; establish goals and objectives; design effective talent acquisition  programs to obtain highly qualified candidates; develop valid and effective selection procedures; onboard and orient new employees; research, conceive, and initiate best practices programs as an “employer of choice” for employee retention; implement progressive employee development, employee recognition, employee wellness and employee work-life balance programs; research, collect, compile, and analyze information and data; make complete and accurate analyses, reports, and recommendations in a variety of personnel areas; prepare clear, concise, oral and written reports both narrative and statistical; work tactfully with and gain confidence and cooperation of other internal personnel, the public, and outside agencies and organizations; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; understand, interpret, and apply general and specific administrative and human resources policies and procedures as well as applicable federal, state, and local policies, laws, and regulations; formulate and conduct presentations to employees, supervisors, and division managers; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; operate office equipment including computers and supporting software applications; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely, and appropriately to inquiries from the public, City staff, or other agencies on sensitive issues in area of responsibility; exercise good judgment and maintain confidentiality in maintaining critical sensitive information, records, and reports; utilize public relations techniques in responding to inquiries and complaints; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  Travel by vehicle may be required while conducting City business.  

 

Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Deputy Talent & Special Projects Director.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally, the environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER




In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Community Development Director
description:
Job title: Community Development Director

Job Summary

DEFINITION

 

Under direction of the City Manager, plans, manages, and oversees the activities and operations of the Community Development Department including Planning, Engineering, Capital Projects, Public Works, Municipal Enforcement, Landscape and Urban Design, Facilities and Street Maintenance, Transportation and Mobility, Housing and Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Administration, and Trails, Parks, and Open Space; coordinates assigned activities with other departments and outside agencies; provides highly responsible and complex administrative support to the City Manager; and performs other related duties as required.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives direction from the City Manager or designee.   Provides general direction over the Engineering team, and Planning team.

Essential Functions

1. Assumes full management responsibility for all Community Development Department including Planning, Engineering, Capital Projects, Public Works, Municipal Enforcement, Landscape and Urban Design, Facilities and Street Maintenance, Transportation and Mobility, Housing and Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Administration, and Trails, Parks, and Open Space

2. Manages the development and implementation of departmental goals, objectives, and priorities for each assigned service area; identifies opportunities for improvement.

3. Recommends and administers policies and procedures; identifies opportunities for improvement. 

4. Establishes, within City policy, appropriate service and staffing levels; monitors and evaluates the efficiency and effectiveness of service delivery methods and procedures; allocates resources accordingly; assesses and monitors work load, administrative and support systems, and internal reporting relationships. 

5. Prepares and presents staff reports and other necessary correspondence.

6. Represents the Community Development Department and coordinates assigned activities with the use of other departments, elected officials, and outside agencies.

7. Coordinates assigned activities with those of other departments and outside agencies and organizations.

8. Explains department programs, policies, and activities; negotiates and resolves sensitive and controversial issues. 

9. Participates in a leadership and management role on a variety of boards, commissions, and committees including Planning Commission and City Council; attends and participates in professional group meetings.

10. Maintains awareness of new trends and developments in the fields of community development; incorporates new developments and best practices as appropriate.

11. Develops, manages, and implements changes; plans, and coordinates, through subordinate level staff, the Community Development Department’s Strategic work plan.

12. Assigns projects and programmatic areas of responsibility; reviews and evaluates work methods and procedures.

13. Selects, trains, motivates, influences, inspires, and evaluates assigned personnel; provides or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies; implements discipline and termination procedures.

14. Manages professional and project contracts to achieve goals, results, and social outcomes.

15. Meets with key staff to identify and resolve problems. 

16. Selects, trains, motivates, and evaluates assigned personnel; provides or coordinates staff training; works with employees to correct deficiencies; implements discipline and termination procedures. 

17. Oversees and participates in the development and administration of the department budget; approves the forecast of funds needed for staffing, equipment, materials, and supplies; recommends expenditures and implements budgetary adjustments as appropriate and necessary.

18. Develops, coordinates, and manages multiple contracts and projects; solicits and negotiates consultant services, issues public works projects, development proposals, development agreements, and/or requests for proposals or qualifications. 

19. Oversees and participates in assigned special projects.

20. Coordinates the preparation, publication, and distribution of agendas and support material for City Council and other meetings as needed.

21. Responds to and resolves difficult, sensitive, and confidential citizen inquiries and complaints.

22. Participates in cross-training and provides back up to other department staff; assists other office personnel in performing related administrative support functions; serves as a back-up to other finance and/or City functions.   

23. Establishes positive working relationships with City staff and the general public.

24. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe and efficient manner.

25. Manages current planning functions that includes compliance with all local, state, and federal regulations such as the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) and the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA).

26. Manages current and advanced planning functions and related to development projects and design projects and plans, policy development, and major policy documents including general plan, zoning, specific plan, development agreements, and various master plans and special studies.

27. Researches grant funding opportunities as requested by the City Manager; prepares grant applications; manages the implementation of grant funded programs and evaluates programs for accomplishment of stated objectives; manages and oversees the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) programs and administration including housing rehabilitation loan program.

28. Provides staff assistance to the City Manager; assists the City Manager with the City newsletter, City Manager’s Report, and works with other City staff to develop articles.

29. Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Qualifications:

 

Five years of recent progressively responsible professional work experience in the administration of zoning, planning, economic development, engineering, and redevelopment programs in a municipal planning environment, including two (2) years serving in a supervisory and management or administrative level, and graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in City or Urban Planning, Architecture, Civil Engineering, Geography, Landscape Architecture, Business Administration, Public Administration, or related field. A master's degree in City Planning, Engineering, Public Administration, Economics, or Finance is highly desirable.  Ability to speak Spanish or Mandarin is highly desirable.  

 

 

License/Certificate:  

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

 

Possession of an American Institute of Certified Planners (AICP), CNU-A Accreditation, Professional Engineering license(s), or combination of multi-disciplinary experience is highly desirable, as is active involvement in professional organizations such as or a combination of (but not limited to) American Planning Association (APA), Congress for New Urbanism (CNU), Association of Environmental Professionals (AEP), Association of Pedestrian and Bicycle Professionals (APBP), American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Public Works Association (APWA), Urban Land Institute (ULI).  

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

 

Knowledge of:




Operations, services, and activities of a comprehensive community and economic development program; principles, practices, and procedures of contemporary city planning, zoning, urban design, redevelopment process, California land use and environmental law, research techniques, economics, municipal finance, and sociology as applied to city planning; advanced principles and practices of program development and administration; modern principles, practices and techniques of community development administration, organization, and operation; principles and practices of building inspection, plan check, code compliance and community enhancement; engineering, planning, Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) programs, and trails, parks and open space; current social, political and environmental issues influencing community development programs; principles and practices of municipal budget preparation and administration; principles of supervision, training, and performance evaluation; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes, and regulations; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications such as word processing, spreadsheets, and databases.

 

Ability to:

 

Manage a progressive and comprehensive community development program with a growth mindset; demonstrate adaptability to change; develop and administer departmental goals, objectives, and procedures; analyze and assess programs, policies, and operational needs and make appropriate adjustments; identify and respond to sensitive community and organizational issues, concerns, and needs; plan, organize, direct, and coordinate the work of lower level staff; delegate authority and responsibility; select, supervise, train, and evaluate staff; analyze problems, identify alternative solutions, project consequences of proposed actions, and implement recommendations in support of goals; research, analyze, and evaluate new service delivery methods and techniques; prepare clear and concise administrative and financial reports; prepare and administer large and complex budgets; interpret and apply applicable federal, state, and local policies, laws, and regulations; operate office equipment including computers and supporting word processing, spreadsheet, and database applications; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required 

                          

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

 

 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.  Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

 

Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Community Development Director.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings and holidays.  The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER




In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.
