title: Assistant Engineer
description:
Job title: Assistant Engineer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, to perform a variety of moderately complex professional engineering work involving the research, design, and construction of public works and engineering activities; reviews plans, evaluates costs, conducts field reviews, participates in the preparation of engineering reports, and performs related duties as required. 

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the entry level classification within the professional engineering series. Positions in this classification typically lead and perform a variety of moderately complex independent engineering analyses, plan review and project management assignments, and make recommendations in resolving engineering issues and problems. The complexity of assignments will increase with training and experience, and correspondingly, the level of supervision will decrease. The Assistant Engineer position differs from the Associate Engineer in that the Assistant Engineer performs less complex assignments and exercises limited independent judgement as experience is gained.    

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the City Engineer, or designee. May function in a lead capacity over technical, and administrative support staff. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 




Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Assists the City Engineer, or designee with plan check activities, permitting, projects and coordination between the City and engineering consultants; maintains record keeping and tracking; ensures expeditious processing.

 2. Assists with requests for proposal and contract administration for engineering consultants and maintenance vendors; and monitors projects costs.

 3. Responds to and researches inquiries and complaints and coordinates activities with outside agencies and the public. 

 4. Gathers data required for the planning of a wide variety of engineering projects; assists with staff reports related to engineering projects.

 5. Reviews traffic accident reports and statistics; assists with developing policies and plans for traffic signs and signal systems; coordinates city street plans and traffic flow with highways and freeways.

 6. Reviews, makes comments and recommendations regarding proposed projects by checking plans, maps, related studies and supporting data for concept, design, and compliance with regulations; recommends conditions of approval for projects.

 7. Prepares and reviews plans, specifications, and estimates; prepares and processes legal documents required for project completion.

 8. Serves as staff to the City Council and Planning Commission when assigned; participates in staff project meetings; participates in discussions or drafting staff reports or presentations regarding engineering projects.

 9. Assists the City Engineer or designee in surveying, mapping, and data collection activities; may be assigned routine investigation, design, and drafting tasks, and provides recommendations in resolving problems.

 10. Researches and identifies project design requirements for particular elements, including hydrology, traffic and soils reports and calculations as well as grading plans, sewer plans, water plans, streets plans, traffic studies, and other documents, including plans, parcel and tract maps, and studies; reviews drawings and details of construction and implementation plans; prepares conditions for approval.

 11. Assists and provides technical guidance to inspectors in studying field problems and incorporating design revisions during grading and construction phases based on site inspections.

 12. Assists with preparing construction inspection reports, non-compliance letters, bond and fee letters and developer credits as well as environmental status reports, and public education materials.

 13. Conducts field reviews and prepares quarterly progress reports and staff reports; prepares project check lists, deeds, and exhibits; drafts and revises associated ordinances and resolutions; reviews and processes change orders.

 14. Assists in the research and development of BMP guidelines for engineering projects.

 15. Investigates field problems affecting property owners, contractors, and maintenance operations; prepares quarterly progress reports; reviews and coordinates the submission and approval of construction specifications; ensures compliance with plan specifications.

 16. Assists with the coordination of right-of-way projects with utilities and affected parties;  assists with plan checks of lot-line adjustments.

 17. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

18. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.

19. Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.

 20. Performs related duties as assigned.




Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES
 
Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 
 
Qualifications:
 
Graduation from an accredited college with a bachelor’s degree in civil engineering, or a closely related field. Two or more years of responsible professional civil engineering experience in a municipal setting, including experience with public works projects; or an equivalent combination of training and experience.
 
License/Certificate: 
 
A California Class C Driver’s License or the ability to obtain a valid license.
 
Possession of valid certification as a Civil Engineer issued by the California State Board of Registration for Civil and Professional engineers is desirable.
 
Possession of a certification as an Engineer in Training (EIT) is highly desirable.
 
Membership in American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Public Works Association (APWA), and related groups is highly desirable.  
 
KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES
 
Knowledge of: 
 
Modern principles, procedures, practices and standards of municipal civil engineering; land development, surveying methods and techniques; municipal engineering laws, ordinances, codes, specifications and plans; engineering project inspection methods; water and wastewater systems/plants; modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding engineering; principles and practices of contract administration; traffic engineering fundamentals and use of standard equipment used in the engineering profession; communications techniques; cost estimation practices; engineering principles and practices as applied to public works, including planning and development, design, and construction; methods and techniques utilized in the preparation of public works project designs and related plans, specifications, and cost estimates; related federal and state laws, ordinances and regulations; standard office procedures, practices and equipment; modern office equipment, including a computer and applicable software; methods and techniques for record keeping and report preparation and writing; proper English, spelling and grammar; occupational hazards and standard safety practices
 
Ability to: 

Operate computer terminal and use computer-aided design, mapping, spreadsheet and word processing programs; review and prepare engineering plans, specifications and design requirements; analyze and interpret legal contracts and work agreements; prepare and evaluate engineering data; organize and prioritize tasks to meet deadlines; prepare clear and concise reports, drawings, maps, notes, correspondence and other written materials; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships with staff, management, public and private representatives, contractors, architects, developers, and others in the course of work; perform professional engineering work, including project design; direct the work of others involved in related activity; interpret and apply related laws, ordinances, and regulations; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; prepare and maintain records and reports; meet the public in situations requiring diplomacy and tact; deal constructively with conflict and develop effective resolutions; communicate effectively both orally and in writing; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships.
 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS
 
Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. 
                          
Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.
 
PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS
 
The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
 
Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment and occasionally works in a construction site and field environment. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Employees may occasionally work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or electrical hazards. Travel throughout the City is required. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, City Commission meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Associate Engineer. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. 
DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Finance Director/City Treasurer
description:
Job title: Finance Director/City Treasurer

Job Summary

DEFINITION 

Under direction, to serve as the City's Chief Financial Officer and City Treasurer responsible for planning and oversight of all City financial affairs/operations and the supervision of staff. to perform a variety of responsible and professional accounting and fiscal activities in order to maintain the integrity of the City's finances; to advise the City Manager related to current and projected budget status; and to perform related duties as required.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

Receives direction from the City Manager; exercises general direction over professional level staff and general supervision over paraprofessional, technical and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Develops and directs the implementation of goals, objectives, policies, and procedures for the Finance Department and related activities.

2. Oversees and coordinates the preparation and assembly of the budget document.

3. Provides assistance and guidance to other departments and staff.

4. Establishes financial controls and prepares financial reports and analyzes for accounting and operational management purposes including periodic budget status reports.

5. Plans, develops, implements and administers the City's cash management and investment program in accordance with applicable State law and the City's Investment Policy adopted by the City Council.

6. Evaluates rates and charges for City services to determine that they are current and appropriate.

7. Coordinates the development and implementation of new/improved financial software applications to ensure maximum benefit and use to City staff from these applications.

8. Responsible for the administration of the City's assessment districts including the monitoring of delinquencies and the foreclosure process.

9. Forecasts City revenues, expenditures and year-end fund balances. Prepares long range financial projections of the City's General Fund or other Funds as required and/or needed.

10. Oversees the administration of payroll.

11. Supervises, trains and evaluates subordinate professional and administrative support staff.

12. Provides advice and recommendations regarding City financial affairs to the City Council and executive management.

13. Conducts studies and recommends administrative, organizational and policy improvements with departmental and City-wide implications.

14. Directs preparation of a variety of reports which may include the Comprehensive annual Financial Report (CAFR), State Controller's reports and other reports required by law.

15. Administers grant funds and ensures that the City complies with financial and legal requirements.

16. Directs and/or reviews the work of financial consultants for auditing, analysis, fee determination and related matters.

17. Develops strategic financial plans for all City Funds for consideration by the City Council and senior management; serves as the City Treasurer.

18. Responsible for purchasing activities and the establishment and administration of purchasing policies and procedures.

19. Administers the City's business registration and rental registration programs.

20. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

21. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in finance, accounting, business or closely related field. A minimum of five years of progressively responsible experience professional accounting or auditing experience in a governmental setting and at least three years supervision of professional and support staff. Designation as a Certified Public Accountant or Certified Public Finance Officer is preferred.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

Knowledge of operations, services and activities of a municipality including the policies and procedures related to governmental accounting and finance; general laws and administrative policies governing municipal financial practices and procedures; applicable ordinances and regulations governing financial operations of the City; business letter writing and basic report preparation techniques; modern office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and related software applications such as word processing, spread sheets and databases; office management principles, methods and procedures, including principles and procedures of financial record keeping; the organization and operations of the City and of outside agencies in order to perform necessary assigned responsibilities; advanced principles and practices of budget preparation and administration; advanced principles and practices of auditing; English usage, spelling, grammar and punctuation; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Perform responsible and difficult administrative and financial management and recordkeeping involving the use of independent judgment and personal initiative; develop and apply administrative and departmental policies and procedures; provide information and organize material in compliance with applicable laws and regulations; effectively represent the City to outside individuals and agencies to accomplish the goals and objectives of the Finance department; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely and appropriately to inquiries from the public or other agencies on issues in area of responsibility; maintain confidentiality of information and exercise tact and diplomacy in interpersonal dealings which are difficult, highly sensitive and confidential; work independently in the absence of supervision; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; operate a computer using word processing, spreadsheet, and financial software at a high level of competency and proficiency; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City Manager, City officials, Board and Commission members, contractors, consultants, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Possession of a designation as a Certified Public Accountant is highly desirable.

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS 

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required in order to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Finance Director/City Treasurer. These hours may include, but are not limited to: weekends, evenings and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale Employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Senior Permit Technician
description:
Job title: Senior Permit Technician

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under close to general supervision, to assist in performing a variety of routine and responsible work within the Community Safety Department; to provide superior customer service, to respond to all general and building inquires at a high volume public counter, to review and issue permits; to build cohesive professional relationships with external agencies; to coordinate inter/intra departmental communication and documentation; to perform a variety of tasks related to preparing, gathering, analyzing, and summarizing permit data and reports; to issue permits, calculate, and collect fees; to provide administrative and technical support; and perform related duties as assigned. 

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Permit Technician is the entry level class within the Permit Technician series and is expected to learn to perform the full range of assigned duties and responsibilities at the entry level. Incumbents within the classification initially perform routine and less complex plan review and permit issuance related responsibilities, however, steadily receive more complex duties as experience is gained. Employees in this class normally work under close and continuous supervision performing repetitive or closely related duties according to established procedures. This classification is distinguished from the Senior Permit Technician in that an incumbent is expected to perform assigned duties under direct supervision as they learn their positions. 

 

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Building Official, Community Safety Director, or designee. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.  Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job

1. Assists the public by phone, email, or at the Building & Safety and Planning counter; provides information related to permit procedures, policies, and functions; verifies plan check status; processes forms, building permit applications, and plans necessary for the issuance of permits; performs minor plan checking at the counter for plans such as patio covers, block walls and swimming pools; receives, logs, and routes plans.

2. Calculates and collects fees in accordance with established fee schedules; verifies final inspection clearances for all City requirements; determines that all fees have been paid prior to permit issuance; processes refunds to applicants.

3. Maintains Building & Safety records; forwards monthly building reports to the County Assessor and the State; looks up and verifies Assessor parcel numbers, ownership and addresses from computerized files; inputs permit information into computer files.

4. Assists the general public by responding to inquiries and routine questions by phone, email, or over the counter; provides information related to permit procedures, policies, and functions; route various calls to various City departments; verifies plan check status, land use, building permits, the general plan and other projects.  

5. Issues annual fire inspection permits; determines occupancy of business and fees; schedules inspections; enters inspection results into computer and maintains related files.

6. Maintains building records including worker's compensation and insurance records for contractors, department revenue receipts, monthly building reports to the County Assessor and the State; verifies State Contractor's Licenses for contractors working in the City. 

7. Coordinates final inspection clearances from all departments; determines that all fees have been paid prior to permit issuance and/or occupancy and utility releases.

8. Responds to general property information including but not limited to: Location, Zoning, general planning, general building, etc.

9. Processes new address or address change notifications and notifies the County Assessor of changes. 

10. Coordinates and assists with various departments, outside agencies, and consultants to process projects and collection of fees.

11. Maintains records for issued and expired permits, utility releases, tract, and lot finals, warrant requests, audits, inspections, and annual permits. 

12. Exercises diplomacy and tact and establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.

13. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

14. Provides back-up support to other front counter and office staff as required. 

15. Performs other related duties as assigned.  

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Education: Equivalent to a High school diploma or satisfactory equivalent (GED) supplemented by college level course work. One year of experience in processing building permits, and/or reviewing minor construction plans for code compliance and completeness for a public agency. Plan review coordination and permit issuance experience in a municipal setting is desirable.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

Possession of ICC certification as a Permit Technician, Plans Examiner, or equivalent certification is desirable.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Building requirements in the areas of plumbing, mechanical, electrical, energy conservation, and disabled access, as defined in state and municipal laws, regulations, and codes; basic housing construction methods and terminology; basic symbols and conventions found in construction plans and blueprints; record keeping principles and practices; standard business arithmetic; effective interpersonal relations. Permit issuance process, including fee calculations, contractor license laws, and related statutes. Basic concepts of construction methods and materials. City Municipal Code, including building, zoning, and fire safety requirements; building, engineering, construction and utility permit processing procedures and fee rates; customer service methods and techniques. Personal computer operation and relevant software applications; proper English, spelling, and grammar; methods and techniques for report preparation and writing; occupational hazards and standard safety practices.

Ability to:

Accurately interpret and explain to the public building code requirements as defined in laws, regulations, codes, and policies. Issue permits and perform minor plan review. Read plans and identify violations of the model codes; make accurate arithmetic computations to determine and collect fees and balance cash received; read and interpret building and housing blueprints, plans, specifications, codes and ordinances; utilize computer terminal and word processing and related software programs; read and interpret regulations and requirements related to the issuance of permits and assessment of fees; provide information to the public regarding requirements and procedures for obtaining land use entitlements and engineering permits. Understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; promote and observe safety principles and work in a safe manner; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City personnel and the public; operate an office computer and a variety of word processing and software applications.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

title: Communications Specialist
description:
Job title: Communications Specialist

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, to assist in performing paraprofessional administrative work related to the City's public information platforms and outreach programs; to assist in preparing and disseminating informational materials to the public and news media; to assist in preparing marketing publications concerning City services, activities, programs, events and functions; to assist in coordinating events for the City; and to perform other related work as required.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the City Clerk/Communication Director or designee. May serve in a lead capacity over interns and volunteers and/or provide guidance and leadership for daily activities, assigned projects or tasks as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.
Researches, drafts for approval, and disseminates timely and accurate City related information to the public through various outlets including, but not limited to, social media, email notifications, press releases, newsletters, articles, special presentations, reports, and other related channels.
Assists in the development and implementation of a comprehensive communications program for the City which identifies audiences, messages, communications tools, and evaluation measures.
Monitors and updates the various City related social media accounts, pages, and groups on all applicable platforms.
Evaluates and measures mobile and social media program success and impact; monitors trends in social media tools, trends, applications and appropriately applies that knowledge to increasing the use of social media for the City.
Represents the City at assigned meetings, functions, or events as assigned while fostering positive relationships with partner agencies, community groups, non-profit organizations, and the community.
Assists in coordinating events for the City, including, but not limited to, event logistics, registration, attendee tracking, presentation and materials support, and pre- and post-event evaluations.
Researches and recommends new and alternative ways to maximize public outreach to enhance community outreach and engagement and increase public awareness of City happenings.
Maintains and updates the City's community calendar with timely, accurate and detailed information; works collaboratively with partner agencies to ensure all City related events are relayed to the public.
Assists in developing multi-media presentations as required, including PowerPoint slide shows, displays and photographic exhibits.
Develops, edits, and designs all City promotional items, event flyers, social media graphics and other materials as required.
Assists with receiving visitors and telephone calls; provides information and handles issues that may require sensitivity and use of sound independent judgment; assists with responding to requests for information and complaints referring matters to appropriate City staff.
Interacts with co-workers at all levels in the organization in a collaborative and customer service-oriented manner.
Maintains archives of press articles related to City news; tracks media response along with a variety of indicators (e.g. positive, negative, message portrayed, etc.); prepare report of results for City leadership as assigned.
Assists with directing incoming mail and email communications; determines the priority level and routes incoming correspondence, reports, requests, and instructions; handles or refers matters as directed.
Conducts various cross-training with other team members to provide coverage during absences.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation, or near completion, from an accredited college or university with the equivalent to a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university with major coursework in Public Relations, Journalism, Communications, Marketing, or a closely related field; and a minimum of one year of progressively responsible experience involving the development and coordination of public affairs, public information, community outreach and social media marketing; or an equivalent combination of training and experience.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Techniques and methods used in the development and evaluation of communications; principles and practices of research, journalism, graphic design, layout and production; fundamentals of photography, video-photography and cable-casting; personal computer operation; software applications including graphics and desktop publishing systems; interviewing techniques, communications, media services and resources; organization, services and functions of municipal government; pertinent federal, state, and local laws, codes and regulations; principles of supervision, training and performance evaluation; and local government process, management and governance; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Develop, organize, and coordinate a communications program; communicate effectively, both orally and in writing; gather and verify news information through interview, observation and research; analyze administrative problems, evaluate alternatives and make creative recommendations; advise on most effective techniques of information dissemination; exercise judgment in release of information; give information rapidly, accurately and tactfully; prepare press releases, news articles, presentations, reports and other written materials in a timely manner; prepare and present a variety of communications materials; write and edit newsletters and news releases; prepare flyers and reports; prepare and give presentations; edit materials for proper punctuation and grammar; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City officials, employees, the public and news media; coordinate activities with other divisions and City departments; operate a personal computer and applicable software including graphics and desktop publishing systems; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle where required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.

Bi-lingual ability is highly desirable.

Graphic Design experience is highly desirable.

Photography and videography experience are highly desirable.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item(s) above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the City's Communications Specialist. These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.

title: Maintenance Coordinator
description:
Job title: Maintenance Coordinator

Job Summary

DEFINITION 

 

Under general direction, plans and coordinates the operations, maintenance, and repair of the City’s infrastructure including, streets, curbs, traffic safety, storm drain systems, landscaping, and irrigation systems, and performs related work as required. 

 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS 

 

The Maintenance Coordinator is an entry level position serving within the Public Works/Engineering Department assisting with the implementation of the City’s landscape and facilities programs as well as the road maintenance and repair program. Assignments are broad in scope and require adherence to the maintenance and road repair schedules, fiscal responsibility, effectively executing tasks, accountability for assignments, and awareness of surrounding environment and neighborhood needs. 

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 

 

Receives direction from the Public Works Director/City Engineer, Maintenance & Operations Manager, Public Works Superintendent, or designee. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

 

 

1. Plan, schedule, prioritize, and assign maintenance work in consultation with assigned supervisor and lead-level staff; communicate status of projects and activities to appropriate staff and contractors; work cooperatively to schedule in accordance with established priorities. 

 

2. Inspect assigned City infrastructure, facilities, and right-of-way areas for maintenance needs, streets, sidewalks, gutters, storm drains, signals, and various other facilities for conformance with specifications and regulations and recommends appropriate actions; assist in developing short- and long-range work plans, procedures, and schedules. 

  

3. Train employees and contractors in work method, use of tools and equipment, and relevant safety precautions; confirm plant materials and irrigation equipment are to contract specifications. 

 

4. Make field inspections to ensure acceptable maintenance service levels and completed work is in conformance with departmental standards, contracts, and specification; evaluate work quality.  

 

5. Serve as liaison between contractors and city staff; resolves minor complaints.  

 

6. Conduct research, compile technical data, and prepare reports, or direct such activity, regarding maintenance projects and programs; assist in the preparation of cost estimates and specifications.  

 

7. Provide technical assistance as necessary; research and prepare technical and administrative reports; prepare written correspondence. 

 

8. Inspect a variety of landscape maintenance, renovation, and repair projects including mowing, trimming, pruning, planting, irrigation, fertilization, pest control, lighting repairs, fencing, graffiti removal, and various other activities; observe work during progress and upon completion; ensure that safety procedures are followed; ensure compliance with applicable codes, ordinances, regulations, and specifications.  

 

9. Prepare various inspection reports as required; maintain files, reports, and logs regarding inspection and plan check activities and findings; record amounts of materials used, and work performed. 

 

10. Provide information to the public; respond to and resolve difficult and sensitive citizen inquiries and complaints. 




11. Coordinate, inspect, maintain records, and ensure compliance to specifications, terms, and conditions for facility maintenance work performed under contract by contractors, subcontractors, and service/maintenance vendors within the public works and maintenance operations departments.  

 

12. Coordinate building maintenance services, preventative maintenance and repair activities with other City departments and outside agencies. 

 

13. Assist reviewal of both public and private land development project plans and drawings, confers with engineers, contractors, and City staff regarding projects and project problems; provides technical advice and assistance; and evaluates work and makes change recommendations based on observation and operational problems.  

 

14. Identify potential hazards and safety issues related to City facilities and recommend improvements to minimize liability. 

 

15. Monitor developments related to equipment maintenance, evaluate their impact, and implement policy and procedure improvements; provides technical assistance to staff. 

 

16. Establish positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public. 

 

17. Assume responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner. 

 

18. Provide back-up support to other office staff as required.  

 

19. Perform related duties as assigned.  

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES 

 

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:  

 

Qualifications: 

 

Graduation from high school or equivalent, and three years of progressive experience in landscape and grounds maintenance; facilities management and/or building maintenance, project management, construction management. 

 

License/Certificate:   

 

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record. 

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES 

 

Knowledge of: 

 

Operational characteristics, services, and activities of a maintenance in facilities and landscape, construction, installation and repair programs; organization and management practices as applied to the evaluation of maintenance operations programs, policies and operation needs; modern and complex principles and practices of municipal maintenance operations; services program development and administration; principles and practices of public works maintenance operations and facilities; and their application to a wide variety of operational programs; hazardous material containment and disposal principles and practices; specification writing principles and practices; preparation and evaluation of "Requests for Proposal" for services; principles and practices of contract administration; principles of municipal budget preparation and control; principles of supervision, training, and performance evaluation; principles and procedures of record keeping; principles of business letter writing and report preparation; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications such as word processing, spreadsheets, and databases; pertinent federal, state and local laws, codes, and regulations. Customer service and customer relations practices and principles. English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; principles and practices of sound business communications; safe work methods and safety regulations. 




Ability to:  

 

Display interpersonal communication; analyze situations accurately and adopt an effective course of action as necessary; perform responsible administrative work; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; research, design, prepare, and evaluate plans, and specifications for accuracy and conformance with accepted standards, compliance with appropriate laws, codes, regulations, and community needs; examine plans, specifications, designs, cost estimates, and legal descriptions for a variety of landscape, irrigation, and City facility projects; provide technical expertise for projects, evaluate alternatives, make sound recommendations, and prepare technical reports; organize, schedule, the work of contractors; interpret, apply, explain, and ensure compliance with Federal, State, and local policies, procedures, laws, and regulations; understand, and successfully communicate both orally and in writing, pertinent department policies and procedures; and legal guidelines; establish, maintain, and foster positive and harmonious working relationships with those contacted in the course of work. 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 

 

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required. 

 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

 

Physical Demands: 

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, climb, stoop, kneel, bend, lean, turn, twist, reach, grasp, push, and pull on even, uneven and slippery surfaces and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office and field equipment; and reach with hands and arms. Lift, carry, and push objects weighing up to 50 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business. 

 

Mental Demands: 

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work. 

 

WORKING CONDITIONS 

 

The employee typically works in an office environment. The employee also works in the field and will be exposed to loud noise levels, cold and hot temperatures, inclement weather conditions, road hazards, vibration, construction equipment, and mechanical and/or electrical hazards. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and other related matters.  These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays.  Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events.  

 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER 

 

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Analyst
description:
Job title: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Analyst

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, performs complex professional-level work in the design, development, implementation, and maintenance of the City’s Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and spatial databases. Provides mapping, analysis, and data management services to support a variety of City projects, programs, and decision-making processes. Serves as a technical resource to City staff and the public in the use of GIS data and applications. Performs related duties as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is a journey-level classification responsible for independently performing complex GIS analysis, cartographic design, and spatial database management. Incumbents are expected to exercise independent judgment, manage multiple projects, and apply GIS best practices in support of City operations, planning, and public services. This classification is distinguished by its responsibility for advanced spatial data analysis, system integration, and GIS application development.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Public Works Director/City Engineer or designee; provides guidance or project-based support to other departmental staff, may exercise lead capacity over other administrative staff as assigned. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  


1. Designs, develops, updates, and maintains GIS software applications and databases for the creation, deployment, and maintenance of maps and related spatial data in paper, digital, and web formats.

2. Coordinates with City departments, outside agencies, and consultants to assess, define, and fulfill mapping and GIS data needs, ensuring data layers are accurate, complete, and consistent with City standards.

3. Interprets and analyzes information from recorded maps, deeds, land grants, engineering plans, and other documents to develop and maintain GIS layers and data elements.

4. Produces a variety of standard and custom maps, reports, atlases, diagrams, exhibits, and displays; applies effective cartographic design principles, including projection, scale, color, and symbology.

5. Integrates GIS with other City systems and databases, such as asset management systems, and supports data sharing across platforms and applications.

6. Performs quality control and assurance of GIS data to maintain accuracy, integrity, and compliance with applicable standards.

7. Provides technical support, training, and guidance to end users; explains technical concepts to non-technical audiences and assists with data access and interpretation.

8. Researches, evaluates, and recommends new GIS tools, technologies, and enhancements to improve efficiency and system capabilities.

9. Prepares and maintains GIS-related documentation, metadata, and records in accordance with City policies and retention requirements.

10. Responds to inquiries and requests for GIS-related information from City staff, contractors, consultants, agencies, and the public.

11. Stays abreast of emerging trends, best practices, and innovations in GIS to ensure the City’s systems remain current and effective.

12. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

13. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in geographic information systems, geography, computer science, cartography, civil engineering, or a closely related field; and three (3) years of increasingly responsible experience in the design, development, implementation, and maintenance of GIS systems, applications, and relational databases. A GIS Professional (GISP) certification is highly desirable.




License/Certificate

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Principles, practices, and techniques of geographic information systems (GIS), including spatial data development, cartography, and geospatial analysis; GIS software and applications, and related tools; principles and practices of GIS database management, data integrity, and quality control; methods and techniques for integrating GIS with other City systems and relational databases; cartographic design elements including projection, scale, color, and symbology; methods and techniques of spatial analysis, data modeling, and report generation; applicable Federal, State, and local laws, codes, and regulations related to mapping, data management, and public records; research methods and techniques; principles and practices of sound business communication; correct English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; modern office practices, methods, and procedures; computer applications and software including word processing, spreadsheets, and specialized GIS tools; and safe work methods and safety regulations.




Ability to:

Design, develop, and maintain GIS data layers, databases, and applications; produce clear and accurate maps, reports, and spatial analyses; interpret, explain, and apply applicable laws, regulations, policies, and procedures related to GIS; analyze and interpret complex spatial and tabular data; perform technical research and prepare clear, accurate, and comprehensive reports, exhibits, and documentation; operate a computer using word processing, spreadsheet, and GIS software at an advanced level; train and assist end users in accessing and interpreting GIS data; organize and prioritize multiple tasks and projects to meet deadlines; exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; communicate clearly and effectively, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City staff, management, outside agencies, and the public; provide excellent customer service; and skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.  




Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this position, the employee may be required to sit for extended periods and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone. The employee may use hands and fingers to handle, touch, feel, and operate standard office equipment and reach with hands and arms in the course of performing routine tasks. Occasional reaching above or below desk level and lifting or carrying of records and documents, typically weighing up to 20 pounds, may also be required. Specific vision abilities that may be necessary for this position include close vision, and the ability to adjust focus.




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the incumbent.   These hours may include but are not limited to weekends, evenings and holidays. A generally clean work environment with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. 




DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Associate Engineer
description:
Job title: Associate Engineer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, to perform a variety of highly responsible professional engineering work involving the research, design and construction of public works & engineering activities; reviews plans, evaluates costs, conducts field reviews, and participates in the preparation of engineering reports; and performs related duties as assigned.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

Positions in this class perform entry journey level assignments and are responsible for independent engineering analyses and recommendations. This classification performs varied engineering assignments requiring knowledge of civil engineering principles, design standards, and construction regulations. The Associate Engineer differs from the Senior Engineer in that the Associate Engineer exercises general supervision over paraprofessional, technical, and administrative support staff.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the City Engineer, or designee. May exercise general supervision over paraprofessional, technical, and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.
Directs plan check activities, assigns projects and directs coordination between the City and engineering consultants; directs record keeping and tracking; ensures expeditious processing.
Prepares requests for proposal and performs contract administration for engineering consultants and evaluates their performance; makes construction contract modifications and negotiates contract change orders; reviews billings; projects costs; may assist in developing and administering the engineering budget.
Responds to inquiries and investigates complaints; provides technical expertise and coordinates activities with outside agencies and the public.
Gathers technical data required for the planning of a wide variety of engineering projects; prepares staff reports and recommendations related to engineering projects.
Reviews traffic accident reports and statistics; develops policies and plans for traffic signs and signal systems; coordinates city street plans and traffic flow with highways and freeways.
Reviews, makes comments and recommendations regarding proposed projects by checking plans, maps, related studies and supporting data for concept, design, and compliance with regulations; recommends conditions of approval for projects.
Prepares and reviews plans, specifications, and estimates; prepares and processes legal documents required for project completion.
Serves as staff to the City Council and Planning Commission when assigned; participates in staff project meetings; participates in discussions or makes presentations regarding engineering projects.
Meets with developers to define project objectives and prescribe standards; attempts to resolve conflicts between developers and staff; meets with neighborhood groups to discuss plans and obtain feedback; enforces City policies and procedures.
Directs staff in survey, mapping, and data collection activities; assigns routine investigation, design, and drafting tasks, and provides direction in resolving problems.
Researches and identifies project design requirements for particular elements, including hydrology, traffic and soils reports and calculations as well as grading plans, sewer plans, water plans, streets plans, traffic studies, and other documents, including plans, parcel and tract maps, and studies; reviews drawings and details of construction and implementation plans; prepares conditions for approval.
Assists and provides technical guidance to inspectors in studying field problems and incorporating design revisions during grading and construction phases based on site inspections.
Prepares construction inspection reports, non-compliance letters, bond and fee letters and developer credits as well as environmental status reports, and public education materials.
Conducts field reviews and prepares quarterly progress reports and staff reports; prepares project check lists, deeds, and exhibits; drafts and revises associated ordinances and resolutions; reviews and processes change orders.
Assists in the development of BMP guidelines for engineering projects.
Administers consultant and construction contracts; investigates field problems affecting property owners, contractors, and maintenance operations; prepares quarterly progress reports; reviews and coordinates the submission and approval of construction specifications; ensures compliance with plan specifications.
Coordinates right-of-way projects with utilities and affected parties; conducts plan checks of lot-line adjustments.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.
Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college with a bachelor's degree in civil engineering, or a closely related field. Three or more years of responsible professional civil engineering experience in a municipal setting, including experience with public works projects; or an equivalent combination of training and experience.

License/Certificate:

A California Class C Driver's License or the ability to obtain a valid license.

Possession of valid certification as a Civil Engineer issued by the California State Board
of Registration for Civil and Professional engineers is desirable.

Possession of a certification as an Engineer in Training (EIT) is highly desireable.

Membership in American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Public Works Association (APWA), and related groups is highly desirable.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Modern principles, procedures, practices and standards of municipal civil engineering; land development, surveying methods and techniques; municipal engineering laws, ordinances, codes, specifications and plans; engineering project inspection methods; water and wastewater systems/plants; modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding engineering; principles and practices of contract administration; traffic engineering fundamentals and use of standard equipment used in the engineering profession; communications techniques; cost estimation practices; engineering principles and practices as applied to public works, including planning and development, design, and construction; methods and techniques utilized in the preparation of public works project designs and related plans, specifications, and cost estimates; related federal and state laws, ordinances and regulations; standard office procedures, practices and equipment; modern office equipment, including a computer and applicable software; methods and techniques for record keeping and report preparation and writing; proper English, spelling and grammar; occupational hazards and standard safety practices

Ability to:

Operate computer terminal and use computer-aided design, mapping, spreadsheet and word processing programs; review and prepare engineering plans, specifications and design requirements; analyze and interpret legal contracts and work agreements; prepare and evaluate engineering data; organize and prioritize tasks to meet deadlines; prepare clear and concise reports, drawings, maps, notes, correspondence and other written materials; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships with staff, management, public and private representatives, contractors, architects, developers, and others in the course of work; perform professional engineering work, including project design; direct the work of others involved in related activity; interpret and apply related laws, ordinances, and regulations; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; prepare and maintain records and reports; meet the public in situations requiring diplomacy and tact; deal constructively with conflict and develop effective resolutions; communicate effectively both orally and in writing; establish and maintain cooperative working relationships.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed, and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment and occasionally works in a construction site and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Associate Engineer. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. Employees may occasionally work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or electrical hazards.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.
