title: Temporary Code Enforcement Officer
description:
Job title: Temporary Code Enforcement Officer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general supervision, performs field inspections and investigations related to property maintenance violations, zoning, and housing code violations. Performs research and writes reports regarding zoning and municipal code violations, and facilitates special projects and assignments. 

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Code Enforcement Officer is the journey level classification in the Code Enforcement job series. It differs from the Senior Code Enforcement Officer position in that the incumbent performs less complex and more routine code enforcement activities. Incumbent demonstrates knowledge and experience in the performance of established procedures and protocols for code violation investigations and enforcement activities.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general supervision from the Code Enforcement Manager or designee. This position exercises no supervision. 

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Ensures compliance with State laws, City and County land use, housing, zoning, abatement, and nuisance codes and ordinances.

2. Responds to complaints and performs proactive patrols.

3. Prepares case files, documentation, and issues notices and citations.

4. Maintains accurate records and tracks enforcement efforts..

5. Prepares documentation for legal actions and testifies in court..

6. Schedules and conducts property inspections and seeks voluntary compliance. 

7. Coordinates with other departments and agencies. 

8.Provides the public with information regarding applicable codes and ordinances. 

9. Assists with street sweeping and parking enforcement.

10. Assists with writing warrants and abatements.

11. Provides excellent customer service and handles conflict with professionalism.    

12. Performs other related duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:
High School Diploma and two (2) years of experience as a Code Enforcement Officer or two (2) years of experience performing inspections, investigations, abatements, land use, zoning, building, public safety, related code enforcement or administration of justice work.  The completion of up to one year of college (30 semester units) in a related field from an accredited college or university may substitute for up to one year of experience. 

License/Certificate:
Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.
Criminal background checks are conducted post-offer and in compliance with the Fair Chance Act. 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:
State and local laws and ordinances related to land use and zoning. Investigation techniques and enforcement practices.  Case documentation and reporting. Office software and enforcement-related technology.   Safety procedures and public relations practices.

Ability to:
Interpret and apply codes and regulations. Conduct investigations and prepare reports. Testify in legal proceedings.  Communicate clearly and effectively.  Provide high-level customer service. Work independently and manage priorities

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Possession of a P.C. 832 Peace Officer’s Standard and Training (POST) Certificate is required at the time of employment or must be obtained within six (6) months of employment. 

Possession of a Certified Code Enforcement Officer (CCEO) Designation is required at the time of hire, but incumbent may be provided with one (1) year to obtain the designation if they have an equivalent (non-CACEO) designation.  

Possession of relevant certifications from CACEO, ICC, AACE, or equivalent is highly desirable.
Ability to work evenings, weekends, and holidays, as needed. 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this job with or without reasonable accommodation.

Physical Demands:
Frequent walking, climbing, balancing, sitting, standing, bending, kneeling, and entering/exiting vehicles. Occasional lifting and carrying of objects up to 25 pounds. Visual and auditory acuity for inspections and communication. Manual dexterity for computer and enforcement equipment use.

Mental Demands:
Ability to manage multiple tasks, respond to public inquiries, and resolve complaints. Must maintain attention to detail and follow established procedures. 

Ability to exercise judgment, prioritize work, and handle interactions with the public in potentially stressful situations. 

WORKING CONDITIONS

Work is performed in a combination of indoor office settings and outdoor field environments, including exposure to varying weather conditions such as heat, cold, rain, and wind. Field work may involve exposure to noise, dust, traffic, animals, and potentially unpleasant property conditions. The employee may drive a city vehicle throughout the community to assist with inspections and parking enforcement activities. Office work includes using a computer, phone, and standard office equipment to support case documentation and research. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Code Enforcement Technician
description:
Job title: Code Enforcement Technician

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under close to general supervision, to perform routine field inspections and investigations related to property maintenance violations, zoning and housing code violations; to perform research and write reports regarding zoning and municipal code violations; to carry out special projects and assignments; and to perform related duties as required.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Community Enhancement Technician is an entry level classification in the Community Enhancement job series. It differs from the Community Enhancement Officer position in that the incumbent performs less complex and more routine code enforcement responsibilities while learning enforcement procedures for State and City codes and the rules and regulations of the Community Enhancement & Safety Division.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives close to general supervision from the Community Enhancement & Safety Manager or designee.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

Learns to enforce and apply the Zoning and Municipal Code, Uniform Housing Code, and other related codes and regulations relating to community preservation, health and safety.
Learns and performs field investigations, takes on-site photographs, prepares diagrams and measurements of residential, commercial and industrial properties in assisting in the implementation of the City's Community Enhancement & Safety program.
Learns to determine if development projects compliant with zoning ordinances and regulations.
Advises applicants, homeowners or developers of the City's requirements and the correct procedures to be taken to ensure compliance; responds to citizen complaints.
Prepares written daily reports and maintains accurate records and files.
Assists in the preparation of code violation cases for presentation at public hearings, City Council meetings and judicial proceedings under the direction of his/her supervisor; and appear as a witness in court regarding violation cases.
Participates in joint inspections of properties with other agencies and City departments.
Researches property ownership and zoning, building and parcel histories.
Learns to interpret building and planning project entitlements; compiles statistics.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

High school diploma or equivalent. The completion of college level coursework related to building and construction and/or code enforcement is highly desirable. Two years of experience in performing responsible public contact work, and/or experience in construction, code enforcement, permit issuance or other building and construction related activities is preferred.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

Operations and organizational structure of municipal government; principles and practices of research and report preparation; modern office procedures, methods and equipment including computers and supporting software applications; English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; principles and practices of filing and record keeping; methods and techniques of public relations and customer service; safe and efficient work practices as they relate to code enforcement.

Ability to:

Learn, interpret and apply zoning and land use regulations and planning concepts to unusual or difficult zoning or municipal code violations; learn and understand rules of evidence related to public hearing and judicial cases; compile and analyze technical information; learn and apply investigative techniques; maintain and follow department policies and procedures; operate and use modern office equipment including a computer and various software packages; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; ensure safety standards are met; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work; delivery quality customer service; work independently and as a team member.

Special Requirements

Possession of a P.C. 832 Peace Officer's Standard and Training (POST) Certificate is highly desirable at the time of employment, or must be obtained within one year of employment.

Possession of any combination of certifications are highly desirable including those from the Statewide California Association of Code Enforcement Officials (SCACEO), California Association of Code Enforcement (CACE), American Association of Code Enforcement (AACE) or certification as a Zoning Enforcement Officer, and/or Property Maintenance and Housing Inspector.

Ability to work weekends, evenings and attend special events as needed is required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. 

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is frequently climbing, balancing, reaching, sitting, standing, stooping, kneeling, crouching, walking, talking, seeing, hearing, smelling, and manual dexterity. Occasional lifting and carrying up to 20 pounds. Work is typically performed in both standard office and outdoor environments, with potential exposure to adverse weather conditions. Work is occasionally performed in high and precarious places and near moving mechanical parts. Occasional exposure to the risk of electric shock, fumes, airborne particles, infectious diseases, and criminal suspects. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee may be required to deal constructively with conflict and in developing effective resolutions.

WORKING CONDITIONS 

Generally clean work environment with regular exposure to conditions such as rain, heat and strong winds, and limited exposure to dust, fumes, odors or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale Employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Accounting Technician
description:
Job title: Accounting Technician

Job Summary

DEFINITION 




Under close to general supervision, to assist in performing a variety of routine and responsible accounting related functions in billing, cashiering, accounts payable, accounts receivable, purchasing, permits, registrations, and related functions; to receive and process payments, and verify account and application information; to explain procedures by telephone and in-person; to perform clerical work in connection with the City's financial record keeping; and to perform related duties as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS 




The Accounting Technician is the entry/journey level class within the Accounting Technician series and is expected to learn to perform the full range of assigned finance related duties and responsibilities at the journey level. Incumbents within this classification initially perform routine and less complex accounting related responsibilities, however, steadily receive more complex duties as experience is gained. Employees in this class normally work under close and continuous supervision performing repetitive or closely related duties according to established procedures. This classification is distinguished from the Senior Accounting Technician in that an incumbent is expected to perform assigned duties under direct supervision as they learn their positions.




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED 




Receives close to general supervision from the Finance Director/ City Treasurer or designee.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Maintains various ledgers, registers, journals, and logs according to generally accepted accounting principles.

2. Assists with billing, cashiering, accounts payable, accounts receivable, purchasing, permits, registrations, and other department functions, as assigned or required.

3. Performs various routine financial tasks, including: preparing basic level financial and statistical reports; making bank deposits; processing checks; preparing checks; assisting with reconciling ledgers and reports; counting and distributing petty cash; posting charges and credits to various accounts, or special projects, as assigned.

4. Responds to the public, in person, by telephone, or by e-mail.

5. Performs various general clerical duties, such as: maintaining files, records and supplies; retrieving and filing of records; processing business registrations.

6. Uses spreadsheet software to keep financial records and to process documents involved in financial transactions; processes invoices for payment.

7. May assist in audit preparation and site visits.

8. Drafts correspondence.

9. Conducts cross-training with other clerical functions to cover the duties of other office staff during absences, as needed.

10. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

11. Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from high school or satisfactory equivalent, supplemented by college level coursework in accounting or related field, and one year of general or accounting clerical experience, including some statistical or financial record keeping. Municipal accounting experience preferred.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of:

General accounting and financial record keeping practices; procedures, methods, and office equipment used in statistical record keeping; principles, methods and practices of accounts receivable, accounts payable, and customer account record keeping work; customer service practices and business communications techniques; safe work methods and safety regulations.

Ability to:

Perform routine clerical, financial record keeping; make arithmetic calculations quickly and with accuracy; operate a computer using word processing and spreadsheet software; type accurately at a speed necessary to meet the requirements of the position; organize, set priorities and exercise sound judgment within areas of responsibility; work independently; handle a high volume of customer questions and concerns in person and by telephone; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; understand and follow written and oral instructions; prepare clear, accurate and concise financial records and reports; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City Manager, management, staff, the public, and others encountered in the course of work; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands: 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS 

The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required in order to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and other related matters. These hours may include, but are not limited to: weekends, evenings and holidays. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events.

title: Senior Streets Maintenance Worker
description:
Job title: Senior Streets Maintenance Worker

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under close supervision, performs skilled work in the construction, maintenance, and repair of streets, curbs, gutters, storm drains, streetlights, and related public works infrastructure; operates a variety of light, medium, and heavy-duty motorized maintenance and construction equipment; and performs related duties as assigned.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

This is the journey level classification within the Street Maintenance Worker series. This classification is distinguished from the Street Maintenance Worker position by the latter’s performance of more routine maintenance and skilled work.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives direction from the Public Works Superintendent or designee. May exercise technical and functional direction over other internal or external crews.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.

1. Performs and leads the work of staff engaged in construction and maintenance of city owned properties including streets, sidewalks, storm water and drainage systems, street sweeping, graffiti abatement, traffic signage, striping, traffic control, irrigation systems, traffic signal systems, electrical systems, and fiber systems and other related duties.

2. Performs and directs the breaking and removal of pavements; digs, shovels, hauls and loads soils, sand, gravel, cement, asphalt mixes and other materials, tools, and equipment; cleans up work sites upon completion of job.

3. Performs and directs the operation of various types and sizes of trucks and motorized equipment, such as dump trucks, tractors, skip loaders, bobcats, backhoes, front loaders, jackhammer, and other power tools; inspects vehicles and reports maintenance as required.

4. Operates and directs the use of air compressor and pneumatic air tools, including breaking guns and concrete saws; uses hand tools including shovels, picks, brooms, wheelbarrows, rakes and rollers, and a variety of small hand tools for a variety of trades.

5. Drives vehicles to work sites and sets up and removes barricades to protect crews from street traffic including lane closures and DUI checkpoints; directs traffic in roadways to protect crews.

6. Removes and installs street lighting poles and fixtures; removes and/or paints over graffiti on private and public property; assists in the fabrication, assembly, and installation of traffic signs.

7. Performs storm drain maintenance, removes, and replaces drains; cleans and removes debris from drains.

8. Organizes and maintains assigned equipment and tools; inspects, cleans, and performs preventative maintenance to ensure operability and reliability of equipment and tools.

9. Reviews equipment and materials required for daily maintenance and work projects; initiates request for or purchases approved materials and supplies.

10. Prepares and/or maintains activity records, logs, work orders, material requests, reports and/or technical documentation for equipment or street maintenance systems.

11. Determines and recommends equipment, materials, staffing, safety needs, devices, and/or equipment for assigned operation, maintenance, and improvement projects.

12. Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.

13. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position and crew are performed in a safe, efficient manner.

14. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.

15. Performs related Public Works duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:
Equivalent to a High School Diploma or GED and three years of street maintenance or construction experience.
License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class “A” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:
Safety equipment and work practices related to the work, including excavation, trenching/shoring, and confined space entry; proper operation and maintenance of hand and power tools, vehicles and light and heavy equipment; basic methods, materials, tools and equipment used in the construction, installation, maintenance and repair of streets, water, sewer and storm drainage lines, mains and services; basic methods for removal, replacement, and application of road surfacing materials; basic methods of locating underground utility services and related notification requirements; basic principles and practices of water/wastewater systems and equipment; basic principles and practices of carpentry work; basic knowledge of plumbing and construction techniques; basic knowledge of work zone safety including OSHA, heat awareness, first aid, and CPR; basic mathematical computations; techniques for dealing effectively with those contacted in the course of work, both in person and on the telephone.

Ability to:
Perform construction, maintenance and repair work on streets, water distribution and wastewater collection systems, infrastructure and equipment; operate and maintain tools, vehicles, and equipment used in the construction, maintenance, repair, installation and monitoring of City streets and utilities systems and infrastructure; set up and operate traffic area construction zones, including cones, barricades and flagging; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; read, understand and interpret written instructions; follow oral and written instructions; physically perform frequent, heavy manual labor using safe work practices; operate computer devices using standard and customized software applications appropriate to assigned tasks; maintain effective and cooperative working relationships with City staff, departments, outside agencies, commercial vendors, and the general public.

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

May be required to be on-call and to work various shifts or emergencies on evenings, weekends, and holidays.
Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required.
Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:
While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, climb, stoop, kneel, bend, lean, turn, twist, reach, grasp, push, and pull on even, uneven and slippery surfaces and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office and field equipment; and reach with hands and arms. Lift, carry, and push objects weighing up to 100 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:
While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

Work is performed in confined spaces and outdoor construction and maintenance environments with moderate to high noise levels, hot and cold temperatures, inclement weather conditions, road hazards, loud noise levels, vibration, confining workspace, chemicals, mechanical and/or electrical hazards, and hazardous physical substances and fumes. Employees use power and noise producing equipment and often work with constant interruptions. Employees may interact with upset staff and/or public and private representatives in interpreting and enforcing departmental policies and procedures.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Senior Engineer
description:
Job title: Senior Engineer

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, performs varied professional engineering work involving the research, design and construction of public works projects; reviews plans, evaluates costs, conducts field reviews, and participates in the preparation of engineering reports; conducts complicated engineering planning, design, and investigation; and performs related duties as assigned.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Senior Engineer is the advanced, journey-level classification in the professional engineering series. Positions within this classification typically lead and perform the most complex professional engineering work. Incumbents have continuing liaisons with developers, contractors, consultants, and support larger projects. This classification oversees a large range of assignments and requires specialized professional knowledge and the ability to exercise independent judgment and initiative in scheduling, assigning, planning, and coordinating the work with that of other units. The Senior Engineer differs from the Associate Engineer in that the Senior Engineer exercises direct and indirect, supervision over professional, paraprofessional, technical, and field staff.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the City Engineer, or designee. Exercises direct and indirect supervision over professional, technical, and field staff.

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class. Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.
Performs complex studies of technical, environmental, and economic feasibility, engineering field studies, and related studies pertaining to proposed and existing facility improvements.
Develop, update, and approve technical directives for the department to include Engineering Guidelines, Standard Drawings, Standard Specifications, and other technical and administrative policies and procedures as applicable; develops and revises engineering procedures, policies, standards, and guidelines as they relate to projects.
Prepare and review economic analyses, street and highway planning analyses and designs, basic civil engineering related structural analyses, hydraulic and hydrogeologic analyses and project justification reports.
Make decisions independently on technical problems and methods related to the work being performed.
Coordinates City Engineering activities with other divisions, departments, consultants, contractors, engineers, and outside agencies; advises the Community Development Director, City Engineer, and City Council on technical matters.
Review project plans and specifications involving hydrology, traffic and soils reports, and calculations as well as grading plans, sewer plans, water and waste water facility plans, street plans, traffic studies, soils reports, and other documents, including plans, parcel and tract maps, and studies; reviews drawings and details of construction and implementation plans; prepares conditions of approval.
Participates in the preparation of cost estimates, construction specifications and financial reports; prepares operating, management, and capital improvement budget estimates, and administers project budget expenses in relation to tasks and schedules; administers plan checks and calculates and administers development fee impact assessments and updates.
Prepares RFP's and RFQ's, evaluates proposals, selects consultants, and administers construction projects.
Attend public hearings, committee meetings, and workshops and acts as a liaison between staff, developers, contractors, consultants, and the public in matters involving engineering planning, construction, cost updates, reimbursement agreements, and capital improvements design.
Prepares construction inspection reports, non-compliance letters, bond and fee letters, and developer credits, as well as environmental status reports, and public education materials; prepares fixed asset reports.
Monitors and keeps informed of current trends in the field of municipal engineering including legislation, court rulings and professional practices and techniques; evaluates their impact and makes recommendations to the City Engineer regarding policy and procedural modifications accordingly.
Gathers, interprets, and prepares data for studies, reports and recommendations; coordinates division activities with other departments and agencies as needed to provide integrated services.
Gives presentations to the City Council, boards, commissions, civic groups, and the public as needed and assigned.
Represents the City, Community Development Department, and/or Engineering Division while providing support to a variety of City commissions, neighboring jurisdictions, boards and committees, and various City Council sub-committees.
Assists in development of the Division's annual budget and work programs; allocates staff and resources among work program priorities.
Supervises, trains, and evaluates paraprofessional, technical, and clerical personnel, as assigned; makes effective recommendations regarding promotion, transfer, and disciplinary action of assigned personnel.
Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Provides back-up support to other office staff as required
Performs other related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be:

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree in Civil Engineering and registration in California as a Professional Engineer; and four or more years of responsible professional civil engineering experience, including experience with public works projects and three years of supervisory experience; or an equivalent combination of training and experience. A master's degree in a field related to Civil Engineering is highly desirable.

License/Certificate:

Possession of a valid Class "C" California driver's license and a satisfactory driving record.

Registration as a Professional Civil Engineer (P.E.) with the California State Board of Registration for Civil and Professional Engineers required.

Membership in American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), American Public Works Association (APWA), and related groups is highly desirable.

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of:

Principles and practices of civil engineering and other engineering disciplines used in the municipal engineering field; Subdivision Map Act, Uniform Building Code, Caltrans Design Manual, Green Book Specifications Manual; grading and subdivision design ordinances and standards; water supply, pumping, storage, and distribution, wastewater, collection treatment, and disposal, hydrology, hydraulics, and soil mechanisms principles; surveying standards and practices; strength, properties, and uses of construction materials; legal guidelines for construction and environmental engineering projects; City Municipal code and related standards, modern methods and techniques used in the design and construction of a wide variety of municipal projects; modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding civil and municipal engineering; applicable laws and regulatory codes relevant to design and construction of municipal facilities; cost estimation practices; budgeting and grant administration practices; principles of supervision, training, and performance evaluation, methods and techniques for record keeping and report preparation and writing; proper English, spelling, and grammar; Methods and techniques for report preparation and writing; occupational hazards and standard safety practices.

Ability to:

Analyze complex engineering issues and develop solutions; plan, organize, direct and evaluate the effectiveness of assigned program activities; exercise supervisory control over complex professional and technical tasks, and perform the full range of professional engineering tasks; interpret, explain and apply applicable laws, codes and regulations pertaining to municipal engineering; make adjustments to standard operating procedures to improve effectiveness and comply with regulatory changes as appropriate; organize, prioritize and follow-up on work assignments; work independently and as part of a team; make sound decisions within established guidelines; analyze complex issues and develop and implement an appropriate response; follow written and oral directions; promote and observe safety principles and work in a safe manner; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City personnel and the public; operate an office computer and a variety of word processing and software applications.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment and occasionally works in a construction site and field environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City's needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Senior Engineer. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required. Employees may occasionally work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or electrical hazards.

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER

In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Senior Management Analyst
description:
Job title: Senior Management Analyst

Job Summary

DEFINITION




Under general direction, to perform a variety of difficult and/or complex professional administrative and analytical generalist duties in support of an assigned department; to manage programs that have City-wide or department impact; to conduct complex and sensitive studies and prepare detailed reports and recommendations; to conduct special projects, financial analysis, grant research, special functions coordination; and to perform related work as assigned.  




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS




This is the advanced journey level class within the Management Analyst series. This class is distinguished from the Management Analyst by the performance of advanced journey level duties and by the difficulty and complexity of work performed.   An incumbent in this class is expected to frequently and independently carry out general administrative assignments and refers to supervisory personnel only those matters which involve policy decisions, technical questions, and unusual public relations problems. Discretion is required in applying general goal and policy statements, and in resolving organizational and service delivery problems. Latitude is necessary in administering a complex and sensitive area of responsibility. 




SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED




Receives general direction from the City Manager, Director, and/or designee; may exercise general supervision over para-professional, technical, and administrative support staff as assigned.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS




Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.   Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  

1. Conducts and performs assigned administrative, fiscal, or operational project activities, prepares and maintains records, performs research and analysis as required; prepares and presents reports of findings and recommendations on programs managed, operating and organizational procedures, and cost comparisons.

2. Performs a variety of duties related to special assignments and projects; leads or participates in committee activities, contributing views and interests of the City or department, and represents the City in relations with the community, local, federal, and state agencies, and professional organizations; makes presentations relating to areas of assignment and attends community events.

3. Reviews, analyzes, and develops recommendations regarding state and federal legislation; monitors and ensures timely compliance with regulatory matters and reporting requirements.

4. Collects, organizes, analyzes, and interprets data relating to operations, policies, functions, organizational structure, forms. and procedures; prepares organization and workflow charts and drafts procedures manuals.

5. Takes a lead role in budget preparation, analysis, and administration; reviews departmental budget requests; investigates proposals for new programs, services, equipment, and personnel; conducts financial studies and prepares revenue estimates and forecasts; coordinates and processes department invoices.

6. Conducts or completes complex surveys as directed; responds to inquiries regarding City operations and programs; provides explanation of City-wide activities, policies, and procedures.

7. Coordinates and prepares City Council reports and resolutions, financial reports, requests for proposals, statistical tables, charts, and graphs; coordinates projects, programs, and studies with other City departments, public agencies, and contractors; serves as liaison to the public in the execution of responsibilities.

8. Engages and communicates with federal, state, and local agencies on the funding of City projects; participates in grant writing and monitoring of grant administrative programs to ensure contract compliance.

9. Utilizes various computer applications and software packages at an advanced level; generates reports from a database or network system; creates documents using word processing software.

10. Supervises, trains, and evaluates para-professional, technical, and clerical personnel, as assigned; makes effective recommendations regarding promotion, transfer, and disciplinary action of assigned personnel.

11. Conducts various cross-training with other team members in order to provide coverage during absences; analyzes unusual situations and resolves them through application of management principles and practices, and in conjunction with upper management; recommends effective courses of action.

12. Responds to concerns, complaints, and other areas of improvement; requests additional information as needed. 

13. Provides back-up support to other office staff as required.

14. Performs other duties as assigned. 

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSES




Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.   A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 




Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree or equivalent in Political Science, Public Administration, Business Administration, or a closely related field.   Five (5) years of increasingly responsible governmental administrative experience.  A master’s degree or graduate level course work in a closely related field is highly desirable.    




License/Certificate

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.




KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES




Knowledge of:

Concepts, theories, principles, methods and practices of organizational and municipal government administration; cost accounting procedures, practices, and their relationship to budgeting; research and statistical methods; state, federal and local laws and regulations; report preparation and presentation methods; principles and techniques of project management; short and long range organizational planning; grant writing and application procedures; legal, ethical, and professional rules of conduct for public sector employees; computer software applications used to create spreadsheets and databases to analyze data; safe work methods and safety regulations; supervisory principles and practices. 




Ability to:

Organize, set priorities and exercise sound independent judgment within areas of responsibility; interpret, apply, explain, and reach sound decisions in accordance with policies and procedures; organize and maintain office and specialized files and records; initiate and compose correspondence as required related to assigned work; communicate clearly and effectively orally and in writing; exercise discretion when dealing with the public and employees on sensitive or confidential matters; understand and follow written and oral instructions; gather pertinent facts, making thorough analyses, and arriving at sound conclusions; report information in clear, complete, and logical form; work independently or as part of a team to organize and complete detailed assignments with minimal direction; conduct organizational and procedural studies and prepare comprehensive reports; recommend and implement goals and objectives for providing effective services; properly interpret and make decisions in accordance with laws, regulations, and policies; plan and present clear, concise, and effective presentations to executive management and the public using non-technical language; organize and maintain accurate records of activities and projects; prepare and administer an operating budget; direct various work activities consistent with goals and priorities; evaluate programs and services from an operational and productivity standpoint; establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work, including the City Manager, management, staff, other government officials, community groups, and the general public; apply safe work practices; provide excellent customer service; skillfully and safely operate a motor vehicle when required in the course of performing work duties; operate a computer using word processing, database and spreadsheet software at an advanced level. 

Special Requirements

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS




Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.




PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS




The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.




Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk, and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  




Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants, and others encountered in the course of work.




WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Senior Management Analyst. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. The employee may be required to travel using public transportation.  Generally, the environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Travel throughout the City is required.

title: Public Works Superintendent
description:
Job title: Public Works Superintendent

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, plans, directs, and coordinates the operations, maintenance, and repair of the City’s infrastructure including; streets, curbs, traffic safety, and storm drain systems; and performs related work as required.




DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Public Works Superintendent is a single incumbent managerial level (at-will) class serving within the Engineering Division exercising proactive responsibility for the development and implementation of the City’s Public Works maintenance and repair programs; and inspection program for both Public Works and Land Development projects. Responsibilities and assignments are broad in scope and require considerable independent judgment in areas related to managing projects, managing and adhering to maintenance schedule, proactiveness vs reactiveness, efficiently executing tasks, effectively executing tasks, economically executing tasks, accountability for assignments, moral decision making, awareness of surrounding environment, awareness of neighborhood needs, awareness of department goals and direction.. Significant knowledge of all types of Public Works related construction, inspection, and project management is required.

 

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives direction from the City Engineer or designee. Exercises general supervision over para-professional, technical and administrative support staff as assigned. 

Essential Functions

Class specifications are intended to present a descriptive list of the range of duties performed by employees in the class.  Specifications are not intended to reflect all duties performed within the job.  




1. Inspect various public works facilities including, streets, sidewalks, gutters, storm drains, signals, and various other facilities for conformance with specifications and regulations. 




2. Reviews both public and private land development project plans and drawings, confers with engineers, contractors, and City staff regarding projects and project problems; provides technical advice and assistance; and evaluates work and makes change recommendations based on observation and operational problems. 




3. Reads and interprets project plans and specifications for public works construction and industry standards, such as the Caltrans Standard Plans and Specifications as they apply to assigned projects.




4. Develops, implements, and monitors safe operating procedures and safety programs in the construction, maintenance, and operation of the City’s assets.




5. Manages, coordinates, and reviews long-range work plans for providing field maintenance, equipment maintenance, and related services.  




6. Inspect work quality and materials used in a variety of complex public works projects during various stages of construction to ensure compliance with applicable codes, ordinances, and regulations.




7. Inspects work and directs use of the most efficient methods, interprets, analyzes, and explains policies, procedures and programs. 




8. Conducts preliminary examination of plans and specifications of assigned projects; determines compliance with the provisions of the construction codes, ordinances, and regulations. 




9. Prepares complete and accurate inspection logs and reports; maintains files regarding inspection and plan check activities and findings.




10. Participates in the development of public works maintenance goals and objectives; recommends and implements policies, and plans activities involved in public works maintenance functions.




11. Conducts research, compiles technical data and prepares reports, or directs such activity, regarding maintenance projects and programs; assists in the preparation of cost estimates and specifications. 




12. Provides technical assistance as necessary; researches and prepares technical and administrative reports; prepares written correspondence.




13. Responds to and resolves difficult and sensitive citizen inquiries and complaints concerning construction and repair projects.




14. Serves as departmental liaison to other departments and outside agencies; meets with county, state, federal and other officials to resolve problems affecting public works programs and projects.




15. Assists with preparation of specifications, contracts and bids for services, supplies and equipment; issues requisitions for purchase orders; administers and oversees contracts and service agreements.




16. Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.




17. Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.




18. Provides back-up support to other field staff as required. 




19. Assists in development of the Division’s annual budget and work programs related to Public Works functions




20. Manages in house staff and/or consultants providing field services related to public works maintenance, inspection and complaints. 




21. Performs related duties as assigned.  

Experience, Training & License

A combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying.  A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

 

Minimum Qualifications:

 

Option 1: 

Education: Equivalent to a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university with major coursework in public administration, business administration, construction management, civil engineering or a related field and five years of progressively responsible experience in a variety of public works construction or maintenance activities in a municipal public works or closely related organization including three years in a supervisory capacity.

 

Option 2: 

Experience: Ten years of sub-professional civil engineering experience of progressively responsible experience in a variety of public works construction or maintenance activities in municipal public works including three years in a supervisory capacity. (One year of education from an accredited college or university in civil engineering or closely related subjects may substitute for up to two years of the non-specialized experience.) 




License/Certificate:  

Possession of a valid Class “C” California driver’s license and a satisfactory driving record.

 

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES

 

Knowledge of:




Operational characteristics, services, and activities of a maintenance, construction, and repair program; organization and management practices as applied to the evaluation of maintenance operations programs, policies and operation needs; modern and complex principles and practices of municipal maintenance operations; services program development and administration; principles and practices of public works maintenance operations and their application to a wide variety of operational programs; hazardous material containment and disposal principles and practices; specification writing principles and practices; preparation and evaluation of "Requests for Proposal" for services; principles and practices of contract administration; principles of municipal budget preparation and control; principles of supervision, training, and performance evaluation; principles and procedures of record keeping; principles of business letter writing and report preparation; office procedures, methods, and equipment including computers and applicable software applications such as word processing, spreadsheets, and databases; pertinent federal, state and local laws, codes, and regulations. English usage, spelling, grammar, and punctuation; principles and practices of sound business communications; safe work methods and safety regulations. 




Ability to:

 

Coordinate and direct maintenance programs; supervise, direct, and coordinate the work of lower level staff; select, supervise, train, and evaluate staff; recommend and implement goals, objectives, policies and procedures for providing maintenance services; understand the organization and operation of the City and of outside agencies as necessary to assume assigned responsibilities; understand, interpret, and apply general and specific administrative and departmental policies and procedures as well as applicable federal, state, and local policies, laws, and regulations; participate in the preparation and administration of assigned budgets; plan and organize work to meet changing priorities and deadlines; effectively represent the City to outside individuals and agencies to accomplish the goals and objectives of the unit; work cooperatively with other departments, City officials, and outside agencies; respond tactfully, clearly, concisely, and appropriately to inquiries from the public, City staff, or other agencies on sensitive issues in area of responsibility; interpret and explain City policies and procedures; prepare clear and concise reports; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; and establish and maintain effective working relationships with those contacted in the course of work.

Special Requirements

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings, and holidays, as required. 

 

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

 

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

 

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

 

Physical Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; stand and walk between work areas and conduct field inspections as appropriate and necessary, including traversing uneven terrain, climbing ladders, stairs, and other temporary construction access points; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for items above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus. Travel by vehicle while conducting City business.  

 

Mental Demands:

 

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, management, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

 

WORKING CONDITIONS




The employee typically works in an office environment and in a construction site and field environment. Generally, the office environment is clean with limited exposure to conditions such as dust, fumes, odors, or noise. Employees will work in the field and may be exposed to loud noise levels, dust, fumes, odors, inclement weather conditions, vibration, mechanical and/or other Public Works related hazards. Travel throughout the City is required. Non-traditional work hours may be required to accommodate the City’s needs including attendance at City Council meetings, City Commission meetings, special City events, and matters requiring the presence of the Public Works Superintendent. These hours may include, but are not limited to weekends, evenings, and holidays. 

DISASTER SERVICE WORKER




In accordance with Government Code Section 3100, City of Eastvale employees, in the event of a disaster, are considered disaster service workers and may be asked to respond accordingly.

title: Principal Planner
description:
Job title: Principal Planner

Job Summary

DEFINITION

Under general direction, to plan, manage, supervise, oversee and perform professional and technical work in the current and long-range planning programs of the City related to the development and implementation of land use and related municipal plans and policies; coordinates civil engineering projects, development review, and/or master plans; to coordinate assigned activities with other divisions, departments, consultants, contractors, and outside agencies; and to perform related duties as required.

DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS

The Planning Manager is a single incumbent managerial level (at-will) class serving as City Planner within the Community Development Department and as Division Manager exercising responsibility for the development and implementation of the City's General Plan and land use; planning and organizing a variety of assigned planning projects; and directing the work of assigned professional and technical staff. This classification is distinguished from the other classifications in the Planner series by the responsibility for developing, implementing and accomplishing the City's planning goals and objectives, and for ensuring that these goals and objectives are provided to the community in an effective, cost-efficient manner.

SUPERVISION RECEIVED AND EXERCISED

Receives general direction from the Community Development Director. Exercises direct and indirect supervision over professional, technical and field staff.

Essential Functions

ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS 



Plans, manages, leads, oversees and performs professional and technical City Planning work demonstrating a full understanding of applicable policies, procedures and work methods associated with assigned duties, including the Subdivision Map Act; the California Environmental Quality Act; the National Environmental Policy Act; the City of Eastvale's Municipal Code (Zoning Ordinance); the General Plan; pertinent provisions of the Building Code; and Federal and State statutes and regulations.
Coordinates City Planning activities with other divisions, departments, consultants, contractors, engineers, and outside agencies; advises the Community Development Director, City Manager, and City Council on technical matters.
Prepares and amends Zoning regulations, General Plan policies, and other City codes and policies that regulate land use, development, historic preservation and the environment.
Selects, trains, supervises and evaluates assigned professional, technical, and administrative support personnel; provides or coordinates staff training; assigns work activities, projects and programs; meets with staff to identify and resolve problems; works with employees to correct deficiencies.
Monitors and keeps informed of current trends in the field of municipal planning including legislation, court rulings and professional practices and techniques; evaluates their impact and makes recommendations to the Director regarding policy and procedural modifications accordingly.
Gathers, interprets, and prepares data for studies, reports and recommendations; coordinates department activities with other departments and agencies as needed to provide integrated services.
Evaluates land use proposals for conformity to established plans and ordinances; evaluates proposals' development impact as they relate to the adopted plans of the City and make recommendations; ensures compliance with applicable City, State or Federal laws.
Manages and directly performs the most complex land use issues, as needed, including but not limited to, development agreements, annexations, regional plans and growth projections.
Manages the Community Development customer service activities and resolves entitlement, land use policy, and code interpretation questions and issues for customers, and among various City departments involved in the entitlement process.
Provides advice regarding the land use entitlement process, City codes and policies to applicants, including landowners, developers and citizens.
Develops and monitors Department standards and service levels; coordinates activities and work programs with other City departments to ensure consistency of work plan measurements and adequacy of resources.
Manages the preparation of environmental documentation, and ensures excellent quality control for all CEQA and NEPA documents; ensures that appropriate mitigation measures are placed on development to reduce adverse impacts of development, commensurate with the level of impact.
Prepares and/or directs the preparation of grant applications pertaining to Planning Division functions and work programs.
Gives presentations to the City Council, boards, commissions, civic groups and the general public as needed and assigned.
Represents the City, Community Development Department, and/or Planning Division while providing support to a variety of City commissions, neighboring jurisdictions, boards and committees, including the Planning Commission, and various City Council sub-committees.
Assists in development of the Department's annual budget and work programs; allocates staff and resources among work program priorities.
Participates in the selection of personnel; supervise, discipline, train and evaluate subordinates.
Establishes positive working relationships with representatives of community organizations, state/local agencies and associations, City management and staff, and the public.
Assumes responsibility for ensuring the duties of the position are performed in a safe, efficient manner.
Performs related duties as assigned.

Experience, Training & License

EXPERIENCE, TRAINING, AND LICENSE

Any combination of experience and training that would likely provide the required knowledge and abilities may be qualifying. A typical way to obtain the knowledge and abilities would be: 

Qualifications:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in urban or regional planning, or a related field, and five years of progressively responsible professional experience in municipal current and long-range planning programs including three years in a supervisory capacity.

License/Certificate:

A California Class C Driver's License or the ability to obtain a valid license.

Possession of an American Institute of Certified Planners (AICP), CNU-A Accreditation, and active involvement in professional organizations such as or a combination of (but not limited to) American Planning Association (APA), Congress for New Urbanism (CNU), Association of Environmental Professionals (AEP), Association of Pedestrian and Bicycle Professionals (APBP), and Urban Land Institute (ULI).

KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of: 

Modern principles, procedures, practices and standards of municipal planning and community development; planning and zoning laws, ordinances, codes, modern developments, current literature and sources of information regarding City planning; comprehensive plans including their formation, process of adoption, and enforcement; Principles and practices of management, organization, budget practices, administrative procedures and fiscal management; principles and practices of contract administration; methods and techniques of supervision, training and motivation; applicable federal, state and local laws, codes, and regulations, including but not limited to the California Environmental Quality Act; methods and techniques of scheduling work assignments; standard office procedures, practices and equipment; modern office equipment, including a computer and applicable software including GIS applications; methods and techniques for record keeping and report preparation and writing; proper English, spelling and grammar; Methods and techniques for report preparation and writing; occupational hazards and standard safety practices.

Ability to: 

Manage, oversee, review, and perform the operations and activities of the Planning Division; analyze complex planning issues and develop solutions; plan, organize, direct and evaluate the effectiveness of assigned program activities; exercise supervisory control over complex professional and technical tasks, and perform the full range of professional planning tasks; prepare and administer a budget; interpret, explain and apply applicable laws, codes and regulations pertaining to municipal planning including Building codes; make adjustments to standard operating procedures to improve effectiveness and comply with regulatory changes as appropriate; organize, prioritize and follow-up on work assignments; work independently and as part of a team; make sound decisions within established guidelines; analyze complex issues and develop and implement an appropriate response; follow written and oral directions; promote and observe safety principles and work in a safe manner; communicate clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; establish and maintain effective working relationships with City personnel and the public; operate an office computer and a variety of word processing and software applications;

SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS

Ability to attend special City events including weekends, evenings and holidays, as required.

Ability to attend night meetings and work extended hours, as needed and/or required.

PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DEMANDS

The physical and mental demands described here are representative of those that must be met by employees to successfully perform the essential functions of this class Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Physical Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is constantly required to sit and frequently stand, walk, talk and hear, both in person and by telephone; use hands or fingers to handle, touch, or operate standard office equipment; and reach with hands and arms. The employee occasionally reaches for item above or below desk level, and lifts and carries records and documents, typically weighing less than 20 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the ability to adjust focus.

Mental Demands:

While performing the duties of this class, the employee is regularly required to use oral and written communication skills; exercise sound judgment in the absence of specific guidelines; establish priorities and work on multiple assignments and projects concurrently; meet intense and changing deadlines given continual interruptions; and interact appropriately with staff, City officials, Boards, Commissions, contractors, consultants and others encountered in the course of work.

WORKING CONDITIONS

The employee typically works in an office environment. The employee will be required to attend Council meetings and work on weekends or during the evenings. Occasional driving is required to attend special meetings at various City facilities, training sites, and public and private events.
